title: Fentanyl
text:
【0】Pregnancy, breastfeeding and fertility while using fentanyl
===========================================================

【1】Fentanyl and pregnancy
----------------------

【2】Fentanyl may occasionally be used for pain that is severe or difficult to treat during pregnancy.

【3】If you take fentanyl towards the end of pregnancy your baby might have withdrawal symptoms, such as drowsiness, after they're born. Your baby may need extra time in hospital for observation.

【4】It's important to treat pain in pregnancy. For some pregnant women with pain that lasts a long time or is difficult to treat, fentanyl might be the best option. Your doctor is the best person to help you decide what's right for you and your baby.

【5】Fentanyl and breastfeeding
--------------------------

【6】Fentanyl can be used if you're breastfeeding. It's important that your pain is controlled.

【7】Only very small amounts of fentanyl pass into breast milk, but there's still a small risk that it may cause side effects in your baby. Your doctor may recommend different painkillers first.

【8】If you do take fentanyl while breastfeeding, it's best to take it in low doses and only for a short time if possible. This reduces the risk of your baby getting side effects.

【9】It's also important not to stop breastfeeding suddenly so your baby does not get withdrawal symptoms.

【10】Talk to your doctor, pharmacist, health visitor or midwife as soon as possible if you have any concerns about your baby, including if you notice your baby:

【11】*   is not feeding as well as usual
*   has constipation
*   seems unusually pale

【12】### Urgent advice: Call 111 for advice or go to A&E now if:

【13】*   your baby is unusually sleepy
*   your baby has breathing problems

【14】However, these effects are very rare.

【15】If you need to go to A&E, take the fentanyl packet or leaflet inside it, plus any remaining medicine, with you.

【16】Fentanyl and fertility
----------------------

【17】There's no evidence that fentanyl affects fertility in either men or women.

【18】Speak to a pharmacist or your doctor if you're trying to get pregnant. They may want to review your treatment.

【19】Non-urgent advice: Tell your doctor if you're:
----------------------------------------------

【20】*   trying to get pregnant
*   pregnant
*   breastfeeding

【21】Information:

【22】Find out more about how fentanyl can affect you and your baby during pregnancy on the Best Use of Medicines in Pregnancy (BUMPS) website.

----------------

title: Ankylosing spondylitis
text:
【0】Complications \- Ankylosing spondylitis
=======================================

【1】Contents
--------

【2】1.  Overview
2.  Symptoms
3.  Causes
4.  Diagnosis
5.  Treatment
6.  Complications

【3】**Ankylosing spondylitis (AS) is a complex condition that can affect many parts of your body. It can cause complications in your day-to-day life and lead to additional health conditions.**

【4】Reduced flexibility
-------------------

【5】Although most people with AS remain fully independent or minimally disabled in the long term, some people with the condition eventually have severely restricted movement in their spine.

【6】This usually only affects the lower back and is the result of the bones in the spine joining up (fusing).

【7】Fusing of the spine can make it difficult to move your back and can mean your posture becomes fixed in 1 position, although it does not lead to severe disability in most cases.

【8】In rare cases surgery may be recommended to correct severe bends in the spine.

【9】Joint damage
------------

【10】AS can cause joints such as the hips and knees to become inflamed. This can damage the affected joints over time, making them painful and difficult to move.

【11】If a joint becomes particularly damaged, you may need surgery to replace it with an artificial joint.

【12】Iritis
------

【13】Iritis, also known as acute anterior uveitis, is a condition sometimes associated with AS where the front part of the eye becomes red and swollen. It usually only affects 1 eye, rather than both.

【14】If you have iritis, your eye may become red, painful and sensitive to light (photophobia). Your vision may also become blurred or cloudy.

【15】You should visit your GP as soon as possible if you have AS and think you may have developed iritis, as the condition can cause the loss of some or all of your vision if not treated promptly.

【16】If your GP thinks you have iritis, they'll refer you urgently to an ophthalmologist, a medical doctor who specialises in eye problems, for treatment.

【17】Iritis can usually be treated with corticosteroid eyedrops.

【18】Osteoporosis and spinal fractures
---------------------------------

【19】Osteoporosis is where the bones become weak and brittle. In AS osteoporosis can develop in the spine and increase your risk of fracturing the bones in your backbone. The longer you have the condition, the more this risk increases.

【20】If you do develop osteoporosis, you'll usually need to take medicine to help strengthen your bones.

【21】There are a number of medicines that can be used to treat osteoporosis, which can be taken by mouth (orally) as tablets or given by injection.

【22】Read about treating osteoporosis.

【23】Cardiovascular disease
----------------------

【24】If you have AS, you may also have an increased risk of developing cardiovascular disease (CVD). CVD is a general term that describes a disease of the heart or blood vessels, such as heart disease and stroke.

【25】Because of this increased risk, it's important to take steps to minimise your chances of developing CVD.

【26】Your rheumatologist, a specialist in treating muscle and joint conditions, can advise about lifestyle changes you should make to minimise your risk of developing CVD.

【27】These changes may include:

【28】*   stopping smoking – if you smoke
*   losing weight – if you are overweight or obese
*   taking regular exercise – 150 minutes of exercise a week can greatly improve your health
*   making changes to your diet to keep other conditions you may have under control – such as diabetes or high blood pressure

【29】You may also be prescribed medicine to reduce your blood pressure or blood cholesterol level.

【30】Cauda equina syndrome
---------------------

【31】Cauda equina syndrome is a very rare complication of AS that occurs when nerves at the bottom of your spine become compressed (compacted).

【32】Symptoms of cauda equina syndrome include:

【33】*   sciatica on both sides of your body
*   weakness or numbness in both legs that is severe or getting worse
*   numbness around or under your genitals, or around your anus
*   finding it hard to start peeing, being unable to pee or being unable to control when you pee – and this is not normal for you
*   not noticing when you need to poo or not being able to control when you poo – and this is not normal for you

【34】Go to A&E or call 999 if you have AS and you develop any of these symptoms.

【35】Psoriasis
---------

【36】It's common for people with AS to also have psoriasis, a skin condition that causes flaky patches of skin.

【37】There's no cure for psoriasis, but your GP can recommend treatments that can improve symptoms and the appearance of skin patches.

【38】Inflammatory bowel disease (IBD)
--------------------------------

【39】Some people with AS also have inflammatory bowel disease (IBD).

【40】Symptoms of IBD include:

【41】*   pain, cramps or swelling in the tummy
*   recurring or bloody diarrhoea
*   weight loss
*   extreme tiredness

【42】There are treatments that can relieve the symptoms and prevent them returning, including specific diets, lifestyle changes, medicines and surgery.

【43】See your GP if you have symptoms of IBD.

title: Spironolactone
text:
【0】About spironolactone \- Brand name: Aldactone
=============================================

【1】Spironolactone is a type of medicine called a diuretic. These medicines are sometimes called "water tablets" because they make you pee more.

【2】It is also an anti-androgen, which means it stops male hormones, such as testosterone, from working.

【3】Spironolactone is used to treat build-up of fluid in your body (oedema) caused by:

【4】*   heart failure
*   liver disease – it treats build-up of fluid in your abdomen, called ascites
*   kidney disease – it treats a condition that causes your kidneys to leak large amounts of protein into your pee, called nephrotic syndrome
*   high levels of aldosterone (a hormone made by the adrenal glands)

【5】It can also be used to treat high blood pressure (hypertension) when other medicines have not worked.

【6】Spironolactone is only available on prescription. It comes as tablets.

【7】Spironolactone also comes as tablets that contain other diuretics. When it's mixed with furosemide it's called by the brand name Lasilactone. When it's mixed with hydroflumethiazide it's called by the brand name Aldactide.

【8】Key facts
---------

【9】*   You'll usually take spironolactone once a day in the morning. Some people need to take it twice a day. If you're taking it twice a day, take the second dose before 4pm.
*   Take spironolactone with food, to help stop you feeling or being sick.
*   The most common side effect of spironolactone is high potassium levels. Your doctor will give you blood tests while you're taking spironolactone to make sure your potassium levels are stable.
*   Do not have low-sodium salt or salt substitutes, like Lo-Salt, because they contain a lot of potassium. Using these with spironolactone can cause your potassium levels to become too high.
*   Try to limit other food and drink that contain a lot of potassium, including bananas, avocados, pulses, nuts and salmon.

【10】More in Spironolactone
----------------------

title: Clotrimazole for thrush (Canesten)
text:
【0】About clotrimazole for thrush \- Brand name: Canesten
=====================================================

【1】Clotrimazole is an antifungal medicine.

【2】It's used to treat yeast infections, including thrush in men and women, although thrush is more common in women.

【3】Thrush is caused by a fungus (yeast) and can affect the vagina, the area around the vagina, breasts and nipples or the end of the penis. It can also affect other areas of skin, such as the armpits, top of the inner thighs (groin) and between the fingers. Clotrimazole works by killing the fungus (yeast) that is causing the infection.

【4】Clotrimazole comes as an external cream, an internal cream and a tablet you insert into your vagina (pessary).

【5】For vaginal thrush you can use either pessaries or cream, or both at the same time. The pessaries and internal cream are sometimes sold together.

【6】For thrush on the penis, breasts, armpits, groin or between the fingers you would use the external cream.

【7】Some Canesten products combine clotrimazole with other medicines. These include Canesten Thrush Duo Oral Capsule and External Cream. The capsule contains fluconazole, and Canesten cream contains clotrimazole.

【8】Clotrimazole for thrush is available to buy in pharmacies and shops. Some stronger treatments are only available with a prescription.

【9】Clotrimazole is also available as a cream, spray and solution to treat other fungal infections such as athlete’s foot, ringworm and nappy rash.

【10】Key facts
---------

【11】*   Clotrimazole works by killing the yeast that causes the fungal infection.
*   It usually treats thrush within 7 days but it's best to treat the infection for at least 2 weeks to stop it coming back.
*   The most common side effect is an itching or burning feeling in the area being treated. Clotrimazole cream can damage the latex used in condoms and diaphragms. This can mean your contraception will not work as well as it should.
*   Do not use clotrimazole for more than 14 days, unless a doctor tells you to. The fungal infection may become resistant and the medicine may stop working properly.

title: Liver disease
text:
【0】Liver disease
=============

【1】**There are many different types of liver disease. You can help prevent some of them by maintaining a healthy weight and staying within the recommended alcohol limits, if you drink.**

【2】Types of liver disease
----------------------

【3】There are several types of liver disease, which can have different causes.

【4】Common types of liver disease and the possible causes

| Condition | Possible causes |
| --- | --- |
| ConditionAlcohol-related liver disease  | Possible causesRegularly drinking too much alcohol  |
| ConditionNon-alcoholic fatty liver disease  | Possible causesBeing very overweight (obese) – this may cause fat to build up in the liver  |
| ConditionHepatitis  | Possible causesCatching a viral infection or regularly drinking too much alcohol  |
| ConditionHaemochromatosis  | Possible causesA gene that runs in families and may be passed from parents to children  |
| ConditionPrimary biliary cholangitis  | Possible causesMay be caused by a problem with the immune system  |

【6】Symptoms of liver disease
-------------------------

【7】Most types of liver disease do not cause any symptoms in the early stages.

【8】Once you start to get symptoms of liver disease, your liver is already damaged and scarred. This is known as cirrhosis.

【9】Symptoms of cirrhosis include:

【10】*   feeling very tired and weak all the time
*   loss of appetite – which may lead to weight loss
*   loss of sex drive (libido)
*   yellow skin and whites of the eyes (jaundice)
*   itchy skin
*   feeling or being sick

【11】Non-urgent advice: See a GP if:
-------------------------------

【12】you think you might have liver disease or cirrhosis

【13】Information:

【14】If you or your child has been diagnosed with liver disease, the British Liver Trust or Children's Liver Disease Foundation can also offer advice and support.

【15】Treatment for liver disease
---------------------------

【16】Treatment for liver disease depends on the type you have and how severe it is.

【17】Healthy lifestyle changes can help with some types of liver disease. For example, alcohol-related liver disease may improve if you stop drinking alcohol.

【18】Some types of liver disease (such as certain types of hepatitis) may need to be treated with medicine.

【19】If you have severe liver damage and scarring (cirrhosis), you may need a liver transplant.

【20】How to prevent liver disease
----------------------------

【21】The 3 main causes of liver disease are:

【22】*   obesity
*   an undiagnosed hepatitis infection
*   alcohol misuse

【23】You can reduce your risk of many types of liver disease with some simple lifestyle changes such as:

【24】*   trying to maintain a healthy weight
*   not drinking too much alcohol

【25】Vaccines are available for hepatitis A and hepatitis B. These are recommended if you're at risk.

【26】### Important

【27】You do not have to drink an excessive amount of alcohol to risk damaging your health. Regularly drinking just over the recommended levels can be harmful.

【28】More information
----------------

【29】*   Use the BMI healthy weight calculator to find out your body mass index (BMI)
*   Start the NHS weight loss plan
*   Read about cutting down on alcohol
*   Find out who should have the hepatitis A vaccine and who should have the hepatitis B vaccine

title: Kawasaki disease
text:
【0】Treatment \- Kawasaki disease
=============================

【1】Contents
--------

【2】1.  Overview
2.  Symptoms
3.  Causes
4.  Diagnosis
5.  Treatment
6.  Complications

【3】**Kawasaki disease is treated in hospital as it can cause serious complications. Treatment should begin as soon as possible.**

【4】It may take longer for your child to recover if Kawasaki disease isn't treated promptly.

【5】Their risk of developing complications will also be increased.

【6】The 2 main treatments for Kawasaki disease are:

【7】*   aspirin
*   intravenous immunoglobulin

【8】Aspirin
-------

【9】Your child may be prescribed aspirin if they have Kawasaki disease.

【10】This is one of the few occasions where aspirin may be recommended for a child under 16 years old.

【11】Never give your child aspirin, unless it's prescribed by a healthcare professional. It can cause side effects, including Reye's syndrome.

【12】Aspirin is a non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID).

【13】It's used to treat Kawasaki disease because:

【14】*   it can ease pain and discomfort
*   it can help reduce a high temperature
*   at high doses, aspirin is an anti-inflammatory (it reduces swelling)
*   at low doses, aspirin is an antiplatelet (it prevents blood clots forming)

【15】The dose of aspirin your child is prescribed and how long they need to take it for depends on their symptoms. 

【16】They'll probably be given high-dose aspirin until their temperature subsides.

【17】They may then be prescribed low-dose aspirin until 6 to 8 weeks after the start of their symptoms.

【18】This is to reduce blood clots if there are problems developing in the blood vessels that supply blood to the heart.

【19】Intravenous immunoglobulin
--------------------------

【20】Intravenous immunoglobulin is also called IVIG. Immunoglobulin is a solution of antibodies taken from healthy donors. Intravenous means it's injected directly into a vein.

【21】Antibodies are proteins the immune system produces to fight disease-carrying organisms.

【22】Research has shown IVIG can reduce fever and the risk of heart problems.

【23】The immunoglobulin used to treat Kawasaki disease is called gamma globulin.

【24】After your child is given IVIG, their symptoms should improve within 36 hours.

【25】If their high temperature doesn't improve after 36 hours, they may be given a second dose of IVIG.

【26】Corticosteroids
---------------

【27】Corticosteroids are a type of medicine that contain hormones, which are powerful chemicals that have a wide range of effects on the body.

【28】They may be recommended if IVIG hasn't been effective, or if your child is found to have a high risk of heart problems.

【29】Read more about corticosteroids.

【30】After treatment
---------------

【31】When your child is discharged from hospital, you should be given advice about how to care for them at home.

【32】This may include making sure they're as comfortable as possible and they drink plenty of fluids.

【33】Make sure your child continues taking any medicine that's been prescribed for them and look out for any side effects.

【34】Your child will be given a follow-up appointment and their heart will continue to be monitored.

【35】Once an ultrasound scan of the heart (echocardiogram) has confirmed that your child doesn't have any heart abnormalities, they can usually stop taking aspirin.

【36】Full recovery could take around 6 weeks, but may take longer in some children.

【37】Follow-up treatment may be needed if your child develops further complications.

【38】Support
-------

【39】The Kawasaki Support Group and Societi, the UK Foundation for Kawasaki Disease can give you further information and advice about your child's condition.

【40】Aspirin side effects
--------------------

【41】Aspirin isn't usually given to children under the age of 16 because it can cause side effects, including Reye's syndrome.

【42】Reye's syndrome is rare, but it can cause serious liver and brain damage, and be fatal if not treated quickly.

【43】The symptoms of Reye's syndrome include persistent vomiting and a lack of energy.

【44】Get medical help immediately if your child experiences either of these symptoms.

【45】See the Yellow Card Scheme website for more information.

title: Phenoxymethylpenicillin
text:
【0】Side effects of phenoxymethylpenicillin
=======================================

【1】Like all medicines, phenoxymethylpenicillin can cause side effects, although not everyone gets them.

【2】If you're taking phenoxymethylpenicillin to prevent infections, your doctor will usually ask you to have blood tests. This is to make sure you're not getting any unexpected side effects.

【3】Common side effects
-------------------

【4】These common side effects of phenoxymethylpenicillin happen in 1 in 10 people. There are things you can do to help cope with them:

【5】Feeling sick (nausea)

【6】Stick to simple meals and do not eat rich or spicy food while you're taking this medicine.

【7】Being sick (vomiting)

【8】Take small, frequent sips of water or squash to avoid dehydration. Signs of dehydration include peeing less than usual or having dark, strong-smelling pee. Do not take any other medicines to treat vomiting without speaking to a pharmacist or doctor.

【9】If you take contraceptive pills and you're being sick, your contraception may not protect you from pregnancy. Check the pill packet for advice.

【10】Diarrhoea

【11】Drink lots of fluids, such as water or squash, to avoid dehydration. Signs of dehydration include peeing less than usual or having dark, strong-smelling pee. Do not take any other medicines to treat diarrhoea without speaking to a pharmacist or doctor.

【12】If you take contraceptive pills and you have severe diarrhoea for more than 24 hours, your contraception may not protect you from pregnancy. Check the pill packet for advice.

【13】Stomach pain

【14】Try to rest and relax. It can help to eat and drink slowly and have smaller and more frequent meals. Putting a heat pad or covered hot water bottle on your stomach may also help. If you're in a lot of pain, speak to your pharmacist or doctor.

【15】Speak to a doctor or pharmacist if the advice on how to cope does not help and a side effect is still bothering you or does not go away.

【16】### Mild allergic reactions

【17】Around 1 in 10 people have an allergic reaction to phenoxymethylpenicillin.

【18】In most cases, the allergic reaction is mild.

【19】You can usually treat a mild allergic reaction by taking antihistamines.

【20】Talk to your doctor or pharmacist if you have a mild allergic reaction and your symptoms get worse.

【21】Serious side effects
--------------------

【22】Serious side effects are rare and happen in less than 1 in 1,000 people.

【23】Call your doctor or call 111 now if you get:

【24】*   stomach pain
*   a high temperature and watery diarrhoea with blood and mucus in it – this could be a sign that your bowels have become irritated and swollen (inflamed).

【25】### Serious allergic reaction

【26】In rare cases, phenoxymethylpenicillin can cause a serious allergic reaction (anaphylaxis).

【27】#### Immediate action required: Call 999 now if:

【28】*   your lips, mouth, throat or tongue suddenly become swollen
*   you're breathing very fast or struggling to breathe (you may become very wheezy or feel like you're choking or gasping for air)
*   your throat feels tight or you're struggling to swallow
*   your skin, tongue or lips turn blue, grey or pale (if you have black or brown skin, this may be easier to see on the palms of your hands or soles of your feet)
*   you suddenly become very confused, drowsy or dizzy
*   someone faints and cannot be woken up
*   a child is limp, floppy or not responding like they normally do (their head may fall to the side, backwards or forwards, or they may find it difficult to lift their head or focus on your face)

【29】You or the person who's unwell may also have a rash that's swollen, raised, itchy, blistered or peeling.

【30】These can be signs of a serious allergic reaction and may need immediate treatment in hospital.

【31】Other side effects
------------------

【32】These are not all the side effects of phenoxymethylpenicillin. For a full list, see the leaflet inside your medicine packet.

【33】Information:

【34】You can report any suspected side effect using the Yellow Card safety scheme.

【35】Visit Yellow Card for further information.

title: Infertility
text:
【0】Causes \- Infertility
=====================

【1】Contents
--------

【2】1.  Overview
2.  Causes
3.  Diagnosis
4.  Treatment

【3】**Infertility can be caused by many different things. For 1 in 4 couples, a cause cannot be identified.**

【4】Infertility in women
--------------------

【5】Infertility is commonly caused by problems with ovulation (the monthly release of an egg from the ovaries).

【6】Some problems stop an egg being released at all, while others prevent an egg being released during some cycles but not others.

【7】Ovulation problems can be a result of: 

【8】*   polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS)
*   thyroid problems – both an overactive thyroid gland and an underactive thyroid gland can prevent ovulation
*   premature ovarian failure – where the ovaries stop working before the age of 40

【9】### Scarring from surgery

【10】Pelvic surgery can damage and scar the fallopian tubes, which link the ovaries to the womb.

【11】Cervical surgery can also sometimes cause scarring or shorten the neck of the womb (the cervix).

【12】### Cervical mucus problems 

【13】When you're ovulating, mucus in your cervix becomes thinner so sperm can swim through it more easily. If there's a problem with the mucus, it can make it harder to conceive.

【14】### Fibroids

【15】Non-cancerous growths called fibroids in or around the womb can affect fertility. In some cases, they may prevent a fertilised egg attaching itself in the womb, or they may block a fallopian tube.

【16】### Endometriosis

【17】Endometriosis is a condition where tissue, similar to the lining of the womb (the endometrium), grows in other places outside of the womb.

【18】This can damage the ovaries or fallopian tubes and cause fertility problems.

【19】### Pelvic inflammatory disease

【20】Pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) is an infection of the upper female genital tract, which includes the womb, fallopian tubes and ovaries.

【21】It's often caused by a sexually transmitted infection (STI). PID can damage and scar the fallopian tubes, making it virtually impossible for an egg to travel down into the womb.

【22】### Sterilisation

【23】Some women choose to be sterilised if they do not want to have any more children.

【24】Sterilisation involves blocking the fallopian tubes to make it impossible for an egg to travel to the womb.

【25】It's rarely reversible – if you do have a sterilisation reversed, you will not necessarily be able to have a child.

【26】### Medicines and drugs 

【27】The side effects of some types of medicines and drugs can affect your fertility. These include:

【28】*   non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) – the long-term use or a high dosage of NSAIDs, such as ibuprofen or aspirin, can make it more difficult to conceive
*   chemotherapy – medicines used for chemotherapy can sometimes cause ovarian failure, which means your ovaries will no longer be able to function properly
*   neuroleptic medicines – antipsychotic medicines, often used to treat psychosis, can sometimes cause missed periods or infertility
*   spironolactone – a type of medicine used to treat fluid retention (oedema); fertility should recover around 2 months after you stop taking spironolactone

【29】Illegal drugs, such as marijuana and cocaine, can affect fertility and make ovulation more difficult.

【30】Infertility in men
------------------

【31】### Semen and sperm

【32】A common cause of infertility in men is poor-quality semen, the fluid containing sperm that's ejaculated during sex.

【33】Possible reasons for abnormal semen include:

【34】*   a lack of sperm – you may have a very low sperm count or no sperm at all
*   sperm that are not moving properly – this will make it harder for sperm to swim to the egg
*   abnormal sperm – sperm can sometimes be an abnormal shape, making it harder for them to move and fertilise an egg

【35】Many cases of abnormal semen are unexplained.

【36】There's a link between increased temperature of the scrotum and reduced semen quality, but it's uncertain whether wearing loose-fitting underwear improves fertility. 

【37】### Testicles

【38】The testicles produce and store sperm. If they're damaged, it can seriously affect the quality of your semen.

【39】This can happen as a result of:

【40】*   an infection of your testicles
*   testicular cancer
*   testicular surgery
*   a problem with your testicles you were born with (a congenital defect)
*   when 1 or both testicles has not descended into the scrotum (the loose sac of skin that contains your testicles (undescended testicles))
*   injury to your testicles

【41】### Sterilisation

【42】Some men choose to have a vasectomy if they do not want children or any more children. 

【43】It involves cutting and sealing off the tubes that carry sperm out of your testicles (the vas deferens) so your semen will no longer contain any sperm.

【44】A vasectomy can be reversed, but reversals are not usually successful.

【45】### Ejaculation disorders

【46】Some men experience ejaculation problems that can make it difficult for them to release semen during sex (ejaculate).

【47】### Hypogonadism

【48】Hypogonadism is an abnormally low level of testosterone, the male sex hormone involved in making sperm.

【49】It could be caused by a tumour, taking illegal drugs, or Klinefelter syndrome (a rare syndrome involving an extra female chromosome).

【50】### Medicines and drugs

【51】Certain types of medicines can sometimes cause infertility problems. These include:

【52】*   sulfasalazine – an anti-inflammatory medicine used to treat conditions such as Crohn's disease and rheumatoid arthritis; sulfasalazine can decrease the number of sperm, but its effects are temporary and your sperm count should return to normal when you stop taking it
*   anabolic steroids – are often used illegally to build muscle and improve athletic performance; long-term misuse of anabolic steroids can reduce sperm count and sperm mobility
*   chemotherapy – medicines used in chemotherapy can sometimes severely reduce sperm production
*   herbal remedies – some herbal remedies, such as root extracts of the Chinese herb Tripterygium wilfordii, can affect the production of sperm or reduce the size of your testicles

【53】Illegal drugs, such as marijuana and cocaine, can also affect semen quality.

【54】Unexplained infertility
-----------------------

【55】In the UK, unexplained infertility accounts for around 1 in 4 cases of infertility. This is when no cause can be identified in either partner.

【56】If a cause for your fertility problems has not been found, talk to your doctor about the next steps.

【57】The National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) recommends that women with unexplained infertility who have not conceived after 2 years of having regular unprotected sex should be offered IVF treatment.

【58】The NICE guidance has more about unexplained infertility.

【59】Find out more about fertility tests and how problems are diagnosed.

title: Mumps
text:
【0】Causes \- Mumps
===============

【1】Contents
--------

【2】1.  Overview
2.  Symptoms
3.  Causes
4.  Treatment
5.  Complications

【3】**Mumps is caused by the mumps virus, which belongs to a family of viruses known as paramyxoviruses. These viruses are a common source of infection, particularly in children.**

【4】When you get mumps, the virus moves from your respiratory tract (your nose, mouth and throat) into your parotid glands (saliva-producing glands found either side of your face), where it begins to reproduce. This causes the glands to swell.

【5】The virus can also enter your cerebrospinal fluid (CSF), which is the fluid that surrounds and protects your brain and spine. Once the virus has entered the CSF, it can spread to other parts of your body, such as your brain, pancreas, testicles (in boys and men) and ovaries (in girls and women).

【6】How mumps is spread
-------------------

【7】Mumps is an airborne virus and can be spread by:

【8】*   an infected person coughing or sneezing and releasing tiny droplets of contaminated saliva, which can then be breathed in by another person
*   an infected person touching their nose or mouth, then transferring the virus onto an object, such as a door handle, or work surface; if someone else touches the object shortly afterwards, they can transfer the virus into their respiratory tract
*   sharing utensils, such as cups, cutlery or plates with an infected person

【9】People with mumps are usually most infectious from a few days before their parotid glands swell until a few days afterwards. For this reason, it's advisable to avoid work or school for 5 days after your symptoms first develop if you're diagnosed with mumps.

【10】Mumps can also be passed on by people who are infected with the virus but don't have any obvious symptoms.

title: Zopiclone
text:
【0】About zopiclone
===============

【1】Zopiclone is a type of sleeping pill that can be taken for short-term treatment of severe insomnia.

【2】It helps you fall asleep more quickly, and also helps stop you waking up during the night. It works by affecting a calming chemical in your brain called gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA).

【3】Zopiclone comes as tablets. It also comes as a liquid for people who find it hard to swallow tablets, but your doctor will have to order this specially.

【4】This medicine is only available on prescription.

【5】Key facts
---------

【6】*   Zopiclone takes around 1 hour to work.
*   It's usually prescribed for just 2 to 4 weeks. This is because your body gets used to it quickly and after this time it's unlikely to have the same effect. Your body can also become dependent on it.
*   Common side effects are a metallic taste in your mouth, a dry mouth, and daytime sleepiness.
*   Do not drink alcohol while you're on zopiclone. Having them together can make you go into a deep sleep where you find it difficult to wake up.
*   If zopiclone makes you feel sleepy in the daytime, do not drive a car, ride a bike or use machinery.

title: Care after illness or hospital discharge (reablement)
text:
【0】Care after illness or hospital discharge (reablement)
=====================================================

【1】If you or someone you know has been in hospital or had an illness or fall, you may need temporary care to help you get back to normal and stay independent.

【2】This short-term care is sometimes called intermediate care, or aftercare. Reablement is a type of care that helps you relearn how to do daily activities, like cooking meals and washing.

【3】Most people who receive this type of care do so for around 1 or 2 weeks, although you get free, short-term care for a maximum of 6 weeks. It will depend on how soon you are able to cope at home.

【4】If you need care for longer than 6 weeks, you may have to pay for it.

【5】When you can get free short-term care and how to get it
-------------------------------------------------------

【6】### After leaving hospital

【7】Care can help you recover from an illness or an operation.

【8】Hospital staff will assess your health and help you to decide if you need further help to recover. If they think you do, they will arrange care before you leave hospital.

【9】Speak to the person in charge of you going home (discharge co-ordinator) to make sure this happens.

【10】Information:

【11】Contact social services if you have been discharged and care hasn't been arranged.

【12】The hospital will not get involved after you leave.

【13】### After a fall or short illness

【14】Care can help you avoid going into hospital if you do not need to.

【15】If you or someone you know falls or needs help because they're ill, speak to your GP surgery or social services.

【16】They may be able to arrange for someone to come to your home and discuss what you need.

【17】### If you have started to find everyday tasks difficult

【18】You can get help with daily tasks. This can help you learn new ways of doing things before needing paid home help.

【19】If you find everyday tasks difficult, you can apply for a needs assessment at GOV.UK. This will identify the type of care or equipment you need.

【20】What care you'll get
--------------------

【21】A team with a mix of people from the NHS and social services will help you do the things you need to do to stay independent.

【22】This might include getting dressed, preparing a meal, or getting up and down stairs.

【23】They might care for you at first, but will help you practise doing things on your own.

【24】Your team might include:

【25】*   a nurse
*   an occupational therapist
*   a physiotherapist
*   a speech and language therapist
*   a social worker
*   doctors
*   carers

【26】They'll start with an assessment that looks at what you can do. You'll agree together what you want to do and set out a plan.

【27】The plan will include a contact person who's in the team and the times and dates they'll visit you.

【28】What happens when aftercare finishes
------------------------------------

【29】When aftercare finishes, your team should work with you and your family or carers to agree what happens next.

【30】This should include:

【31】*   other care you might need, such as home help
*   how you can refer yourself again if you need to
*   what you should do if something goes wrong
*   information about what other types of support or equipment might help

【32】Ask your team's contact person about what happens next if your aftercare is coming to an end.

【33】More in Care after a hospital stay
----------------------------------

【34】*   Planning care before you leave hospital
*   Care after illness or hospital discharge (reablement)
*   Mental health aftercare if you have been sectioned

title: Acrivastine
text:
【0】Acrivastine \- Brand name: Benadryl Allergy Relief
==================================================

【1】On this page
------------

【2】1.  About acrivastine
2.  Key facts
3.  Who can and cannot take acrivastine
4.  How and when to take acrivastine
5.  Side effects
6.  How to cope with side effects of acrivastine
7.  Pregnancy and breastfeeding
8.  Cautions with other medicines
9.  Common questions about acrivastine

【3】1\. About acrivastine
---------------------

【4】Acrivastine is an antihistamine medicine that helps the symptoms of allergies.

【5】It's used to treat hay fever, conjunctivitis (red, itchy eyes), eczema and hives (urticaria).

【6】It's also used for reactions to insect bites and stings and for some food allergies.

【7】Acrivastine is known as a non-drowsy antihistamine. It's less likely to make you feel sleepy than some other antihistamines.

【8】Acrivastine is available on prescription. You can also buy it from pharmacies and supermarkets.

【9】It comes as capsules. Sometimes it's combined with a decongestant called pseudoephedrine to unblock your nose and sinuses.

【10】2\. Key facts
-------------

【11】*   It's usual to take acrivastine as you need it, up to 3 times a day.
*   Acrivastine is classed as non-drowsy antihistamine, but some people still find it makes them feel quite sleepy.
*   Common side effects include a dry mouth and dizziness.
*   Do not drink grapefruit juice while you're taking acrivastine – it might make you more likely to get side effects.
*   It's best not to drink alcohol while you're taking acrivastine as it can make you feel sleepy.
*   When acrivastine is mixed with pseudoephedrine, it's called Benadryl Allergy Relief Plus Decongestant. Some Benadryl products do not contain acrivastine, but a different antihistamine such as cetirizine.

【12】3\. Who can and cannot take acrivastine
---------------------------------------

【13】Acrivastine capsules that you buy from pharmacies and supermarkets can be taken by adults under the age of 65, and children aged 12 years and over.

【14】Acrivastine is not recommended for people over 65 because very little research on the medicine has been done in this age group.

【15】Talk to your pharmacist or doctor if you're over 65 and want to take acrivastine.

【16】Acrivastine is not suitable for some people. To make sure it's safe for you, tell your doctor or pharmacist if you:

【17】*   have ever had an allergic reaction to acrivastine or any other medicine
*   have kidney disease
*   have epilepsy or another health problem that puts you at risk of seizures or fits
*   have a rare illness called porphyria
*   are due to have an allergy test – taking acrivastine may affect the results, so you might need to stop taking it a few days before the test

【18】4\. How and when to take acrivastine
------------------------------------

【19】If you or your child have been prescribed acrivastine, follow your doctor's instructions about how and when to take it.

【20】If you bought acrivastine from a pharmacy or shop, follow the instructions that come with the packet.

【21】### Dosage

【22】Acrivastine comes as capsules (8mg). The usual dose in adults and children aged 12 and over is 1 capsule 3 times a day.

【23】When it's mixed with a decongestant, each capsule contains 8mg of acrivastine and 60mg of pseudoephedrine. The usual dose in adults and children aged 12 and over is 1 capsule 3 times a day.

【24】Do not take more than 3 acrivastine capsules, or 3 acrivastine mixed with pseudoephedrine capsules, in 24 hours.

【25】### How to take it

【26】Acrivastine does not usually upset your stomach. You can take it with or without food.

【27】Swallow the capsules whole. Do not chew them.

【28】Always take acrivastine capsules with a drink of water, milk or juice (but do not drink grapefruit juice with acrivastine as you may be more likely to get side effects).

【29】### When to take it

【30】You may only need to take acrivastine on a day you have symptoms, such as when you've been near to something you're allergic to, like animal hair.

【31】Or you may need to take it regularly to prevent symptoms, such as to stop hay fever during spring and summer.

【32】### What if I forget to take it?

【33】Take your forgotten dose as soon as you remember, unless it's nearly time for your next dose. In this case, skip the missed dose and take your next dose at the usual time.

【34】Do not take 2 doses to make up for a forgotten dose. Do not take more than 3 capsules in 24 hours.

【35】If you often forget doses, it may help to set an alarm to remind you. You could also ask your pharmacist for advice on other ways to help you remember to take your medicine.

【36】### What if I take too much?

【37】Acrivastine is generally very safe. Taking more than your prescribed dose is unlikely to harm you. If you take an extra dose, you might get some of the common side effects.

【38】If this happens or you're concerned, contact your doctor.

【39】#### Urgent advice: Contact 111 for advice now if:

【40】*   you take more than your usual dose of acrivastine and pseudoephedrine (Benadryl Allergy Relief Plus Decongestant) and experience side effects

【41】These include:

【42】*   getting the shakes
*   changes in your heart rate

【43】Go to 111.nhs.uk or call 111

【44】If you need to go to A&E, do not drive yourself. Get someone else to drive you or call for an ambulance.

【45】Take the acrivastine packet, or the leaflet inside it, plus any remaining medicine with you.

【46】5\. Side effects
----------------

【47】Like all medicines, acrivastine can cause side effects, although not everyone gets them.

【48】### Common side effects

【49】There are some differences between the side effects of medicines that only contain acrivastine, and medicines that combine acrivastine with pseudoephedrine.

【50】The most common side effect of acrivastine is feeling sleepy and tired. This happens in more than 1 in 10 people.

【51】Other common side effects of acrivastine happen in more than 1 in 100 people. These include:

【52】*   dry mouth
*   feeling dizzy

【53】Talk to your doctor or pharmacist if these side effects bother you or do not go away.

【54】The common side effects of acrivastine when mixed with pseudoephedrine happen in more than 1 in 100 people. They include:

【55】*   difficulty sleeping
*   feeling sick (nausea)
*   headaches
*   feeling nervous
*   difficulty peeing (for men), especially those with an enlarged prostate

【56】If you experience any of these, stop taking it and talk to your doctor or pharmacist about trying an acrivastine-only medicine.

【57】### Serious side effects

【58】Call a doctor straight away if:

【59】*   you start seeing things that are not there (hallucinations)
*   you get a rash
*   you get pain or discomfort in the chest, neck, back or shoulders – these could be signs of angina, or a heart attack
*   your skin gets more red than usual or you get small, pus-filled blisters on the skin – these could be signs of a condition called acute generalised exanthematous pustulosis (AGEP). This usually happens within the first 2 days of treatment
*   you get sudden stomach pains or start bleeding from your bottom (rectal bleeding)
*   you suddenly cannot see properly

【60】#### Immediate action required: Call 999 or go to A&E now if:

【61】*   you have weakness of the face, arms or legs, or speech problems – these could be signs of a stroke

【62】#### Serious allergic reaction

【63】In rare cases, it's possible to have a serious allergic reaction (anaphylaxis) to acrivastine.

【64】##### Immediate action required: Call 999 now if:

【65】*   your lips, mouth, throat or tongue suddenly become swollen
*   you're breathing very fast or struggling to breathe (you may become very wheezy or feel like you're choking or gasping for air)
*   your throat feels tight or you're struggling to swallow
*   your skin, tongue or lips turn blue, grey or pale (if you have black or brown skin, this may be easier to see on the palms of your hands or soles of your feet)
*   you suddenly become very confused, drowsy or dizzy
*   someone faints and cannot be woken up
*   a child is limp, floppy or not responding like they normally do (their head may fall to the side, backwards or forwards, or they may find it difficult to lift their head or focus on your face)

【66】You or the person who's unwell may also have a rash that's swollen, raised, itchy, blistered or peeling.

【67】These can be signs of a serious allergic reaction and may need immediate treatment in hospital.

【68】These are not all the side effects of acrivastine. For a full list, see the leaflet inside your medicines packet.

【69】Information:

【70】You can report any suspected side effect using the Yellow Card safety scheme.

【71】Visit Yellow Card for further information.

【72】6\. How to cope with side effects of acrivastine
------------------------------------------------

【73】**What to do about:**

【74】*   **feeling sleepy** – try a different non-drowsy antihistamine. If this does not help, talk to your doctor.
*   **dry mouth** – chew sugar-free gum or suck sugar-free sweets.
*   **feeling dizzy** – lie down until the dizziness passes, then get up slowly. Move slowly and carefully. It's best to avoid coffee, cigarettes, alcohol and recreational drugs. If the dizziness does not get better within a couple of days, speak to your pharmacist or doctor.

【75】7\. Pregnancy and breastfeeding
-------------------------------

【76】### Acrivastine and pregnancy

【77】Acrivastine is not usually recommended during pregnancy because there is very little information about its use in pregnancy. Other antihistamines that we know more about may be more suitable.

【78】If you think you need to take acrivastine in pregnancy, talk to your doctor or pharmacist. They will be able to help you decide, or may suggest other medicines for you.

【79】### Acrivastine and breastfeeding

【80】If your doctor or health visitor says your baby is healthy, you can use acrivastine while breastfeeding, but it is better to take occasional doses or only for a short time.

【81】We do not know how much acrivastine gets into breast milk, so it is better to take an antihistamine which we know more about.

【82】If you're breastfeeding, or planning to breastfeed, talk to your doctor. They may prescribe similar antihistamines, called loratadine or cetirizine, that are more suitable while you're breastfeeding.

【83】Talk to your doctor, pharmacist, midwife or health visitor if your baby is not feeding as well as usual, seems unusually sleepy, seems irritable, or if you have any other concerns about your baby.

【84】### Non-urgent advice: Tell your doctor if you're:

【85】*   trying to get pregnant
*   pregnant
*   breastfeeding

【86】8\. Cautions with other medicines
---------------------------------

【87】Some medicines affect how acrivastine works or can increase the chances of you having side effects.

【88】Check with your pharmacist or doctor if you're taking:

【89】*   ketoconazole, a medicine to treat fungal infections
*   erythromycin, an antibiotic
*   any medicine that makes you sleepy, gives you a dry mouth, or makes it difficult for you to pee – taking acrivastine might make these side effects worse

【90】Acrivastine mixed with pseudoephedrine (Benadryl Allergy Relief Plus Decongestant) affects lots of medicines. Check with your pharmacist or doctor before you take it.

【91】### Mixing acrivastine with herbal remedies and supplements

【92】There might be a problem taking some herbal remedies and supplements alongside acrivastine, especially ones that cause sleepiness, a dry mouth, or make it difficult to pee.

【93】Ask your pharmacist for advice.

【94】### Important: Medicine safety

【95】Tell your doctor or pharmacist if you're taking any other medicines, including herbal medicines, vitamins or supplements.

【96】9\. Common questions about acrivastine
--------------------------------------

【97】How does acrivastine work?

【98】Acrivastine is a type of medicine called an antihistamine.

【99】When you come into contact with something you're allergic to, such as pollen, animal hair or if you're bitten or stung by an insect, your body produces a chemical called histamine.

【100】Usually histamine is a useful substance, but in an allergic reaction it causes unpleasant symptoms including itchy, watery eyes, a running or blocked nose, sneezing and skin rashes.

【101】Acrivastine blocks the effects of histamine and reduces these symptoms.

【102】When will I feel better?

【103】You should start to feel better within 1 to 2 hours of taking acrivastine.

【104】How long should I take acrivastine for?

【105】It depends on why you're taking acrivastine.

【106】You may only need to take it as a one-off dose or for 1 or 2 days – for example, if you have a reaction to an insect bite.

【107】You may need to take acrivastine for longer if you're taking it to prevent symptoms – for example, to stop hay fever when the pollen count is high.

【108】Talk to your doctor or pharmacist if you're unsure how long you need to take acrivastine for.

【109】Is it safe to take acrivastine for a long time?

【110】Acrivastine is unlikely to do you any harm if you take it for a long time. But it's best to take it only for as long as you need to.

【111】Can I drink alcohol with it?

【112】It's best not to drink alcohol while you're taking acrivastine as it can make you feel sleepy.

【113】Is there any food or drink I need to avoid?

【114】Do not drink grapefruit juice when you're taking acrivastine. It might make you more likely to have side effects.

【115】Can I drive or ride a bike with it?

【116】Acrivastine is classed as a non-drowsy antihistamine, but it's still possible to feel sleepy after taking it.

【117】If this happens to you, do not drive a car, ride a bike or operate machinery until you feel awake and not tired anymore.

【118】It's an offence to drive a car if your ability to drive safely is affected. It's your responsibility to decide if it's safe to drive. If you're in any doubt, do not drive.

【119】Talk to your doctor or pharmacist if you're unsure whether it's safe for you to drive while taking acrivastine. GOV.UK has more information on the law on drugs and driving.

【120】Can I use acrivastine to help me sleep?

【121】Do not use acrivastine to help you sleep. It's not meant to be used this way and probably will not work either.

【122】If you take the recommended dose, acrivastine causes little or no sleepiness in most people.

【123】If you do feel sleepy after taking acrivastine, it usually wears off after a few days of treatment.

【124】Speak to your doctor if you're having difficulty sleeping.

【125】Does acrivastine make you put on weight?

【126】There's no evidence that acrivastine makes you put on weight.

【127】What's the difference between acrivastine and other antihistamines?

【128】Acrivastine is known as a non-drowsy antihistamine. That's because it's less likely to make you feel sleepy than other so-called sedating antihistamines, such as Piriton (chlorphenamine).

【129】Most people prefer to take a non-drowsy antihistamine instead of a sedating one.

【130】An exception is when you want the medicine to make you sleepy – for example, if you have itchy skin that's keeping you awake.

【131】What's the difference between acrivastine and other non-drowsy antihistamines?

【132】Other non-drowsy antihistamines like cetirizine, loratadine, desloratadine, fexofenadine and levocetirizine seem to work just as well as acrivastine.

【133】But you need to take acrivastine 3 times a day, whereas other non-drowsy antihistamines are only taken once a day.

【134】If one non-drowsy antihistamine has not worked for you, it's worth trying another one.

【135】Can I take it with painkillers?

【136】Yes, you can take acrivastine together with paracetamol or ibuprofen.

【137】Can I take more than 1 type of antihistamine in the same day?

【138】Sometimes doctors recommend that people with a severe itchy skin rash take 2 different antihistamines together for a few days.

【139】As well as taking a non-drowsy antihistamine during the day (such as acrivastine, cetirizine or loratadine), your doctor may advise that you take a sedating antihistamine at night if the itching is making it difficult to sleep.

【140】Do not take 2 antihistamines together unless you have been advised to by your doctor.

【141】Can I take acrivastine with other hay fever treatments?

【142】Yes, it's fine to take acrivastine together with some other hay fever treatments – for example, steroid nasal sprays (such as Beconase, Rhinocort Aqua and Flixonase Nasules) or eye drops.

【143】Will it affect my fertility?

【144】There's no evidence to suggest that taking acrivastine will reduce fertility in either men or women.

【145】But speak to a pharmacist or your doctor before taking it if you're trying to get pregnant.

【146】Will it affect my contraception?

【147】Acrivastine does not affect any type of contraception, including the combined pill and emergency contraception.

【148】Can lifestyle changes relieve hay fever?

【149】It'll help if you don't spend too much time outside if the pollen count is high.

【150】### Tips for when you're outside

【151】*   Do not cut grass or walk on grass.
*   Wear wraparound sunglasses to stop pollen getting into your eyes.
*   Put Vaseline around your nostrils to help trap pollen.
*   Shower and change your clothes after you have been outside to wash off pollen.

【152】### Tips for when you're inside

【153】*   Keep windows and doors shut as much as possible.
*   Vacuum regularly and dust with a damp cloth.
*   Do not keep fresh flowers in the house.
*   Do not smoke or be around smoke as it makes hay fever symptoms worse.

title: How long does it usually take to get pregnant?
text:
【0】How long does it usually take to get pregnant?
==============================================

【1】It's impossible to say how long it takes to get pregnant because it's different for each woman.

【2】Many factors can affect a couple's chances of conceiving, such as:

【3】*   your age
*   your general health
*   your reproductive health
*   how often you have sex

【4】Some women become pregnant quickly, while others take longer. This may be upsetting, but it's normal.

【5】Fertility
---------

【6】Most couples will get pregnant within a year if they have regular sex and don't use contraception.

【7】But women become less fertile as they get older.

【8】The effect of age on men's fertility is less clear.

【9】What does 'regular sex' mean?
-----------------------------

【10】Having regular sex means having sex every 2 to 3 days throughout the month.

【11】Some couples may try to time having sex with when the woman ovulates (releases an egg).

【12】But do not worry about the timing of when you have sex if it makes you feel stressed.

【13】Fertility problems
------------------

【14】Lots of factors can cause fertility problems, including:

【15】*   hormonal (endocrine) disorders, such as polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) and problems with the thyroid or pituitary glands
*   physical disorders, such as obesity, anorexia nervosa or excessive exercise
*   disorders of the reproductive system, such as infections, blocked fallopian tubes, endometriosis or a low sperm count
*   menopause

【16】Some of these factors affect either women or men.

【17】The most common causes are ovulation failure (which can be caused by lots of different things) and sperm disorders.

【18】Read more detailed information about the causes of infertility.

【19】Getting help
------------

【20】If you have been trying for a baby for 1 year without success, see your GP for advice.

title: Quetiapine
text:
【0】Side effects of quetiapine \- Brand names: Atrolak, Biquelle, Seroquel, Sondate, Zaluron
========================================================================================

【1】Like all medicines, quetiapine can cause side effects, although not everyone gets them.

【2】Common side effects
-------------------

【3】These common side effects of quetiapine may happen in more than 1 in 10 people. There are things you can do to help cope with them:

【4】Feeling sleepy during the day

【5】Do not drive, cycle or use tools or machinery. Try to avoid drinking alcohol as this will make you feel more tired.

【6】As your body gets used to quetiapine this side effect should wear off. If it still makes you feel sleepy after a few weeks, speak to your doctor.

【7】Problems with your movement

【8】Speak to your doctor if you have any problems with your movement. This can include difficulty moving or stiff muscles that make your movements jerky. Sometimes you may feel like you "freeze up" and then restart moving. You may have other symptoms like a slow shuffling walk, tremors and drooling.

【9】Headache

【10】Make sure you rest and drink plenty of fluids. Do not drink too much alcohol. Ask your pharmacist to recommend a painkiller.

【11】Talk to your doctor if headaches last longer than a week or are severe.

【12】Feeling dizzy

【13】Stop what you're doing and sit or lie down until you feel better. Do not drive, cycle or use tools or machinery. Try to avoid drinking alcohol as this will make you feel worse.

【14】If you feel dizzy when you stand up, try standing up slowly and hold onto something to steady your balance until the dizziness has passed. It should only last a few moments.

【15】As your body gets used to quetiapine, this side effect should wear off. If you still feel dizzy after a few weeks, speak to your doctor.

【16】Putting on weight or changes to your appetite

【17】If quetiapine makes you feel more hungry than usual, try to eat a healthy, balanced diet without increasing your portion sizes. Do not snack on foods that contain a lot of calories, such as crisps, cakes, biscuits and sweets. If you feel hungry between meals, eat fruit and vegetables and low-calorie foods. Regular exercise will also help to keep your weight stable.

【18】Constipation

【19】Get more fibre into your diet, such as fresh fruit, vegetables and cereals, and drink plenty of water. Try to exercise more regularly, for example, by going for a daily walk or run. If this does not help, talk to your pharmacist or doctor.

【20】Swollen breasts, pain in your breasts or leaking breast milk

【21】Speak to your doctor if you get this side effect.

【22】Irregular periods or stopped periods

【23】Speak to your doctor if you get changes to your periods.

【24】Fast heartbeat

【25】Speak to your doctor if you get this side effect.

【26】Speak to a doctor or pharmacist if the advice on how to cope does not help and a side effect is still bothering you or does not go away.

【27】Serious side effects
--------------------

【28】Serious side effects are uncommon and may happen in up to 1 in 100 people.

【29】Speak to your doctor or call 111 now if you get:

【30】*   twitching or jerking movements that you cannot control in your face, tongue, or other parts of your body
*   infections, such as cold or flu symptoms, high temperature, or ear, eye, bladder or chest infections
*   swelling, pain and redness in your leg – this may be a sign of blood clots

【31】### Immediate action required: Call 999 if:

【32】*   you have weakness on one side of your face or body, trouble speaking or thinking, loss of balance or blurred eyesight – these can be signs of a stroke

【33】### Immediate action required: Call 999 or go to A&E if:

【34】*   you have a painful erection that lasts more than 2 hours (priapism) – this may happen even when you are not having sex
*   you have chest pain or difficulty breathing – these may be signs of a blood clot in your lungs
*   you have a high temperature, muscle stiffness, sweating, anxiety or excess saliva – these may be signs of a disorder called neuroleptic malignant syndrome

【35】Find your nearest A&E

【36】### Serious allergic reaction

【37】In rare cases, it's possible to have a serious allergic reaction (anaphylaxis) to quetiapine.

【38】#### Immediate action required: Call 999 now if:

【39】*   your lips, mouth, throat or tongue suddenly become swollen
*   you're breathing very fast or struggling to breathe (you may become very wheezy or feel like you're choking or gasping for air)
*   your throat feels tight or you're struggling to swallow
*   your skin, tongue or lips turn blue, grey or pale (if you have black or brown skin, this may be easier to see on the palms of your hands or soles of your feet)
*   you suddenly become very confused, drowsy or dizzy
*   someone faints and cannot be woken up
*   a child is limp, floppy or not responding like they normally do (their head may fall to the side, backwards or forwards, or they may find it difficult to lift their head or focus on your face)

【40】You or the person who's unwell may also have a rash that's swollen, raised, itchy, blistered or peeling.

【41】These can be signs of a serious allergic reaction and may need immediate treatment in hospital.

【42】Other side effects
------------------

【43】These are not all the side effects of quetiapine. For a full list see the leaflet inside your medicines packet.

【44】Information:

【45】You can report any suspected side effect using the Yellow Card safety scheme.

【46】Visit Yellow Card for further information.

title: Tips for your birth partner
text: 【0】Tips for your birth partner =========================== 【1】Whoever your birth partner is – the baby's parent, a close friend, partner, or a relative – there are many practical things they can do to help you.  【2】The most important thing your birth partner can do is just be with you. 【3】Talk to your birth partner about the type of birth you'd like and the things you prefer not to do so they can help support your decisions. It can help to go through your birth plan together.  【4】There's no way of knowing what your labour is going to be like or how each of you will cope, but there are many ways a partner can help. 【5】Whatever kind of birth you're planning for, your birth partner can: 【6】* keep you company and help pass the time during the early stages * hold your hand, wipe your face and give you sips of water * massage your back and shoulders, and help you move about or change position * comfort you as your labour progresses and your contractions get stronger * remind you how to use relaxation and breathing techniques, perhaps breathing with you if it helps * support your decisions, such as the pain relief you choose, even if they're different from what's in your birth plan * help you explain to the midwife or doctor what you need – and help them communicate with you – which can help you feel more in control of the situation * tell you what's happening as your baby is being born if you cannot see what's going on 【7】Your birth partner may be able to cut the umbilical cord – you can talk to your midwife about this. 【8】You can also read about feelings and relationships in pregnancy, including worries about the birth and sex in pregnancy. 【9】Make sure you and your birth partner both know what to pack for the birth, and what to expect at the hospital or maternity unit if you're planning to have your baby there. 【10】Find maternity services near you. 【11】Community content from HealthUnlocked 【12】More in What happens in labour and birth ---------------------------------------- 【13】* The stages of labour and birth * Tips for your birth partner * Giving birth to twins or more * Pain relief in labour * Episiotomy and perineal tears * Forceps or vacuum delivery * What happens if your baby is breech? * What complications can affect the placenta? 【14】Page last reviewed: 12 May 2023 Next review due: 12 May 2026

title: Omeprazole
text:
【0】How and when to take omeprazole \- Brand names: Losec, Losec MUPS, Pyrocalm
===========================================================================

【1】Always follow instructions from your doctor, or the instructions inside the pack on how to take it.

【2】Dosage and strength
-------------------

【3】Each tablet or capsule contains 10mg, 20mg or 40mg of omeprazole. Liquid omeprazole comes labelled as either 2mg/1ml or 4mg/1ml.

【4】The usual dose to treat:

【5】*   indigestion is 10mg to 20mg a day
*   heartburn and acid reflux is 20mg to 40mg a day
*   stomach ulcers is 20mg to 40mg a day
*   Zollinger-Ellison syndrome is 20mg to 120mg a day

【6】Doses are usually lower for children and people with liver problems.

【7】### Changes to your dose

【8】Sometimes your doctor will increase your dose of omeprazole if it is not working well enough.

【9】Depending on the reason you take omeprazole, you may take a higher dose to begin with, usually for a few weeks.

【10】After this, your doctor may recommend that you take a lower dose.

【11】How to take it
--------------

【12】You’ll usually take omeprazole once a day, first thing in the morning. It will not affect your stomach, so you can take it with or without food.

【13】If you take omeprazole twice a day, take 1 dose in the morning and 1 dose in the evening.

【14】Swallow tablets and capsules whole with a drink of water or squash.

【15】If you have problems swallowing capsules, most brands of omeprazole capsules are easy to open. This means you can empty the granules inside and mix them into a small amount of water or squash. You could also sprinkle them on soft food, such as yoghurt or apple puree.

【16】Talk to your pharmacist if you're not sure whether you can open your capsules.

【17】Omeprazole also comes as a tablet that melts in your mouth.

【18】You can buy omeprazole 20mg tablets from pharmacies and supermarkets. You cannot buy omeprazole capsules, they are prescription only.

【19】Omeprazole tablets that you buy from pharmacies or supermarkets can be taken by adults for up to 14 days.

【20】Liquid omeprazole can be prescribed by a doctor for children and people who cannot swallow capsules or tablets.

【21】If you or your child is taking omeprazole as a liquid, it will usually be made up for you by your pharmacist. It will come with a syringe or spoon to help you take the right amount. If you do not have a syringe or spoon, ask your pharmacist for one. Do not use a kitchen teaspoon because it will not measure the right amount.

【22】How long to take it for
-----------------------

【23】If you bought the medicine yourself from a pharmacy or supermarket, you can take it for up to 14 days. If you feel no better after taking omeprazole for 14 days, tell your doctor. They may want to do tests to find out what's causing your symptoms or change you to a different medicine.

【24】Depending on your condition or the reason you're taking omeprazole, you may only need it for a few weeks or months. Sometimes, you might need to take it for longer, even for many years.

【25】Some people do not need to take omeprazole every day and take it only when they have symptoms.

【26】Once you feel better (often after a few days or weeks), you can stop taking it.

【27】But taking omeprazole for a short time to treat symptoms is not suitable for everyone. Talk to your doctor about what's best for you.

【28】If you forget to take it
------------------------

【29】If you usually take it once a day, take the missed dose as soon as you remember. If it’s 12 hours or less to your next dose, do not take it.

【30】If you usually take it twice a day, take the missed dose as soon as you remember. If it’s 4 hours or less to your next dose, do not take it.

【31】Do not take 2 doses to make up for a forgotten one.

【32】If you forget doses often, it may help to set an alarm to remind you. You could also ask your pharmacist for advice on other ways to help you remember to take your medicine.

【33】Stopping omeprazole
-------------------

【34】Usually, you can stop taking omeprazole without reducing your dose first. But if you've been taking omeprazole for a long time, speak to your doctor before you stop taking it. Stopping suddenly could make your stomach produce a lot more acid, and make your symptoms come back.

【35】Reducing the dose gradually before stopping completely will prevent this happening.

【36】If you take too much
--------------------

【37】It's very unlikely that taking 1 or 2 extra doses by accident will cause any problems.

【38】But you should check if you are worried.

【39】### Urgent advice: Contact 111 for advice now if:

【40】You take more than your prescribed dose and have any of the following symptoms:

【41】*   feeling sick
*   being sick
*   feeling dizzy
*   stomach pain
*   diarrhoea
*   headache

【42】Go to 111.nhs.uk or call 111

【43】If you need advice for a child under the age of 5 years, call 111.

title: Osteopathy
text:
【0】Overview \- Osteopathy
======================

【1】Contents
--------

【2】1.  Overview
2.  How it's performed
3.  Safety and regulation

【3】**Osteopathy is a way of detecting, treating and preventing health problems by moving, stretching and massaging a person's muscles and joints.**

【4】Osteopathy is based on the principle that the wellbeing of an individual depends on their bones, muscles, ligaments and connective tissue functioning smoothly together.

【5】Osteopaths use physical manipulation, stretching and massage with the aim of:

【6】*   increasing the mobility of joints
*   relieving muscle tension
*   reducing pain
*   enhancing the blood supply to tissues
*   helping the body to heal

【7】They use a range of techniques, but not medicines or surgery.

【8】In the UK, osteopathy is a health profession regulated by UK law.

【9】Read about how osteopathy is performed.

【10】When it's used
--------------

【11】Most people who see an osteopath do so for help with conditions that affect the muscles, bones and joints, such as:

【12】*   lower back pain
*   uncomplicated neck pain (as opposed to neck pain after an injury such as whiplash)
*   shoulder pain and elbow pain (for example, tennis elbow)
*   arthritis
*   problems with the pelvis, hips and legs
*   sports injuries
*   muscle and joint pain associated with driving, work or pregnancy

【13】If you're pregnant, make sure you seek advice from a GP or midwife about your symptoms before you see an osteopath. You should also make sure you see an osteopath who specialises in muscle or joint pain during pregnancy.

【14】Effectiveness of osteopathy
---------------------------

【15】Most research into techniques used in osteopathy tends to focus on general "manual therapy" techniques, such as spinal manipulation. Manual therapy techniques are used by physiotherapists and chiropractors, as well as osteopaths.

【16】The National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) guidelines on managing lower back pain and sciatica recommend manual therapy alongside exercise as a treatment option.

【17】NICE also recommends manual therapy as a possible treatment option for osteoarthritis, although osteopathy is not specifically mentioned.

【18】There's some evidence to suggest that osteopathy may be effective for some types of neck, shoulder or lower-limb pain, some types of headache, and recovery after hip or knee operations.

【19】There's only limited or no scientific evidence that it's an effective treatment for conditions unrelated to the bones and muscles (musculoskeletal system), including:

【20】*   asthma
*   period pain
*   digestive disorders
*   depression
*   excessive crying in babies (colic)
*   glue ear
*   problems affecting the jaw (temporomandibular disorder)
*   abnormal curvature of the spine (scoliosis)

【21】Accessing osteopathy
--------------------

【22】Osteopathy is available in some areas on the NHS. Your GP or local integrated care board (ICB) should be able to tell you whether it's available in your area.

【23】Most people pay for osteopathy treatment privately. Treatment costs vary, but typically range from £40 to £55 for a 30- to 40-minute session.

【24】You do not need to be referred by your GP to see an osteopath privately. Most private health insurance providers also provide cover for osteopathic treatment.

【25】Only people registered with the General Osteopathic Council (GOsC) are allowed to practise as or call themselves osteopaths.

【26】You can find a nearby registered osteopath on the GOsC website.

【27】Read more about how osteopathy is regulated.

title: Macrogol
text:
【0】Pregnancy, breastfeeding and fertility while taking macrogol \- Brand names: Movicol, Laxido, CosmoCol, Molaxole
================================================================================================================

【1】Macrogol and pregnancy
----------------------

【2】Macrogol can be taken during pregnancy. Constipation is more common at the end of pregnancy and just after having a baby.

【3】If you're pregnant, your doctor or midwife may advise you to first try to treat constipation without taking a medicine.

【4】You can do this by eating more fibre (like potatoes, high-fibre cereals, wholemeal bread, brown rice or wholewheat pasta, fruit and vegetables) and drinking plenty of fluids. You'll also be encouraged to do gentle exercise.

【5】If dietary and lifestyle changes do not work, your doctor or midwife may recommend a laxative such as macrogol.

【6】Macrogol and breastfeeding
--------------------------

【7】It is always better to treat constipation without taking a medicine first. If diet and lifestyle changes do not work, your doctor or midwife may recommend a laxative.

【8】You can take macrogol while breastfeeding. It does not pass into breast milk so it's very unlikely to cause any side effects in your baby.

【9】If you have any concerns about your baby, talk to your health visitor, midwife, pharmacist or doctor.

【10】Macrogol and fertility
----------------------

【11】There's no good evidence to suggest that taking macrogol reduces fertility in either men or women.

【12】Non-urgent advice: Tell your doctor if you're:
----------------------------------------------

【13】*   trying to get pregnant
*   pregnant
*   breastfeeding

【14】Find out more about how laxatives such as macrogol can affect you and your baby during pregnancy on the Best Use of Medicines in Pregnancy (BUMPS) website.

【15】More in Macrogol
----------------
