title: Escitalopram
text:
【0】Side effects of escitalopram
============================

【1】Like all medicines, escitalopram can cause side effects in some people, but many people have no side effects or only minor ones.

【2】Some of the common side effects of escitalopram will gradually improve as your body gets used to it.

【3】Common side effects
-------------------

【4】Common side effects of escitalopram happen in more than 1 in 100 people. There are things you can do to help cope with them:

【5】Feeling sick (nausea)

【6】Try taking escitalopram with or after food. It may also help if you avoid rich or spicy food.

【7】Headaches

【8】Make sure you rest and drink plenty of fluids. Do not drink too much alcohol. Ask your pharmacist to recommend a painkiller.

【9】Headaches should usually go away after the first week of taking escitalopram. Talk to your doctor if they last longer than a week or are severe.

【10】A dry mouth

【11】Chew sugar-free gum or suck sugar-free sweets.

【12】Sweating a lot

【13】Try wearing loose clothing and using a strong anti-perspirant. If this does not control the problem, talk to your doctor. You may need to try a different antidepressant.

【14】Being unable to sleep

【15】Take escitalopram first thing in the morning.

【16】Feeling sleepy

【17】Take escitalopram in the evening and cut down the amount of alcohol you drink. Do not drive, ride a bike or use tools or machinery if you're feeling sleepy. If this does not help, talk to your doctor.

【18】Feeling tired or weak

【19】Stop what you're doing and sit or lie down until you feel better. Do not drive, ride a bike or use tools or machinery if you're feeling tired. Do not drink alcohol as it will make you feel worse.

【20】Speak to a doctor or pharmacist if the advice on how to cope does not help and any of these side effects bother you or last more than a few days.

【21】Serious side effects
--------------------

【22】Book an appointment with your doctor if:

【23】*   you lose or gain weight without trying
*   you get changes in your periods, such as heavy bleeding, spotting or bleeding between periods

【24】Call your doctor or call 111 now if:

【25】*   you have constant headaches, long-lasting confusion or weakness, or frequent muscle cramps – these can all be signs of low sodium levels in your blood
*   you have a high temperature, feel agitated or confused, or you're trembling and twitching – this could be a sign of serotonin syndrome
*   you start coughing up blood or have blood in your pee
*   you have black or red poo or blood in your vomit – these can be signs of bleeding from the gut
*   you are bleeding from the gums, or have bruises that appear without a reason or get bigger

【26】### Immediate action required: Call 999 or go to A&E now if:

【27】*   you get painful erections that last longer than 2 hours – this may happen even when you're not having sex
*   you have severe dizziness or pass out
*   you get any bleeding that's severe or you cannot stop, such as cuts or nosebleeds that do not stop within 10 minutes
*   you have thoughts about harming yourself or ending your life

【28】Find your nearest A&E

【29】### Serious allergic reaction

【30】In rare cases, it's possible to have a serious allergic reaction (anaphylaxis) to escitalopram.

【31】#### Immediate action required: Call 999 now if:

【32】*   your lips, mouth, throat or tongue suddenly become swollen
*   you're breathing very fast or struggling to breathe (you may become very wheezy or feel like you're choking or gasping for air)
*   your throat feels tight or you're struggling to swallow
*   your skin, tongue or lips turn blue, grey or pale (if you have black or brown skin, this may be easier to see on the palms of your hands or soles of your feet)
*   you suddenly become very confused, drowsy or dizzy
*   someone faints and cannot be woken up
*   a child is limp, floppy or not responding like they normally do (their head may fall to the side, backwards or forwards, or they may find it difficult to lift their head or focus on your face)

【33】You or the person who's unwell may also have a rash that's swollen, raised, itchy, blistered or peeling.

【34】These can be signs of a serious allergic reaction and may need immediate treatment in hospital.

【35】Sexual side effects
-------------------

【36】The good effects of escitalopram may, after a while, improve your sex life as your mood lifts and you become interested in life and relationships again.

【37】Some of the possible sexual side effects include:

【38】*   painful erections and problems getting an erection and ejaculating
*   vaginal bleeding and not reaching orgasm the same way as before
*   a lower sex drive

【39】Sexual side effects usually pass after the first couple of weeks. However, very rarely, they can be long lasting and may not get better even after stopping the medicine.

【40】If these happen and are a problem for you, go back to your doctor to see if there's another treatment you can try.

【41】Other side effects
------------------

【42】These are not all the side effects of escitalopram. For a full list, see the leaflet inside your medicine packet.

【43】Information:

【44】You can report any suspected side effect using the Yellow Card safety scheme.

【45】Visit Yellow Card for further information.

【46】More in Escitalopram
--------------------

【47】*   About escitalopram
*   Who can and cannot take it
*   How and when to take it
*   Side effects
*   Pregnancy, breastfeeding and fertility
*   Taking escitalopram with other medicines and herbal supplements

title: Bronchiectasis
text:
【0】Complications \- Bronchiectasis
===============================

【1】Contents
--------

【2】1.  Overview
2.  Symptoms
3.  Causes
4.  Diagnosis
5.  Treatment
6.  Complications

【3】**In some cases, people with bronchiectasis can develop serious complications that require emergency treatment.**

【4】Coughing up large amounts of blood
----------------------------------

【5】A rare, but serious, complication of bronchiectasis is coughing up large amounts of blood (the medical term for this is massive haemoptysis).

【6】This can occur when a section of one of the blood vessels supplying the lungs suddenly splits open.

【7】Symptoms that may indicate massive haemoptysis include:

【8】*   coughing up more than 100ml of blood in a 24-hour period – 100ml is roughly equivalent to a third of a can of fizzy drink
*   breathing difficulties – caused by blood obstructing your airways
*   feeling lightheaded and dizzy, and having cold, clammy skin – caused by rapid blood loss

【9】Massive haemoptysis is a medical emergency. If you think someone is experiencing massive haemoptysis, call 999 for an ambulance.

【10】A person with massive haemoptysis needs to be admitted to hospital. A tube may need to be placed into their throat to assist them with their breathing.

【11】A procedure called a bronchial artery embolisation (BAE) will be required to stop the bleeding.

【12】During a BAE, a special dye is injected into your arteries so they show up clearly on X-rays.

【13】Then, using X-ray scans as a guide, the source of the bleeding is located and injected with tiny particles, around the size of a grain of sand, that will help clog the vessel up and stop the bleeding.

title: Blindness and vision loss
text:
【0】Blindness and vision loss
=========================

【1】**In the UK, more than 2 million people are living with sight loss. Of these, around 340,000 are registered as blind or partially sighted.**

【2】Being told you have a visual impairment that can't be treated can be difficult to come to terms with.

【3】Some people go through a process similar to bereavement, where they experience a range of emotions including shock, anger, and denial, before eventually coming to accept their condition.

【4】Specialist referral
-------------------

【5】If you're blind or partially sighted, you may be referred to a specialist low-vision clinic, which is often located within a hospital. Staff at the clinic can help you understand your condition and come to terms with your diagnosis.

【6】They can also advise you about practical things, such as lighting and vision aids, and let you know about further sources of help and support.

【7】Ask your local hospital if they have an Eye Clinic Liaison Officer (ECLO), whose role involves providing support to people with vision loss in eye clinics.

【8】Support groups
--------------

【9】If you're blind or partially sighted, you may find it helpful to contact a support group for people with vision loss.

【10】### Royal National Institute of Blind People (RNIB)

【11】The RNIB is the UK's leading charity for people with vision loss. The RNIB website offers useful information, such as coming to terms with sight loss.

【12】The RNIB's helpline is open Monday to Friday from 8am to 8pm and Saturday from 9am to 1pm. The number is 0303 123 9999, with calls costing no more than a standard rate call to an 01 or 02 number. You can also email helpline staff (helpline@rnib.org.uk).

【13】The RNIB's website is specially designed for people with sight loss and provides a wide range of useful information and resources, including an online community and RNIB online shop.

【14】### Other national charities

【15】Other national charities that specialise in vision loss and you may find useful include:

【16】*   The Macular Society – helpline: 0300 303 0111
*   Glaucoma UK – helpline: 01233 648170 or email helpline@glaucoma.uk
*   Retina UK – helpline: 0300 111 4000 or email: helpline@retinauk.org.uk
*   Diabetes UK – 0345 123 2399 or email: info@diabetes.org.uk
*   Blind Veterans UK – 0800 389 7979
*   Royal Society for Blind Children
*   SeeAbility
*   Thomas Pocklington Trust

【17】### Local organisations

【18】There are also many local voluntary organisations around the country that help and support people with vision problems. You can find local support organisations on the RNIB's Sightline Directory.

【19】Registering as blind or partially sighted
-----------------------------------------

【20】If your vision has deteriorated to a certain level, you may choose to register as visually impaired. Depending on the severity of your vision loss you'll either be registered as sight impaired (previously "partially sighted") or severely sight impaired (previously "blind").

【21】Your eye specialist (ophthalmologist) will measure your ability to see detail at a distance (visual acuity) and how much you can see from the side of your eye when looking straight ahead (your field of vision).

【22】These measurements will help your ophthalmologist determine whether you're eligible to be certified as sight impaired or severely sight impaired. If you are, they will complete an official certificate with the results of your eye examination.

【23】In England and Wales this certificate is called the Certificate of Vision Impairment (CVI), in Scotland it's called the CVI (Scotland) form, and in Northern Ireland it's called an A655.

【24】Your ophthalmologist will send a copy of the certificate to you, a copy to your GP and a copy to your local social services department. Upon receiving the certificate, your local social services team will contact you to ask whether you want to be added to its register of visually impaired people. If you say "yes" then you become registered.

【25】After you're registered, social services will contact you again to arrange for an assessment to be carried out. The aim is to assess your needs and find out what help you require to remain independent, such as help with cleaning and cooking, or help with mobility and transport.

【26】Registering as visually impaired isn't compulsory, but it can help you to get a range of benefits, including:

【27】*   benefits to help with any costs relating to your disability or illness
*   a reduction in the TV licence fee
*   help with NHS costs
*   help with Council Tax and tax allowances
*   reduced fees on public transport
*   parking concessions

【28】Find out more:

【29】*   RNIB: registering as sight impaired
*   GOV.UK: registering vision impairment as a disability

【30】Changes to your home
--------------------

【31】Most visually impaired people can continue to live at home. However, you'll probably need to make some changes to your home, particularly if you live on your own.

【32】Below is a list of some important pieces of equipment you may find useful.

【33】*   Big-button telephone – both landline and mobile phones are available from the RNIB online shop.
*   Computer, smartphone or tablet – the internet can provide a real sense of connection to friends and family as well as other people with a visual impairment. It's also a practical way of finding out information and obtaining goods and services. Big-button keyboards, screen display software and text readers are available from the RNIB.
*   Community alarm – this small, wearable device has an alarm button which, if pressed, sends an alarm signal to a response centre, which will alert a nominated friend or carer. Your local authority should be able to provide you with further information.
*   Bright lighting – bright light bulbs and adjustable lights are essential for your home, particularly in the kitchen and the stairs (areas where you're most likely to have an accident). Fluorescent bulbs are recommended because they produce the most light and tend to be cheaper in the long term than conventional bulbs. Lighting in and around the home: A guide to better lighting for people with visual impairment by the Thomas Pocklington Trust, contains more information on the importance of lighting.

【34】The way your house is painted can also make it easier to find your way around. Using a two-tone contrast approach, such as black and white, can make it easier to tell the difference between nearby objects, such as a door and its handle or the stairs and its handrail.

【35】Read more from the RNIB about adapting your home

【36】Reading and writing
-------------------

【37】There are several options available if you're having problems reading standard text in books, newspapers and magazines.

【38】One of the simplest options is to use a magnifying device that can make print appear bigger to help you read. These can be obtained from a number of places including hospital low-vision services, optometrists, local voluntary organisations, and the RNIB.

【39】The RNIB also has a collection of large-print publications you can borrow, as do most libraries.

【40】You could also use an e-reader to help you read. E-readers are handheld devices that allow you to download books and subscribe to newspapers and magazines on the internet. You can choose a setting that allows you to display text at a larger size. Or you can use text-to-speech software.

【41】The RNIB has more information on text-to-speech in eBooks

【42】If you're unable to read at all you could listen to audio recordings. You can sign up to the:

【43】*   RNIB's Newsagent scheme, which provides more than 200 magazine and newspaper titles in different formats, such as online or on CD.
*   RNIB Talking Books Service, where you can download audio books to listen to on your smartphone, tablet or computer or on a device known as a DAISY player. You can also get books on CD or USB stick, delivered to your door.

【44】You can also install screen-reading software on your computer that will read out emails, documents and text on the internet.

【45】The RNIB has more information about using screen-reading software

【46】There are also voice recognition programmes where you speak into a microphone and the software translates what you say into writing. These programmes can also be used to issue commands, such as closing down the internet and moving from one website to another.

【47】### Braille

【48】Some people with severe sight loss, particularly those who've had the problem from a young age, choose to learn Braille. Braille is a writing system where raised dots are used as a substitute for written letters.

【49】As well as Braille versions of books and magazines, you can buy Braille display units, which can be attached to computers that allow you to read the text displayed on a computer screen. Braille computer keyboards are also available.

【50】The RNIB website has more information about reading and Braille

【51】Getting around
--------------

【52】There are several different methods you can use to get around independently if you have a problem with your vision.

【53】### Long cane

【54】You may find a long cane useful when travelling. These canes are usually foldable and can help you get around by detecting objects in your path. The cane will also make drivers and other pedestrians aware that you have sight loss.

【55】To get the most from a long cane, it's a good idea to attend a training course that will teach you how to use it.

【56】The charity Guide Dogs has more information about getting around safely with a long cane

【57】### Guide dogs

【58】Guide Dogs has been providing guide dogs for people with vision loss for many years. Guide dogs can help you get around, and provide both a sense of independence and companionship.

【59】If you apply for a guide dog, Guide Dogs provide all the essential equipment free of charge and can also offer financial assistance if needed for things like food or vet costs.

【60】You don't need to have lost all your sight to benefit from a guide dog and you don't have to be officially registered as blind or partially sighted to apply for one.

【61】Guide Dogs has more on applying for a guide dog

【62】Guide Dogs also offer a number of other services for people with a visual impairment (even if you don't have a guide dog), such as Help for children and families and mobility training.

【63】The Guide Dogs' Sighted guiding service aims to reduce the isolation that many people with sight loss experience, helping to rebuild their confidence and regain their independence.

【64】### Global positioning system (GPS)

【65】A global positioning system (GPS) is a navigational aid that uses signals from satellites to tell you where you are and help plan your journeys.

【66】GPS devices are available as standalone units that can be programmed using a Braille keyboard, which tell you your current location and give you directions to where you want to go.

【67】If you have a smartphone, there are a number of GPS apps you can download.

【68】The RNIB website has more information about using GPS

【69】### Driving

【70】If you're diagnosed with a condition that affects your vision, you have a legal obligation to inform the Driver and Vehicle Licensing Agency (DVLA). Failure to do so is a crime and can result in a fine of up to £1,000.

【71】GOV.UK has more on driving with a disability or a health condition

【72】If you're registered as having a sight impairment, the DVLA will assume your driving licence is no longer valid and you'll no longer be able to drive.

【73】Exceptions are occasionally made for people with mild vision impairment. If you think this applies to you, then your doctor will need to fill in a DVLA medical information questionnaire.

【74】You're only legally allowed to drive if you can read a number plate from a distance of 20 metres (65 feet), and an eye test shows your visual acuity is at least 6/12. You're allowed to wear glasses or contact lenses when reading the plate or letter chart.

【75】There are also standards relating to your visual field and driving. If you have a condition that may reduce your visual field, the DVLA may ask you to complete a visual field test to demonstrate you're safe to drive.

【76】Technology
----------

【77】Technology to help you live well and safely with sight loss is developing all the time. You can read:

【78】*   the RNIB's information on technology and useful products
*   the Guide Dogs' information on technology for visual impairment

【79】Employment
----------

【80】If you're currently employed and have recently been diagnosed with a visual impairment, you should contact the GOV.UK: Access to Work scheme.

【81】Access to Work is a scheme run by Jobcentre Plus that provides advice and support about what equipment and adjustments may be required to enable you to do your job.

【82】They also offer a grant to contribute towards the costs of any equipment or training you may need, such as voice recognition software, a Braille keyboard and display unit and a printer that can convert text into Braille (Braille embossers).

【83】Depending on the size of the company you work for, the grant can pay for 80% to 100% of costs, up to £10,000.

【84】Find out more:

【85】*   RNIB: equality, rights and employment
*   GOV.UK: Jobcentre Plus
*   The Thomas Pocklington Trust: employment

【86】You don't have to disclose that you have a visual impairment when applying for a job, but it's usually recommended that you do.

【87】If you feel you've been turned down for a job because of your disability, and you were capable of doing the job, you can make a complaint under the Equality Act 2010.

【88】Some people with a visual impairment decide to become self-employed, often because it allows them the flexibility to work at home for hours they choose.

【89】The RNIB website has more information and advice about equality, rights and employment

【90】### Regular sight tests

【91】If you have vision loss, it's still important to have regular sight tests so your optometrist (eye specialist) can check for further changes in your eyes and give you advice about how to make the best use of your vision.

【92】Find an optician or more about NHS eyes services.

title: Crohn's disease
text:
【0】Treatment \- Crohn's disease
============================

【1】Contents
--------

【2】1.  Overview
2.  Symptoms
3.  Diagnosis
4.  Treatment
5.  Living with

【3】**There's currently no cure for Crohn's disease, but treatment can control or reduce the symptoms and help stop them coming back.**

【4】Medicines are the main treatments, but sometimes surgery may be needed.

【5】Steroids
--------

【6】Most people with Crohn's disease need to take steroids (such as prednisolone) from time to time.

【7】Steroid medicines:

【8】*   can relieve symptoms by reducing inflammation in your digestive system – they usually start to work in a few days or weeks
*   are usually taken as tablets once a day – sometimes they're given as injections
*   may be needed for a couple of months – do not stop taking them without getting medical advice
*   can cause side effects like weight gain, indigestion, problems sleeping, an increased risk of infections and slower growth in children

【9】The charity Crohn's & Colitis UK has more information about steroids

【10】Liquid diet
-----------

【11】For children and young adults, a liquid diet (enteral nutrition) can also help reduce symptoms.

【12】This involves having special drinks that contain all the nutrients you need, instead of your usual diet, for a few weeks.

【13】It avoids the risk of slower growth that can happen with steroids.

【14】Enteral nutrition has few side effects, but some people may feel sick or have diarrhoea or constipation while on the diet.

【15】Crohn's & Colitis UK has information about food and Crohn's disease

【16】Immunosuppressants
------------------

【17】Sometimes you might also need to take medicines called immunosuppressants to reduce the activity of your immune system.

【18】Common types include azathioprine, mercaptopurine and methotrexate.

【19】Immunosuppressants:

【20】*   can relieve symptoms if steroids on their own are not working
*   can be used as a long-term treatment to help stop symptoms coming back
*   are usually taken as a tablet once a day, but sometimes they're given as injections
*   may be needed for several months or years
*   can cause side effects like feeling and being sick, increased risk of infections and liver problems

【21】Crohn's & Colitis UK has more about azathioprine and mercaptopurine

【22】Biological medicines
--------------------

【23】If other medicines are not helping, stronger medicines called biological medicines may be needed.

【24】The biological medicines for Crohn's disease are adalimumab, infliximab, vedolizumab and ustekinumab.

【25】Biological medicines:

【26】*   can relieve symptoms if other medicines are not working
*   can be used as a long-term treatment to help stop symptoms coming back
*   are given by injection or a drip into a vein every 2 to 8 weeks
*   may be needed for several months or years
*   can cause side effects like increased risk of infections and a reaction to the medicine leading to itching, joint pain and a high temperature

【27】Crohn's & Colitis UK: adalimumab and Crohn's & Colitis UK: infliximab

【28】If biological medicines have not helped, your doctor might recommend you try the medicine upadacitinib. You take it as a tablet.

【29】Find out more about upadacitinib from Crohn’s and Colitis UK

【30】Surgery
-------

【31】Your care team may recommend surgery if they think the benefits outweigh the risks or that medicines are unlikely to work.

【32】Surgery can relieve your symptoms and help stop them coming back for a while, although they'll usually return eventually.

【33】The main operation used is called a resection. This involves:

【34】1.  Making small cuts in your tummy (keyhole surgery).
2.  Removing a small inflamed section of bowel.
3.  Stitching the healthy parts of bowel together.

【35】It's usually done under general anaesthetic (while you're asleep).

【36】You may be in hospital for about a week and it might take a few months to fully recover.

【37】Sometimes you may need an ileostomy (where poo comes out into a bag attached to your tummy) for a few months to let your bowel recover before it's stitched back together.

【38】You may need to take medicine after surgery to help prevent symptoms returning.

【39】Crohn's & Colitis UK has more information about surgery for Crohn's disease

title: Acupuncture
text:
【0】Acupuncture
===========

【1】**Acupuncture is a treatment derived from ancient Chinese medicine. Fine needles are inserted at certain sites in the body for therapeutic or preventative purposes.**

【2】It is used in many NHS GP practices, as well as in most pain clinics and hospices in the UK.

【3】Acupuncture is often seen as a form of complementary or alternative medicine (CAM).

【4】How acupuncture works
---------------------

【5】Western medical acupuncture (dry needling) is the use of acupuncture following a medical diagnosis. It involves stimulating sensory nerves under the skin and in the muscles.

【6】This results in the body producing natural substances, such as pain-relieving endorphins. It's likely that these naturally released substances are responsible for the beneficial effects experienced with acupuncture.

【7】A course of acupuncture is usually recommended because it can take a few sessions for you to see improvements.

【8】Traditional acupuncture is based on the belief that an energy, or "life force", flows through the body in channels called meridians. This life force is known as Qi (pronounced "chee").

【9】Practitioners who use acupuncture in the traditional way believe that when Qi does not flow freely through the body, this can cause illness. They also believe acupuncture can restore the flow of Qi, and so restore health.

【10】Uses of acupuncture
-------------------

【11】Acupuncture practitioners – sometimes called acupuncturists – use acupuncture to treat a wide range of health conditions. However, the use of acupuncture is not always based on rigorous scientific evidence.

【12】The National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) provides guidelines for the NHS on the use of treatments and care of patients.

【13】Currently, NICE only recommends considering acupuncture as a treatment option for:

【14】*   chronic (long-term) pain
*   chronic tension-type headaches
*   migraines
*   prostatitis symptoms
*   hiccups

【15】Acupuncture is also often used to treat other conditions and symptoms, including:

【16】*   joint and muscle pain
*   jaw pain
*   cancer symptoms such as pain
*   side effects of cancer treatment such as feeling or being sick from chemotherapy
*   feeling sick or being sick after surgery

【17】However, the evidence on the effectiveness of acupuncture compared with other treatments is unclear.

【18】Acupuncture on the NHS
----------------------

【19】Acupuncture is sometimes available on the NHS, most often from GP surgeries or physiotherapists, although access is limited.

【20】Most acupuncture patients pay for private treatment. The cost of acupuncture varies widely between practitioners.

【21】If you're being treated by an acupuncture practitioner for a health condition or are considering having acupuncture, it's advisable to discuss this with your GP.

【22】How acupuncture is performed
----------------------------

【23】An initial acupuncture session usually lasts 20 minutes to 1 hour and involves an assessment of your general health, medical history and a physical examination, followed by insertion of the acupuncture needles.

【24】Courses of treatment often involve several separate sessions, but this can vary.

【25】### Insertion of the needles

【26】Credit:

【27】Picture Partners / Alamy Stock Photo https://www.alamy.com/acupuncturist-performing-acupuncture-on-a-clients-back-image8055273.html?pv=1&stamp=2&imageid=5854BCDD-3312-49E1-937D-808EC258854F&p=11630&n=0&orientation=0&pn=1&searchtype=0&IsFromSearch=1&srch=foo%3dbar%26st%3d0%26pn%3d1%26ps%3d100%26sortby%3d2%26resultview%3dsortbyPopular%26npgs%3d0%26qt%3dAG51JA%26qt\_raw%3dAG51JA%26lic%3d3%26mr%3d0%26pr%3d0%26ot%3d0%26creative%3d%26ag%3d0%26hc%3d0%26pc%3d%26blackwhite%3d%26cutout%3d%26tbar%3d1%26et%3d0x000000000000000000000%26vp%3d0%26loc%3d0%26imgt%3d0%26dtfr%3d%26dtto%3d%26size%3d0xFF%26archive%3d1%26groupid%3d%26pseudoid%3d195878%26a%3d%26cdid%3d%26cdsrt%3d%26name%3d%26qn%3d%26apalib%3d%26apalic%3d%26lightbox%3d%26gname%3d%26gtype%3d%26xstx%3d0%26simid%3d%26saveQry%3d%26editorial%3d1%26nu%3d%26t%3d%26edoptin%3d%26customgeoip%3d%26cap%3d1%26cbstore%3d1%26vd%3d0%26lb%3d%26fi%3d2%26edrf%3d0%26ispremium%3d1%26flip%3d0%26pl%3d

【28】The needles are inserted into specific places on the body, which practitioners call acupuncture points.

【29】During the session, you'll usually be asked to sit or lie down. You may also be asked to remove some clothes so the practitioner can access certain parts of your body.

【30】The needles used are very fine and are usually a few centimetres long. They should be single-use, pre-sterilised needles that are disposed of immediately after use.

【31】Acupuncture practitioners choose specific points to place the needles based on your condition. Several points may be used during a typical session, depending on the number of symptoms you have.

【32】The needles may be inserted just under the skin, or deeper so they reach muscle. Once the needles are in place, they may be left in position for a length of time lasting from a few minutes up to around 30 minutes.

【33】You may feel a tingling or a dull ache when the needles are inserted but you should not experience any significant pain. If you do, let your practitioner know straight away.

【34】Acupuncture safety and regulation
---------------------------------

【35】There's no statutory regulation of acupuncture in England.

【36】If you choose to have acupuncture, it is recommended that you check the acupuncture practitioner is either a regulated healthcare professional such as a doctor, nurse or physiotherapist or a member of a national acupuncture organisation.

【37】You can find an accredited acupuncturist on the Professional Standards Authority for Health and Social Care website.

【38】When it's done by a qualified practitioner, acupuncture is generally very safe.

【39】Some people experience mild, short-term side effects such as:

【40】*   pain where the needles puncture the skin
*   bleeding or bruising where the needles puncture the skin
*   drowsiness
*   feeling sick
*   feeling dizzy or faint

【41】Serious side effects such as a punctured lung or infection are very rare.

【42】If you have a bleeding disorder, such as haemophilia, or are taking any medicines such as anticoagulant medicine, talk to your GP or acupuncture practitioner before you have acupuncture. 

【43】Acupuncture is also not usually advised if you have a metal allergy or an infection in the area where needles may be inserted.

【44】It's generally safe to have acupuncture when you're pregnant. However, let your acupuncture practitioner know if you're pregnant because certain acupuncture points cannot be used safely during pregnancy.

【45】Read more about the safety of complementary therapies in pregnancy.

title: Ketoconazole
text:
【0】Ketoconazole \- Brand names: Daktarin, Dandrazol, Nizoral
=========================================================

【1】On this page
------------

【2】1.  About ketoconazole
2.  Key facts
3.  Who can and cannot use ketoconazole
4.  How and when to use ketoconazole
5.  Side effects of ketoconazole
6.  How to cope with side effects of ketoconazole
7.  Pregnancy and breastfeeding
8.  Cautions with other medicines
9.  Common questions about ketoconazole

【3】1\. About ketoconazole
----------------------

【4】Ketoconazole is an antifungal medicine. It's used to treat skin infections caused by a fungus (yeast). It can also prevent them coming back.

【5】It treats different types of fungal infections including:

【6】*   athlete's foot
*   jock itch, an infection in the groin area
*   sweat rash (intertrigo), a rash that usually appears in folds of skin
*   dandruff and seborrhoeic dermatitis, where your scalp or other areas of your skin become scaly and dry or greasy
*   pityriasis versicolor, sometimes called tinea versicolour, where small patches of skin become scaly and change colour

【7】Ketoconazole is available as a cream or shampoo.

【8】You can buy most ketoconazole creams and shampoos in pharmacies and supermarkets, or get them on prescription. For treating pityriasis versicolor, you will need a prescription.

【9】Ketoconazole also comes as tablets but these usually only treat a rare condition called Cushing's syndrome. The tablets are available on prescription only, and they are not covered here.

【10】2\. Key facts
-------------

【11】*   Ketoconazole usually works within 2 to 3 weeks for most fungal infections, but it can take 6 weeks for athlete's foot to get better.
*   It works by killing the yeasts (fungi) that cause the infections.
*   The most common side effects of the cream and shampoo are irritated or red skin.
*   For most infections, you'll usually use the cream once or twice a day and the shampoo once or twice a week.
*   Some people use ketoconazole shampoo every 1 to 2 weeks to help stop dandruff coming back.

【12】3\. Who can and cannot use ketoconazole
---------------------------------------

【13】Ketoconazole creams and shampoos can be used by most adults and children aged 12 years and over.

【14】Ketoconazole is not suitable for everyone. To make sure it's safe for you, talk to your doctor or pharmacist before using it if you have ever had an allergic reaction to ketoconazole or any other medicine.

【15】4\. How and when to use ketoconazole
------------------------------------

【16】Always follow the instructions that come with your medicine, or your doctor's advice.

【17】How long you use ketoconazole for and how often depends on the type of skin problem you have.

【18】### How often to use cream for athlete's foot, jock itch and sweat rash

【19】Use the cream once or twice a day on the infected skin and surrounding area. For athlete's foot, you need to use it twice a day regularly.

【20】Carry on using the cream for 3 days after your symptoms have cleared up, to stop the infection coming back.

【21】### How often to use shampoo or cream for seborrhoeic dermatitis

【22】Use the shampoo twice a week for 2 to 4 weeks until your symptoms have cleared. Then use it once every 1 to 2 weeks, to stop them coming back.

【23】Alternatively, you can use the cream once or twice a day, for 2 to 4 weeks, and then use the shampoo once every 1 to 2 weeks to stop your symptoms coming back.

【24】### How often to use shampoo for dandruff

【25】Use the shampoo twice a week for 2 to 4 weeks, then once every 1 to 2 weeks to stop your dandruff coming back.

【26】### How often to use cream or shampoo for pityriasis versicolor

【27】Use the shampoo once a day, for up to 5 days.

【28】For treating small areas of skin, you can use the cream instead. Put the cream on once or twice a day for 2 to 3 weeks.

【29】If your symptoms tend to return in sunlight, use the shampoo once a day for up to 3 days before going out in the sun.

【30】### How to use ketoconazole cream

【31】1.  Wash and dry the infected area of skin. If you're treating your feet, make sure you dry between your toes.
2.  Use your own towel or flannel. This stops you passing the infection on to anyone else.
3.  Gently rub the cream into the infected area and surrounding skin. You'll usually need a small amount, depending on the size of the area you're treating. Be careful not to let the cream get into your eyes or mouth. If it does get into your eyes or mouth, rinse them with water.
4.  Wash your hands afterwards. This stops you spreading the infection to other parts of your body or other people.

【32】If you're using any other creams, ointments or lotions on the same area of skin, do not put them on at the same time as ketoconazole cream. After putting on the ketoconazole cream, wait 30 minutes before you use different products on the same area. This gives the ketoconazole time to be absorbed into your skin.

【33】### How to use ketoconazole shampoo

【34】1.  Rinse your hair or the infected area of skin with water.
2.  Shake the shampoo bottle, then squeeze a small amount onto the infected area.
3.  If you're treating your scalp, massage the shampoo into your scalp until it makes a lather.
4.  Leave the shampoo on for 3 to 5 minutes, then wash it off with water. Try not to get the shampoo into your eyes or mouth. If it gets into your eyes or mouth, rinse them with water.
5.  Wash your hands afterwards. This stops you spreading the infection to other parts of your body or other people.

【35】### What if I forget to use it?

【36】If you forget to use your ketoconazole cream or shampoo, just skip the missed dose and then keep to your usual routine.

【37】### What if I use too much?

【38】If you use too much ketoconazole shampoo or cream, or use it more often than you need to, it may make your skin irritated or red. If this happens, use less the next time.

【39】5\. Side effects of ketoconazole
--------------------------------

【40】Like all medicines, ketoconazole cream and shampoo can cause side effects, but not everyone gets them.

【41】Most side effects are minor. You can try using a smaller amount of the cream or shampoo to see if that helps.

【42】### Common side effects

【43】You're unlikely to have common side effects when using the right amount of ketoconazole shampoo.

【44】With ketoconazole cream, common side effects happen in more than 1 in 100 people. They usually affect your skin where you've applied the cream.

【45】Talk to a pharmacist or doctor if these side effects bother you or do not go away, or if they spread beyond the area of skin you've treated:

【46】*   itching or redness
*   a burning feeling on your skin

【47】### Serious allergic reaction

【48】Serious allergic reactions (anaphylaxis) are rare but can happen with ketoconazole cream or shampoo.

【49】##### Immediate action required: Call 999 now if:

【50】*   your lips, mouth, throat or tongue suddenly become swollen
*   you're breathing very fast or struggling to breathe (you may become very wheezy or feel like you're choking or gasping for air)
*   your throat feels tight or you're struggling to swallow
*   your skin, tongue or lips turn blue, grey or pale (if you have black or brown skin, this may be easier to see on the palms of your hands or soles of your feet)
*   you suddenly become very confused, drowsy or dizzy
*   someone faints and cannot be woken up
*   a child is limp, floppy or not responding like they normally do (their head may fall to the side, backwards or forwards, or they may find it difficult to lift their head or focus on your face)

【51】You or the person who's unwell may also have a rash that's swollen, raised, itchy, blistered or peeling.

【52】These can be signs of a serious allergic reaction and may need immediate treatment in hospital.

【53】These are not all the side effects of ketoconazole. For a full list, see the leaflet inside your medicine packet.

【54】Information:

【55】You can report any suspected side effect using the Yellow Card safety scheme.

【56】Visit Yellow Card for further information.

【57】6\. How to cope with side effects of ketoconazole
-------------------------------------------------

【58】**What to do about:**

【59】*   **itching, redness, or a burning feeling on your skin** – try using less cream. Apply it carefully, just to the area you need to treat. Rub it in gently. Try wearing loose clothing to reduce sweat. If the itching, redness or burning feeling is no better after a few days, or it gets worse at any time, stop using the cream and speak to a pharmacist or doctor.

【60】7\. Pregnancy and breastfeeding
-------------------------------

【61】### Ketoconazole and pregnancy

【62】You can use ketoconazole cream or shampoo if you're pregnant. Only tiny amounts are absorbed into your body so it will not affect your baby.

【63】### Ketoconazole and breastfeeding

【64】If you want to breastfeed and are using ketoconazole on your chest, wash any cream off your breasts and nipples and then wash your hands before feeding your baby.

【65】### Non-urgent advice: Tell your doctor if you're:

【66】*   trying to get pregnant
*   pregnant
*   breastfeeding

【67】8\. Cautions with other medicines
---------------------------------

【68】Only tiny amounts of ketoconazole are absorbed into your body when you use it as a cream or shampoo. You can usually use ketoconazole skin treatments while taking most medicines.

【69】### Using ketoconazole with other skin treatments

【70】If you're using a mild steroid cream (such as hydrocortisone) to help with swelling or inflammation caused by the skin infection, put the steroid cream on in the morning and the ketoconazole cream in the evening.

【71】If you're using ketoconazole twice a day, make sure you wait at least 30 minutes after putting it on before using the steroid cream.

【72】### Mixing ketoconazole with herbal remedies and supplements

【73】There's very little information about taking herbal remedies and supplements while using ketoconazole. They are not tested in the same way as other medicines.

【74】### Important: Medicine safety

【75】Tell your doctor or pharmacist if you're taking any other medicines, including herbal medicines, vitamins or supplements.

【76】9\. Common questions about ketoconazole
---------------------------------------

【77】How does ketoconazole work?

【78】Ketoconazole is an antifungal medicine. It works on the fungus (yeast) that is causing the infection.

【79】Ketoconazole causes holes to appear in the fungus's cell membrane and the contents to leak out. This kills the fungus and treats the infection.

【80】How long does ketoconazole take to work?

【81】Ketoconazole cream and shampoo usually take 2 to 4 weeks to work for dandruff, scaly and dry or greasy skin (seborrhoeic dermatitis), jock itch and sweat rash.

【82】Athlete's foot and some other skin infections can take up to 6 weeks to get better.

【83】Pityriasis versicolor (a fungal infection that causes skin to become scaly and discoloured) gets better within 5 days of treatment with ketoconazole shampoo, or after 2 to 3 weeks of treatment with the cream. However, it can take several weeks or months for your skin colour to return to normal.

【84】Talk to your pharmacist or doctor if your symptoms are no better after 4 weeks.

【85】After your skin infection has cleared up, continue to use the cream for a few days, to stop your symptoms coming back.

【86】What if ketoconazole does not work?

【87】Talk to your pharmacist or doctor if:

【88】*   your symptoms have not improved after 4 weeks
*   your symptoms have not improved after 2 weeks after you used ketoconazole shampoo for pityriasis versicolor.

【89】You may need to use a different treatment.

【90】If your symptoms get worse at any time, speak to your doctor.

【91】What do I do if the infection comes back after treatment?

【92】#### Dandruff and seborrhoeic dermatitis

【93】Dandruff and other types of seborrhoeic dermatitis can come back. You can usually use ketoconazole again if it worked well before.

【94】When the infection is under control again, you can continue to use ketoconazole shampoo less often, so the skin infection does not come back.

【95】Some people use ketoconazole shampoo every 1 to 2 weeks for months, or even for years, to stop dandruff or seborrhoeic dermatitis returning.

【96】#### Athlete’s foot, jock itch, sweat rash

【97】Athlete's foot, jock itch and sweat rash can come back.

【98】You can usually use ketoconazole cream again if it worked well before and as long as the infection is mild and has not spread.

【99】#### Pityriasis versicolor

【100】Pityriasis versicolor (a fungal infection that causes skin to become scaly and discoloured) can come back. Warm, damp conditions or being in the sun sometimes bring it back.

【101】You can usually use ketoconazole again in the same way as before.

【102】If your symptoms tend to return in sunlight, use the shampoo once a day for up to 3 days before going out in the sun.

【103】You can then use ketoconazole shampoo 1 to 4 times a month to stop symptoms coming back.

【104】Are there other treatments for fungal infections?

【105】There are many different antifungal medicines. Some are available to buy from a pharmacy, and others are available on prescription.

【106】They can come as creams, gels, sprays, tablets, capsules and liquid.

【107】Your doctor or a pharmacist will be able to recommend the best treatment for you, based on your condition.

【108】Antifungal medicines include:

【109】*   clotrimazole
*   econazole
*   fenticonazole
*   fluconazole
*   itraconazole
*   miconazole
*   terbinafine

【110】Can I drink alcohol?

【111】Yes, you can drink alcohol while using ketoconazole cream or shampoo.

【112】Is there any food or drink I need to avoid?

【113】No, you can eat and drink normally while using ketoconazole cream or shampoo.

【114】Will it affect my fertility?

【115】When ketoconazole is used as a cream or shampoo, only tiny amounts are absorbed into the body. There's no evidence that it affects the fertility of men or women.

【116】Will ketoconazole affect my contraception?

【117】When it's used as a cream or shampoo, ketoconazole does not affect any type of contraceptive, including the combined pill or emergency contraception.

【118】Can I drive or ride a bike?

【119】Yes, you can drive or ride a bike while using ketoconazole cream or shampoo.

【120】What else can I do to help fungal infections?

【121】If you have a fungal skin infection, these tips may help:

【122】*   always wash your hands after treating the infection to stop it from spreading
*   do not scratch the area with the infection, as this can make the infection worse
*   keep the affected areas of your skin clean and dry
*   do not share towels, bedsheets or combs with other people as you could spread the infection to them
*   wash towels and bedding regularly

【123】Related conditions
------------------

【124】*   Athlete's foot
*   Dandruff
*   Fungal nail infection
*   Pityriasis versicolor

【125】Useful resources
----------------

【126】*   HealthUnlocked: ketoconazole forum
*   British Association of Dermatologists: patient information leaflets

title: Japanese encephalitis
text:
【0】Japanese encephalitis
=====================

【1】**Japanese encephalitis is a rare but serious infection you can get from mosquito bites in some parts of the world. If you're travelling to an area where there's a risk of catching it, you can get a vaccine to help prevent it.**

【2】Check if you're at risk of Japanese encephalitis
------------------------------------------------

【3】Japanese encephalitis is not found in the UK. It's mostly found in rural areas of Asia, but it's rare for travellers to get it.

【4】It's caused by a virus which is spread through mosquito bites.

【5】Places where Japanese encephalitis is found include parts of:

【6】*   India
*   China
*   Japan
*   South Korea
*   Indonesia
*   Southeast Asia (such as Thailand, Malaysia and Vietnam)

【7】Information:

【8】### Check your travel risk

【9】You can get health advice for a country you're travelling to on the TravelHealthPro website.

【10】How to lower your risk of Japanese encephalitis
-----------------------------------------------

【11】There are some things you can do to avoid mosquito bites when travelling to areas with a risk of Japanese encephalitis.

【12】### Do

【13】*   use insect repellent on exposed skin, ideally containing at least 50% DEET
    
*   sleep under a mosquito net treated with insecticide
    
*   when possible, wear long-sleeved tops, trousers or long skirts, socks and shoes to protect your skin from mosquito bites
    
*   get advice from a travel vaccination clinic before you travel
    

【14】### Japanese encephalitis vaccine

【15】A vaccine for Japanese encephalitis is recommended if you're travelling to a part of the world where the virus is found, especially if:

【16】*   you're staying for more than a month
*   you're staying in a rural area
*   you're staying near or visiting rice fields, wetlands, or places where pigs are kept

【17】You'll have to pay for the Japanese encephalitis vaccine. You can get it from travel health clinics and pharmacies with travel health services.

【18】Symptoms of Japanese encephalitis
---------------------------------

【19】Most people who get Japanese encephalitis have no symptoms.

【20】Some people get flu-like symptoms such as:

【21】*   a headache
*   a high temperature
*   feeling or being sick
*   tummy pain

【22】The symptoms usually go away on their own, but in some people the infection spreads to the brain and causes more serious symptoms such as:

【23】*   a severe headache
*   feeling confused
*   not being able to feel or move parts of your body (paralysis)
*   seizures (fits)

【24】Urgent advice: Ask for an urgent GP appointment or get help from NHS 111 if:
----------------------------------------------------------------------------

【25】You've recently travelled to an area where Japanese encephalitis is found and you have flu-like symptoms such as:

【26】*   a headache
*   a high temperature
*   feeling or being sick
*   tummy pain

【27】Tell anyone you speak to about your recent travel, and if you were bitten by a mosquito or might have been.

【28】You can call 111 or get help from 111 online.

【29】Immediate action required: Call 999 if you or someone else has:
---------------------------------------------------------------

【30】*   a severe headache and a stiff neck
*   sudden confusion (for example, not being sure of your name, age, or where you are)
*   sudden weakness or suddenly not being able to feel or move part of your body (paralysis)
*   a seizure (fit)
*   loss of consciousness
*   severe difficulty breathing

【31】### Important

【32】Get medical advice quickly if you have Japanese encephalitis symptoms while you're travelling.

【33】Treatment for Japanese encephalitis
-----------------------------------

【34】You'll need to be treated in hospital if you're seriously unwell because Japanese encephalitis can be life-threatening.

【35】Treatments for Japanese encephalitis include medicines to help relieve the symptoms, such as painkillers and steroids.

【36】Japanese encephalitis can sometimes cause long-term complications such as paralysis, seizures, and loss of speech.

title: Advice for parents of healthy-weight children
text:
【0】Advice for parents of healthy-weight children
=============================================

【1】**If your child is a healthy weight, there's lots you can do as a parent to help them stay a healthy size as they grow.**

【2】Research shows children who stay a healthy weight tend to be fitter, healthier, better able to learn, and more self-confident.

【3】They're also much less likely to have health problems now and in later life.

【4】Children whose parents encourage them to be active and eat healthily are more likely to stay a healthy weight and grow up healthy.

【5】Check their BMI every now and then using our BMI calculator for children and teenagers to see how they are growing over time.

【6】Be a good role model
--------------------

【7】One way to instil good habits in your child is for you to be a good role model. Children learn by example. You can encourage your child to be active and eat healthily by doing so yourself.

【8】Set a good example by going for a walk or bike ride instead of watching TV or surfing the internet.

【9】Playing in the park or swimming with your children shows them being active is fun. It's also a great opportunity for you all to spend time together.

【10】Any changes you make to your child's diet and lifestyle are much more likely to be accepted if the changes are small and involve the whole family.

【11】Find easy ways to eat well and move more as a family on the Better Health website

【12】If you're not sure what activities you'd like to try as a family, head to the exercise section on the NHS website.

【13】Get active
----------

【14】School-aged children need about 60 minutes of physical activity a day for good health.

【15】Activity does not need to be all at once, it can be spread throughout the day. It could include riding a bike, skateboarding, walking to school, skipping, swimming, dancing and martial arts.

【16】Children under 5 years old need more than 3 hours' activity a day. It can take the form of active play, such as ball games, chasing games like "it" and "tag", riding a bike or scooter, using playground swings, climbing frames and see-saws.

【17】Activities should make children breathe faster and feel warmer.

【18】Walking or cycling short distances instead of using the car or bus is a great way to be active together as a family. And you'll save money, too.

【19】Find out about physical activity guidelines for children under 5 years

【20】Find out about physical activity guidelines for children and young people aged 5 to 18

【21】Child-size portions
-------------------

【22】There's very little official guidance on precisely how much food children require, so you'll need to use your own judgement on child-size portions.

【23】A good rule of thumb is to start meals with small servings and let your child ask for more if they're still hungry.

【24】Avoid making your child finish everything on the plate or eat more than they want to.

【25】Use smaller plates for younger children, as adult-size plates could encourage them to eat oversized portions.

【26】It may also help if you encourage your child to eat slowly and have set mealtimes. You can use mealtimes as an opportunity to catch up on what's happened during the day.

【27】Explain to your child how to get the balance of their diet right using the Eatwell Guide. It shows how much we should all eat from each food group.

【28】Read more about how to eat a balanced diet.

【29】Get ideas for healthier lunchbox recipes and healthier food swaps on the Better Health website.

【30】Eat a healthy balanced diet
---------------------------

【31】Children, just like adults, should aim to eat 5 or more portions of a variety of fruit and vegetables every day. They're a great source of fibre and vitamins and minerals.

【32】Getting 5 A Day should not be too difficult. Almost all fruit and vegetables count towards your child's 5 A Day, including fresh, tinned, frozen and dried.

【33】Juices, smoothies, beans and pulses also count.

【34】Be aware that unsweetened 100% fruit juice, vegetable juice and smoothies only count as a maximum of 1 portion of their 5 A Day. For example, if they have 2 glasses of fruit juice and a smoothie in 1 day, that still only counts as 1 portion.

【35】Their combined total of drinks from fruit juice, vegetable juice and smoothies should not be more than 150ml a day, which is a small glass.

【36】If they have 150ml of orange juice and a 150ml smoothie in 1 day, for example, they'll have exceeded the recommendation by 150ml.

【37】When fruit is blended or juiced, it releases the sugars. This increases the risk of tooth decay, so it's best to drink fruit juice or smoothies at mealtimes.

【38】Discourage your child from having sugary or high-fat foods like sweets, cakes, biscuits, crisps, chocolate, some sugary cereals, and sugar-sweetened soft and fizzy drinks. These foods and drinks tend to be high in calories.

【39】Aim for your child to get most of their calories from foods like fruit and vegetables, and starchy foods like bread, potatoes, pasta and rice (preferably wholegrain versions).

【40】They should also have some beans, pulses, fish, eggs, meat and other protein foods, and some dairy or dairy alternatives.

【41】And swap sugary soft drinks, juice and flavoured milks for water, lower-fat milks and diet, sugar-free or no added sugar drinks.

【42】Find out more about healthier food swaps on the Better Health website

【43】Less screen time and more sleep
-------------------------------

【44】Help your children avoid sitting and lying around too much, as it makes it more likely for them to put on weight.

【45】Limit the amount of time your child spends on inactive pastimes such as watching television, playing video games and playing on electronic devices.

【46】There's no hard and fast advice on how much is too much, but experts say children should have no more than 2 hours of screen time each day.

【47】And remove all screens (including mobile phones) from their bedroom at night.

【48】It also helps children stay trim if they sleep well. It's been shown children who don't have the recommended amount of sleep are more likely to be overweight.

【49】The less children sleep, the greater the risk of them becoming overweight. Lack of sleep can also affect their mood and behaviour.

title: Polymyalgia rheumatica
text: 【0】Overview \- Polymyalgia rheumatica ================================== 【1】Contents -------- 【2】1. Overview 2. Symptoms 3. Diagnosis 4. Treatment 【3】**Polymyalgia rheumatica (PMR) is a condition that causes pain, stiffness and inflammation in the muscles around the shoulders, neck and hips.** 【4】Symptoms of polymyalgia rheumatica ---------------------------------- 【5】The main symptom is muscle stiffness in the morning that lasts longer than 45 minutes. 【6】Other symptoms may include: 【7】* extreme tiredness * loss of appetite * weight loss * depression 【8】See a GP if you have pain and stiffness for more than a week. They'll try to find out what's causing it. 【9】Diagnosing polymyalgia rheumatica can be difficult because the symptoms are similar to those of many other conditions, including rheumatoid arthritis. 【10】These conditions will need to be ruled out before polymyalgia rheumatica is diagnosed. 【11】Causes of polymyalgia rheumatica -------------------------------- 【12】The cause of polymyalgia rheumatica is unknown, but a combination of genetic and environmental factors is thought to be responsible. 【13】Polymyalgia rheumatica is an age-related condition. Most people diagnosed with it are over 65, and it's very rare in people younger than 50. It's also more common in women than men. 【14】Treating polymyalgia rheumatica ------------------------------- 【15】A steroid medicine called prednisolone is the main treatment for polymyalgia rheumatica. It's used to help relieve the symptoms. 【16】To start with, you may be prescribed a moderate dose of prednisolone, which will be gradually reduced over time. 【17】Most people with polymyalgia rheumatica will need a course of steroid treatment that lasts for 12 months to 2 years to prevent their symptoms returning. 【18】Temporal arteritis ------------------ 【19】Up to 1 in 5 people with polymyalgia rheumatica develop a more serious condition called temporal arteritis (also known as giant cell arteritis), where the arteries in the head and neck become inflamed. 【20】Symptoms of temporal arteritis can include: 【21】* a new or frequent headache that usually develops suddenly (your scalp may also feel sore or tender) * pain in the jaw muscles or tongue when eating or talking * problems with sight, such as double vision or loss of vision in 1 or both eyes 【22】If you have any of these symptoms, contact a GP immediately, go to 111.nhs.uk or call NHS 111. 【23】Unlike polymyalgia rheumatica, temporal arteritis requires immediate medical attention. It can lead to serious problems like stroke or blindness if not treated quickly. 【24】Community content from HealthUnlocked 【25】Page last reviewed: 23 April 2023 Next review due: 23 April 2026 【26】* Next : Symptoms

title: Aspirin for pain relief
text:
【0】About aspirin for pain relief \- Brand names: Anadin, Bonjela gel
=================================================================

【1】Aspirin is an everyday painkiller for aches and pains such as headache, toothache and period pain. It can also be used to treat colds and flu-like symptoms, and to bring down a high temperature.

【2】Aspirin is known as an acetylsalicylic acid. It also belongs to a group of medicines called non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs).

【3】Aspirin combined with other ingredients is also available in some cold and flu remedies.

【4】You can buy most types of aspirin from pharmacies, shops and supermarkets. Some types are only available on prescription.

【5】Aspirin comes as tablets or suppositories – medicine that you push gently into your anus (bottom). It also comes as a gel for mouth ulcers and cold sores.

【6】If you've had a stroke or heart attack, or are at high risk of a heart attack, your doctor may recommend that you take a daily low-dose aspirin. Some women may also be prescribed low-dose aspirin while they’re pregnant.

【7】This is different to taking aspirin for pain relief. Only take low-dose aspirin if your doctor recommends it. Read our information on low-dose aspirin.

【8】Key facts
---------

【9】*   It's best to take aspirin with food. That way, you'll be less likely to get an upset stomach or stomach ache.
*   Never give aspirin to children under the age of 16 (unless their doctor prescribes it). It can make children more likely to develop a very rare but serious condition called Reye's syndrome.
*   You should start to feel better 20 to 30 minutes after taking aspirin.
*   Aspirin is an ingredient in combined medicines such as Anadin Original, Anadin Extra, Alka-Seltzer Original, Alka-Seltzer XS and Beechams Powders.
*   Aspirin as a mouth gel has the brand name Bonjela. Like other aspirin products, it's only for people aged 16 and over. Bonjela Teething Gel and Bonjela Junior Gel do not contain aspirin, so you can give them to children under 16.

title: Supported living services
text:
【0】Supported living services
=========================

【1】Supported living services can help if you do not want to live in residential care but you're finding it difficult to cope at home.

【2】They're a combination of suitable accommodation – which can be your own home – with some forms of personal care (like help with washing or cooking).

【3】Some supported living homes are shared by 2 or 3 people with a similar health problem, such as a substance misuse problem or a particular disability.

【4】Staff usually visit the home to help you get out of bed, go out to college or work, and do simple tasks such as shopping, housework and repairs.

【5】They can also help with administrative tasks and personal care.

【6】Why choose supported living services?
-------------------------------------

【7】Supported living services are flexible and sometimes better value for money than the alternatives, whether you fund your own care or receive a personal budget.

【8】Services that offer care in the home must be delivered by a registered homecare agency or provider. They are regulated by the Care Quality Commission.

【9】Finding out more about supported living services
------------------------------------------------

【10】You may hear about supported living services during a needs assessment.

【11】Supported living services can be provided by the local council or charities, or they may be run by commercial companies.

【12】Social services will let you know about local supported living services if it seems like they might meet your needs.

【13】If a supported living service arrangement is not suitable for you, you may still want to think about personal care at home, wherever you live, and other help, such as household equipment to make your life easier or home adaptations.

【4】Good sources of vitamin E
-------------------------

【5】Vitamin E is a group of compounds found in a wide variety of foods.

【7】*   plant oils – such as rapeseed (vegetable oil), sunflower, soya, corn and olive oil
*   nuts and seeds

【8】How much vitamin E do I need?
-----------------------------

【9】The amount of vitamin E you need is:

【10】*   4mg a day for men
*   3mg a day for women

【11】You should be able to get all the vitamin E you need from your diet.

【12】Any vitamin E your body does not need immediately is stored for future use, so you do not need it in your diet every day.

【13】What happens if I take too much vitamin E?
------------------------------------------

【14】There is not enough evidence to know what the effects might be of taking high doses of vitamin E supplements each day.

【15】What does the Department of Health and Social Care advise?
----------------------------------------------------------

【16】You should be able to get the amount of vitamin E you need by eating a varied and balanced diet.

【17】If you take vitamin E supplements, do not take too much as this could be harmful.

title: Antidepressants
text: 【0】Overview - Antidepressants ========================== 【1】**Antidepressants are a type of medicine used to treat** **clinical depression****.** 【2】They can also be used to treat a number of other conditions, including: 【3】* obsessive compulsive disorder (OCD) * generalised anxiety disorder * post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) 【4】Antidepressants are also sometimes used to treat people with long-term (chronic) pain. 【5】Read more about when antidepressants are used. 【6】How antidepressants work ------------------------ 【7】It's not known exactly how antidepressants work. 【8】It's thought they work by increasing levels of chemicals in the brain called neurotransmitters. Certain neurotransmitters, such as serotonin and noradrenaline, are linked to mood and emotion. 【9】Neurotransmitters may also affect pain signals sent by nerves, which may explain why some antidepressants can help relieve long-term pain. 【10】While antidepressants can treat the symptoms of depression, they do not always address its causes. This is why they're usually used in combination with therapy to treat more severe depression or other mental health conditions. 【11】How effective are antidepressants? ---------------------------------- 【12】Research suggests that antidepressants can be helpful for people with moderate or severe depression. 【13】They're not usually recommended for mild depression, unless other treatments like talking therapy have not helped. 【14】Doses and duration of treatment ------------------------------- 【15】Antidepressants are usually taken in tablet form. When they're prescribed, you'll start on the lowest possible dose thought necessary to improve your symptoms. 【16】Antidepressants usually need to be taken for 1 or 2 weeks (without missing a dose) before the benefit starts to be felt. It's important not to stop taking them if you get some mild side effects early on, as these effects usually wear off quickly. 【17】If you take an antidepressant for 4 weeks without feeling any benefit, speak to your GP or mental health specialist. They may recommend increasing your dose or trying a different medicine. 【18】A course of treatment usually lasts for at least 6 months after you start to feel better. Some people with recurrent depression may be advised to take them indefinitely. 【19】Read more about antidepressant dosages. 【20】Side effects ------------ 【21】Different antidepressants can have a range of different side effects. Always check the information leaflet that comes with your medicine to see what the possible side effects are. 【22】The most common side effects of antidepressants are usually mild. Side effects should improve within a few days or weeks of treatment, as the body gets used to the medicine. 【23】Read more about: 【24】* possible side effects of antidepressants * cautions and interactions of antidepressants 【25】Coming off antidepressants -------------------------- 【26】Talk to your doctor before you stop taking antidepressants. It's important that you do not stop taking antidepressants suddenly. 【27】Once you're ready to come off antidepressants, your doctor will probably recommend reducing your dose gradually over several weeks – or longer, if you have been taking them for a long time. 【28】This is to help prevent any withdrawal symptoms you might get as a reaction to coming off the medicine. 【29】Read more about stopping or coming off antidepressants. 【30】Types of antidepressants ------------------------ 【31】There are several different types of antidepressants. 【32】### Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) 【33】SSRIs are the most widely prescribed type of antidepressants. They're usually preferred over other antidepressants, as they cause fewer side effects. An overdose is also less likely to be serious. 【34】Fluoxetine is probably the best known SSRI (sold under the brand name Prozac). Other SSRIs include citalopram (Cipramil), escitalopram (Cipralex), paroxetine (Seroxat) and sertraline (Lustral). 【35】### Serotonin-noradrenaline reuptake inhibitors (SNRIs) 【36】SNRIs are similar to SSRIs. They were designed to be a more effective antidepressant than SSRIs. However, the evidence that SNRIs are more effective in treating depression is uncertain. It seems that some people respond better to SSRIs, while others respond better to SNRIs. 【37】Examples of SNRIs include duloxetine (Cymbalta and Yentreve) and venlafaxine (Efexor). 【38】### Noradrenaline and specific serotonergic antidepressants (NASSAs) 【39】NASSAs may be effective for some people who are unable to take SSRIs. The side effects of NASSAs are similar to those of SSRIs, but they're thought to cause fewer sexual problems. However, they may also cause more drowsiness at first. 【40】The main NASSA prescribed in the UK is mirtazapine (Zispin). 【41】### Tricyclic antidepressants (TCAs) 【42】TCAs are an older type of antidepressant. They're no longer usually recommended as the first treatment for depression because they can be more dangerous if an overdose is taken. They also cause more unpleasant side effects than SSRIs and SNRIs. 【43】Exceptions are sometimes made for people with severe depression that fail to respond to other treatments. TCAs may also be recommended for other mental health conditions, such as OCD and bipolar disorder. 【44】Examples of TCAs include amitriptyline, clomipramine, dosulepin, imipramine, lofepramine and nortriptyline. 【45】Some types of TCAs, such as amitriptyline, can also be used to treat chronic nerve pain. 【46】### Serotonin antagonists and reuptake inhibitors (SARIs) 【47】SARIs are not usually the first choice of antidepressant, but they may be prescribed if other antidepressants have not worked or have caused side effects. 【48】The main SARI prescribed in the UK is trazodone (Molipaxin). 【49】### Monoamine oxidase inhibitors (MAOIs) 【50】MAOIs are an older type of antidepressant that are rarely used nowadays. 【51】They can cause potentially serious side effects so should only be prescribed by a specialist doctor. 【52】Examples of MAOIs include tranylcypromine, phenelzine and isocarboxazid. 【53】Other treatments for depression ------------------------------- 【54】Other treatments for depression include talking therapies such as cognitive behavioural therapy (CBT). 【55】People with moderate to severe depression are usually treated using a combination of antidepressants and CBT. Antidepressants work quickly in reducing symptoms, whereas CBT takes time to deal with causes of depression and ways of overcoming it. 【56】Regular exercise has also been shown to be useful for those with mild depression. 【57】Read more about alternatives to antidepressants. 【58】Yellow Card Scheme ------------------ 【59】The Yellow Card Scheme allows you to report suspected side effects from any type of medicine you're taking. It's run by a medicines safety watchdog called the Medicines and Healthcare products Regulatory Agency (MHRA). 【60】See the Yellow Card Scheme website for more information. 【61】Community content from HealthUnlocked 【62】More in Antidepressants ----------------------- 【63】* Overview - Antidepressants * Uses - Antidepressants * Cautions - Antidepressants * Dosage - Antidepressants * Side effects - Antidepressants * Alternatives - Antidepressants 【64】Page last reviewed: 4 November 2021 Next review due: 4 November 2024

title: Pleurisy
text:
【0】Pleurisy
========

【1】**Pleurisy is inflammation around the lungs, which causes sharp chest pain. It's easy to treat and usually gets better in a few days, but can sometimes be a sign of something more serious, like pneumonia.**

【2】Check if it's pleurisy
----------------------

【3】The main symptom of pleurisy is sharp chest pain when you breathe in.

【4】The pain may be worse when you cough, sneeze or move around.

【5】It may also spread to your shoulders and back.

【6】Urgent advice: Ask for an urgent GP appointment or get help from NHS 111 if:
----------------------------------------------------------------------------

【7】*   you have sharp chest pain that comes and goes, or only happens when breathing or coughing
*   you have sharp chest pain that has not got better after a few days
*   you've coughed up a few small spots, flecks or streaks of blood, or noticed blood in your phlegm or on a handkerchief
*   you're feeling short of breath regularly

【8】You can call 111 or get help from 111 online.

【9】Immediate action required: Call 999 or go to A&E if:
----------------------------------------------------

【10】*   you have sudden chest pain that lasts for 15 minutes or more
*   you have sudden chest pain that spreads to your arms, back, neck or jaw
*   you have difficulty breathing
*   you're coughing up more than just a few spots or streaks of blood
*   you're coughing up blood and finding it hard to breathe, have a very fast heartbeat, or have pain in your chest or upper back

【11】These symptoms could be a sign of a more serious problem, such as a heart attack or a blood clot in the lungs (pulmonary embolism).

【12】Find your nearest A&E

【13】What happens at your appointment
--------------------------------

【14】If you have symptoms of pleurisy, a GP will examine you and listen to your chest.

【15】The GP may refer you to a specialist if they're not sure what's causing your symptoms.

【16】You may need to have tests, such as:

【17】*   blood tests
*   a chest X-ray
*   an ultrasound scan
*   a CT scan

【18】Treatment for pleurisy
----------------------

【19】Pleurisy will usually get better on its own in a few days without treatment from a GP.

【20】If your symptoms are being caused by a bacterial infection, such as pneumonia, you may need antibiotics.

【21】You can ease the chest pain by:

【22】*   taking painkillers such as paracetamol or ibuprofen
*   resting in different positions until you find a comfortable one – lying on the painful side can help

【23】You may need to have treatment in hospital if your symptoms are severe or being caused by something more serious, such as a pulmonary embolism or tuberculosis.

【24】Page last reviewed: 18 May 2023  
Next review due: 18 May 2026

title: Omeprazole
text:
【0】Taking omeprazole with other medicines and herbal supplements \- Brand names: Losec, Losec MUPS, Pyrocalm
=========================================================================================================

【1】### **Cautions with other medicines**

【2】Some medicines and omeprazole can affect each other and make it more likely that you'll have side effects or stop one of the medicines working properly.

【3】Tell your doctor if you're taking these medicines before you start omeprazole treatment:

【4】*   heart medicines, such as digoxin
*   cilostazol, a medicine that treats peripheral arterial disease (PAD)
*   antifungal medicines, such as itraconazole, ketoconazole, posaconazole and voriconazole
*   methotrexate, a medicine that treats psoriasis and rheumatoid arthritis
*   HIV medicines
*   phenytoin, an epilepsy medicine
*   rifampicin, an antibiotic
*   clopidogrel and warfarin, medicines to prevent or treat blood clots

【5】These are not all the medicines that may not mix well with omeprazole. For a full list, see the leaflet inside your medicine packet.

【6】Taking omeprazole with painkillers
----------------------------------

【7】It is safe to take painkillers such as paracetamol or ibuprofen at the same time as omeprazole.

【8】It's best to take ibuprofen with, or just after, a meal so it does not upset your stomach.

【9】Mixing omeprazole with herbal remedies or supplements
-----------------------------------------------------

【10】Do not take St John's wort, the herbal remedy for depression, while you're taking omeprazole. It may stop omeprazole working as well as it should.

【11】There's not enough information to say that other complementary medicines and herbal remedies are safe to take with omeprazole. They're not tested in the same way as pharmacy and prescription medicines. They're generally not tested for the effect they have on other medicines.

【12】Important: Medicine safety
--------------------------

【13】Tell your doctor or pharmacist if you're taking any other medicines, including herbal remedies, vitamins or supplements.

title: Flucloxacillin
text:
【0】Flucloxacillin
==============

【1】On this page
------------

【2】1.  About flucloxacillin
2.  Key facts
3.  Who can and cannot take flucloxacillin
4.  How and when to take flucloxacillin
5.  Side effects
6.  How to cope with side effects of flucloxacillin
7.  Pregnancy and breastfeeding
