9.  Common questions about flucloxacillin

【3】1\. About flucloxacillin
------------------------

【4】Flucloxacillin is an antibiotic.

【5】It's used to treat:

【6】*   skin and wound infections
*   bone infections (osteomyelitis)
*   ear infections in children

【7】Flucloxacillin is only available on prescription.

【8】It comes as capsules or as a liquid that you swallow. It can also be given by injection, but this is usually done in hospital.

【9】2\. Key facts
-------------

【10】*   Take flucloxacillin on an empty stomach. This means at least 30 to 60 minutes before a meal or snack, and at least 2 hours after.
*   For most infections, you should start to feel better within a few days.
*   The most common side effects are feeling sick (nausea) and diarrhoea.
*   You can drink alcohol while taking flucloxacillin.
*   You can take flucloxacillin during pregnancy or while you're breastfeeding.

【11】3\. Who can and cannot take flucloxacillin
------------------------------------------

【12】Flucloxacillin can be taken by adults, including throughout pregnancy and while breastfeeding. Flucloxacillin can also be taken by children.

【13】To make sure flucloxacillin is safe for you, tell your doctor if you:

【14】*   have ever had an allergic reaction to penicillin, flucloxacillin or any other medicine
*   have liver or kidney problems
*   have recently had, or are due to have, any vaccinations

【15】4\. How and when to take flucloxacillin
---------------------------------------

【16】### Dosage

【17】The usual dose of flucloxacillin is 250mg to 500mg, taken 4 times a day. For children, the dose may be lower.

【18】Try to space your doses evenly throughout the day. For example, first thing in the morning (before breakfast), at around midday (before lunch), late in the afternoon (before tea) and at bedtime.

【19】### Important

【20】Carry on taking this medicine until you've finished all your tablets, capsules or liquid, even if you feel better. If you stop your treatment early, your symptoms could come back.

【21】### How to take it

【22】Swallow flucloxacillin capsules whole with a drink of water. Do not chew or break them.

【23】It's best to take flucloxacillin on an empty stomach. That means taking it at least 30 to 60 minutes before a meal or snack, and at least 2 hours after.

【24】Liquid flucloxacillin is available for children, and people who find it difficult to swallow capsules.

【25】If you or your child are taking liquid flucloxacillin, it will usually be made up for you by your pharmacist. The medicine will come with a syringe or spoon to help you take the right amount. If you do not have a syringe or spoon, ask your pharmacist for one. Do not use a kitchen teaspoon because it will not measure the right amount.

【26】### If you forget to take it

【27】If you forget to take a dose, take it as soon as you remember, unless it's nearly time for your next dose. If this happens, just leave out the missed dose and take your next dose at the usual time.

【28】Never take 2 doses at the same time. Never take an extra dose to make up for a forgotten one.

【29】If you forget doses often, it may help to set an alarm to remind you. You could also ask your pharmacist for advice on other ways to help you remember to take your medicine.

【30】### If you take too much

【31】Try to take the right number of doses each day, leaving at least 3 hours between doses.

【32】Taking an extra dose of flucloxacillin is unlikely to harm you or your child.

【33】Talk to your pharmacist or doctor if you're worried or if you take more than 1 extra dose.

【34】5\. Side effects
----------------

【35】Like all medicines, flucloxacillin can cause side effects in some people, although not everyone will get them.

【36】### Common side effects

【37】Common side effects of flucloxacillin happen in more than 1 in 100 people. Keep taking the medicine, but tell your doctor or pharmacist if these side effects bother you or do not go away:

【38】*   feeling sick (nausea) or being sick (vomiting)
*   diarrhoea
*   bloating and indigestion

【39】### Serious side effects

【40】Serious side effects are rare and happen in less than 1 in 1,000 people.

【41】Call a doctor or call 111 straight away if:

【42】*   you get diarrhoea (possibly with muscle cramps) that contains blood or mucus, or severe diarrhoea that lasts more than 4 days
*   you have pale poo with dark pee, and the whites of your eyes or skin turn yellow (this may be less obvious on black or brown skin) – this can be a sign of liver problems
*   you get bruising or discoloured skin
*   you have joint or muscle pain that starts happening after 2 days of taking the medicine

【43】Some of these serious side effects may not happen for up to 2 months after finishing the course of flucloxacillin.

【44】#### Serious allergic reaction

【45】In rare cases, it's possible to have a serious allergic reaction (anaphylaxis) to flucloxacillin.

【46】##### Immediate action required: Call 999 now if:

【47】*   your lips, mouth, throat or tongue suddenly become swollen
*   you're breathing very fast or struggling to breathe (you may become very wheezy or feel like you're choking or gasping for air)
*   your throat feels tight or you're struggling to swallow
*   your skin, tongue or lips turn blue, grey or pale (if you have black or brown skin, this may be easier to see on the palms of your hands or soles of your feet)
*   you suddenly become very confused, drowsy or dizzy
*   someone faints and cannot be woken up
*   a child is limp, floppy or not responding like they normally do (their head may fall to the side, backwards or forwards, or they may find it difficult to lift their head or focus on your face)

【48】You or the person who's unwell may also have a rash that's swollen, raised, itchy, blistered or peeling.

【49】These can be signs of a serious allergic reaction and may need immediate treatment in hospital.

【50】These are not all the side effects of flucloxacillin. For a full list see the leaflet inside your medicine packet.

【51】Information:

【52】You can report any suspected side effect using the Yellow Card safety scheme.

【53】Visit Yellow Card for further information.

【54】6\. How to cope with side effects of flucloxacillin
---------------------------------------------------

【55】**What to do about:**

【56】*   **feeling sick or being sick** – stick to simple meals and try not to eat rich or spicy food. If you are being sick, take small, frequent sips of fluids such as water or squash to stop getting dehydrated. Signs of dehydration include peeing less than usual or having dark, strong-smelling pee. If you take contraceptive pills and you're being sick, your contraception may not protect you from pregnancy. Check the pill packet to find out what to do.
*   **diarrhoea** – drink lots of fluids such as water or squash to stop getting dehydrated. Signs of dehydration include peeing less than usual or having dark, strong-smelling pee. Do not take any other medicines without speaking to a pharmacist or doctor. If you take contraceptive pills and you have severe diarrhoea, your contraception may not protect you from pregnancy. Check the pill packet to find out what to do.
*   **bloating and indigestion** – try not to eat foods that cause farting (flatulence), like lentils, peas, beans and onions. You could also try eating smaller meals, eating and drinking more slowly, and exercising regularly.

【57】7\. Pregnancy and breastfeeding
-------------------------------

【58】### Flucloxacillin and pregnancy

【59】It's safe to take flucloxacillin during pregnancy.

【60】### Flucloxacillin and breastfeeding

【61】It is OK to take flucloxacillin while breastfeeding.

【62】Information shows that only tiny amounts of flucloxacillin get into breast milk, which would not be expected to cause any side effects in your baby.

【63】Talk to your doctor, pharmacist, health visitor or midwife if:

【64】*   your baby is not feeding as well as usual
*   they have sickness or diarrhoea
*   your baby has oral thrush or a skin rash
*   you have any other concerns about your baby

【65】8\. Cautions with other medicines
---------------------------------

【66】Some medicines can affect the way that flucloxacillin works and increase the chance of you having side effects.

【67】Tell your doctor if you're taking any of these medicines before you start flucloxacillin:

【68】*   methotrexate, an anti-inflammatory medicine for arthritis and similar conditions
*   warfarin, a medicine to prevent blood clots
*   other antibiotics

【69】Tell your doctor if you've recently had, or are due to have, an oral typhoid vaccination. Flucloxacillin can make it less effective.

【70】### Mixing flucloxacillin with herbal remedies and supplements

【71】There is little information about taking herbal remedies and supplements with flucloxacillin.

【72】### Important: Medicine safety

【73】Tell your doctor or pharmacist if you're taking any other medicines, including herbal medicines, vitamins or supplements.

【74】9\. Common questions about flucloxacillin
-----------------------------------------

【75】How does flucloxacillin work?

【76】Flucloxacillin is one of a group of antibiotics called penicillins. It works by killing harmful bacteria.

【77】When will I feel better?

【78】For most infections, you should feel better within a few days. But even if you feel better, it's very important to carry on taking flucloxacillin until you've finished the course. This helps to stop the infection coming back.

【79】What if I do not get better?

【80】Tell your doctor if you do not start feeling better after taking flucloxacillin for 3 days. Also tell them if, at any time, you start to feel worse.

【81】Will it give me thrush?

【82】Some people get a fungal infection called thrush after taking a course of antibiotics like flucloxacillin. If you think you have thrush, speak to your pharmacist or doctor for advice.

【83】Will it affect my contraception?

【84】Flucloxacillin does not stop any type of contraception working, including the combined pill or emergency contraception.

【85】However, if flucloxacillin makes you sick (vomit) or have severe diarrhoea for more than 24 hours, your contraceptive pills may not protect you from pregnancy. Check the pill packet to find out what to do.

【86】Find out about what to do if you're on the pill and you're being sick or have diarrhoea.

【87】Will it reduce my fertility?

【88】There's no clear evidence to suggest that taking flucloxacillin will reduce fertility in either men or women.

【89】Can I drive or ride a bike?

【90】Yes. Flucloxacillin should not affect being able to drive or cycle.

【91】Can I drink alcohol with it?

【92】Yes, you can drink alcohol while taking flucloxacillin.

【93】Is there any food or drink I need to avoid?

【94】You do not need to avoid any foods or drinks while taking flucloxacillin. However, make sure to take it on an empty stomach.

text:
【0】Taking allopurinol with other medicines and herbal supplements \- Brand names: Zyloric, Uricto
==============================================================================================

【1】Cautions with other medicines
-----------------------------

【2】Some medicines and allopurinol can affect each other and increase the chances of you having side effects.

【3】Tell a doctor or pharmacist if you're taking any of these medicines before you start taking allopurinol:

【4】*   aspirin or medicines used to help prevent blood clots (anticoagulants), such as warfarin
*   any antibiotics
*   medicines used to reduce your immune response (for arthritis or after you've had an organ transplant)
*   tablets that make you pee more (diuretics) such as furosemide or ACE inhibitors to treat high blood pressure (hypertension) such as enalapril or ramipril

【5】If you take aluminium hydroxide (found in some antacids such as Maalox and Mucogel), leave a 3-hour gap between the aluminium hydroxide and your allopurinol dose.

【6】Taking allopurinol with painkillers
-----------------------------------

【7】You can take allopurinol with paracetamol and anti-inflammatory medicines such as ibuprofen, naproxen, or indomethacin.

【8】Your doctor may prescribe an NSAID (such as diclofenac or naproxen) or a medicine called colchicine to help prevent or to deal with attacks of gout – especially in the early stages of allopurinol treatment.

【9】Mixing allopurinol with herbal remedies and supplements
-------------------------------------------------------

【10】There's not enough information to say whether complementary medicines, herbal remedies and supplements are safe to take with allopurinol. They are not tested in the same way as pharmacy and prescription medicines. They're generally not tested for the effect they have on other medicines.

-----------------------------

【2】Metronidazole may not mix well with some other medicines. This is not usually a problem when metronidazole is applied to the skin as a gel or cream, but it can be a problem with metronidazole tablets, suppositories, liquid or vaginal gel.

text:
【0】Side effects of finasteride \- Brand names: Proscar, Propecia
=============================================================

【1】Like all medicines, finasteride can cause side effects in some people, although not everyone gets them.

【2】Common side effects
-------------------

【3】These common side effects of finasteride happen in more than 1 in 100 people.

【4】They usually improve after a while. There are things you can do to help cope with them:

【5】Problems getting an erection and less interest in having sex

【6】These side effects should improve with time. If they do not get better, speak to your doctor.

【7】Problems with ejaculating, such as little or no semen

【8】If the amount you ejaculate is less than usual or you have no semen at all, you do not need to worry as this side effect is harmless. Talk to a doctor if it does not get any better.

【9】Speak to a doctor or pharmacist if the advice on how to cope does not help and a side effect is still bothering you or does not go away.

【10】Serious side effects
--------------------

【11】Serious side effects are rare and happen in less than 1 in 1,000 people. Some people may notice these side effects after taking finasteride for a few months.

【12】Call your doctor or call 111 now if you get:

【13】*   any lumps, pain or swelling in your chest area or discharge from your nipples – these may be signs of a serious condition such as breast cancer
*   unusually low mood (depression)

【14】### Immediate action required: Call 999 or go to A&E now if:

【15】*   you have thoughts of harming yourself

【16】Find your nearest A&E

【18】In rare cases, finasteride may cause a serious allergic reaction (anaphylaxis).

【20】*   your lips, mouth, throat or tongue suddenly become swollen

*   your throat feels tight or you're struggling to swallow

【21】You or the person who's unwell may also have a rash that's swollen, raised, itchy, blistered or peeling.

【22】These can be signs of a serious allergic reaction and may need immediate treatment in hospital.

------------------

【0】Who can and cannot take trazodone
=================================

【1】Who can take trazodone
----------------------

【2】Most adults aged 18 years and over can take trazodone.

【3】If you have diabetes, trazodone can make it more difficult to keep your blood sugar stable. Your doctor may advise that you monitor your blood sugar more often for the first few weeks of treatment with trazodone, and adjust your diabetes treatment if necessary.

【5】Who may not be able to take trazodone
-------------------------------------

【6】Trazodone is not suitable for some people. To make sure it's safe for you, check with your doctor before starting to take it if you:

【7】*   have ever had an allergic reaction to trazodone or any other medicine
*   have ever had thoughts of self-harming or ending your life
*   have recently had a heart attack or have heart, kidney or liver problems

*   are pregnant, trying to get pregnant or breastfeeding
*   have porphyria, a rare disorder

title: Eyelid problems
text:
【0】Eyelid problems
===============

【1】**Find out what to do if you have a lump on your eyelid, or an eyelid that's swollen, sticky, itchy or painful.**

【2】Most eyelid problems are harmless
---------------------------------

【3】Many eyelid problems are not serious.

【4】It's fairly common to have any of these problems:

【5】*   a lump that goes away by itself after several days or weeks
*   mildly itchy, flaky or sticky eyelids that clear up by themselves
*   swelling from a nearby insect bite, injury or operation that goes away after a week or so
*   twitching or blinking from time to time – often when you're tired
*   eyelids that droop (or get more "hooded") as you get older

【6】Types of eyelid problems
------------------------

【7】Your symptoms might give you an idea of what's causing your eyelid problem. But do not self-diagnose – see a pharmacist, GP or optician.

【8】Common eyelid problems and possible causes

| Eyelid problem | Possible cause |
| --- | --- |
| Eyelid problemLump or swelling on eyelid  | Possible causeStye or meibomian cyst (chalazion)  |
| Eyelid problemItchy, flaky, sticky or swollen eyelid  | Possible causeAllergy, blepharitis, or conjunctivitis  |
| Eyelid problemYellow lump or patch on eyelid  | Possible causeXanthelasma (yellow patches sometimes caused by high cholesterol)  |
| Eyelid problemEyelid turning outwards or inwards  | Possible causeEctropion  |
| Eyelid problemHot, painful and swollen eyelid  | Possible causeCellulitis  |

【10】Information:

【11】There is separate information about twitching eyelids.

【12】A pharmacist can help with eyelid problems
------------------------------------------

【13】You can ask a pharmacist about:

【14】*   what you can do to treat common eyelid problems, like a stye or conjunctivitis, yourself
*   if you can buy anything to help – for example, cleaning solutions for sticky eyelids
*   if you need to see an optician or GP

【15】Find a pharmacy

【16】Non-urgent advice: See a GP if:
-------------------------------

【17】*   you're worried about an eyelid problem
*   your eyelid symptoms are not improving or they're lasting a long time
*   you have yellow lumps or patches around your eyes

【18】Urgent advice: Ask for an urgent GP or optician appointment or get help from NHS 111 if:
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

【19】*   your swollen eyelid is red, hot, painful, tender or blistered
*   your eyelid droops suddenly
*   you cannot open your eye or keep it open
*   the pain is in your eye (not your eyelid)
*   the white of your eye is very red, in part or all over
*   you have eye symptoms and a headache or you feel sick or are being sick
*   a newborn baby (less than 1 month old) has a sticky, red eye
*   you're sensitive to light (photophobia)
*   your eyesight changes – for example, you have blurred vision and see wavy flashing lights, zigzag patterns or coloured spots or lines
*   you have a very high temperature, or feel hot and shivery, or you feel generally unwell
*   you think it's an allergic reaction

【20】You can call 111 or get help from 111 online.

title: Rabeprazole
text:
【0】About rabeprazole
=================

【1】Rabeprazole reduces the amount of acid your stomach makes. It's widely used to treat heartburn, acid reflux and gastro-oesophageal reflux disease (GORD). GORD is when you keep getting acid reflux.

【2】Rabeprazole is also taken to prevent and treat stomach ulcers.

【3】Sometimes, it is also prescribed for a rare condition caused by a tumour in the pancreas or gut, called Zollinger-Ellison syndrome.

【4】Rabeprazole is only available on prescription. It comes as tablets.

【5】Key facts
---------

【6】*   You’ll usually take rabeprazole once a day in the morning.
*   If you are prescribed a higher dose, you can take it twice a day, in the morning and in the evening. It starts to work within 2 to 3 days, but it may take up to 4 weeks for rabeprazole to work fully.
*   Common side effects include headaches, diarrhoea, feeling or being sick, constipation, stomach pain. These tend to be mild and go away when you stop taking the medicine.
*   Rabeprazole is not usually recommended during pregnancy but you may be able to take while breastfeeding if your doctor says it’s OK. Ask your doctor for advice
*   You can drink alcohol with rabeprazole but it may make your symptoms worse.

title: Antidepressants
text:
【0】Alternatives - Antidepressants
==============================

【1】**Several treatments can be used instead of antidepressants for treating depression and other mental health conditions.**

【2】Talking therapies
-----------------

【3】### Cognitive behavioural therapy

【4】Cognitive behavioural therapy (CBT) is a type of talking therapy that's increasingly being used in the treatment of depression. Most experts recommend that people with moderate to severe depression are treated with a combination of CBT and antidepressants.

【5】However, if you're unable or unwilling to take antidepressants, you have the option of receiving CBT on its own.

【6】CBT helps you understand your thoughts and behaviour, and how they affect you. It helps you recognise that events in your past may have affected you, but it concentrates mostly on how you can change the way you think, feel and behave in the present. It also teaches you how to overcome negative thoughts.

【7】CBT is usually available on the NHS, although the waiting lists are usually long. You normally have a short course of sessions, usually 6 to 8 sessions, over 10 to 12 weeks, on a 1-to-1 basis with a therapist trained in CBT. In some cases, you may be offered group CBT.

【8】### Online CBT

【9】Computerised or online CBT is a form of CBT that works through a computer screen, rather than face-to-face with a therapist.

【10】These therapies can be prescribed by your GP or a mental health specialist and are carried out with their advice and support.

【11】Ask your GP for more information or read more about self-help therapies.

【12】### Interpersonal therapy (IPT)

【13】Interpersonal therapy (IPT) focuses on your relationships with other people and on problems you may be having in your relationships, such as difficulties with communication or coping with bereavement.

【14】A course of IPT is usually structured in the same way as a course of CBT.

【15】There's some evidence that IPT can be as effective as antidepressants or CBT, but more research is needed.

【16】### Counselling

【17】Counselling is a form of therapy that helps you think about the problems you're experiencing in your life to find new ways of dealing with them. Counsellors support you in finding solutions to problems but do not tell you what to do.

【18】Counselling on the NHS usually consists of 6 to 12 sessions lasting an hour each. You talk in confidence to a counsellor, who supports you and offers practical advice.

【19】Counselling is ideal for people who are generally healthy but need help coping with a current crisis, such as anger, relationship issues, bereavement, redundancy, infertility or the onset of a serious illness.

【20】### Talking therapies on the NHS

【21】You can get talking therapies like counselling for depression and cognitive behavioural therapy (CBT) on the NHS.

【22】You can refer yourself directly to an NHS talking therapies service without a referral from a GP.

【23】Read more about NHS talking therapies

【24】Exercise
--------

【25】Research suggests that regular exercise may be a more effective treatment for mild depression than antidepressants.

【26】Exercise helps boost levels of chemicals called serotonin and dopamine in the brain, which can lift your mood.

【27】Exercising on a regular basis can boost self-esteem and confidence, which can help to relieve symptoms of depression.

【28】Read about starting exercise and exercise for depression.

【29】Self-help groups
----------------

【30】Talking through your feelings can be helpful. You can either talk to a friend or relative, or you can ask your GP to suggest a local self-help group. There are also chat rooms on the internet that offer support.

【31】Read more about depression support groups.

【32】Lithium
-------

【33】If you've tried several different antidepressants and seen no improvement, your doctor may offer you a medicine called lithium, in addition to your current treatment.

【34】If the level of lithium in your blood becomes too high, it can become toxic. So, you'll need blood tests every few months to check your lithium levels while you're taking it.

【35】You'll also need to avoid eating a low-salt diet because this can also cause the lithium to become toxic. Ask your GP for advice about your diet.

【36】Side effects of lithium include:

【37】*   dry mouth
*   a metallic taste in your mouth
*   some mild shaking of your hands
*   diarrhoea

【38】These side effects usually pass with time once your body gets used to the medicine.

【39】Electric shock treatment
------------------------

【40】Sometimes a treatment called electroconvulsive therapy (ECT) may be recommended if you have severe depression and other treatments have not worked, as it can be highly effective.

【41】During ECT, you'll first be given an anaesthetic and medicine to relax your muscles. Then you'll receive an electric current to your brain through electrodes placed on your head.

【42】You may be given a series of ECT sessions. It's usually given twice a week for 3 to 6 weeks.

【43】It's not exactly clear how ECT works, but recent studies suggest it may help reduce connections in an area of the brain linked to depression.

【44】For most people, ECT is good for relieving severe depression, but the beneficial effect tends to wear off after several months.

【45】Some people get unpleasant side effects, including short-term headaches, memory problems, nausea and muscle aches.

【46】But these risks need to be balanced against the risks of other treatments and the effects of not treating depression.

title: Co-dydramol
text:
【0】About co-dydramol \- Brand names: Paramol, Remedeine, Remedeine Forte
=====================================================================

【1】Co-dydramol is a mixture of 2 different painkillers: paracetamol and dihydrocodeine. Dihydrocodeine belongs to a group of medicines called opiates.

【2】It's used to treat aches and pains, including headaches, migraines, muscle and joint pain, period pain and toothache.

【3】Paracetamol and dihydrocodeine work by blocking messengers in the nerves and brain that tell your body that you're in pain.

【4】You'll usually take co-dydramol when everyday painkillers such as aspirin, ibuprofen and paracetamol have not worked on their own.

【5】Co-dydramol comes in 4 different strengths. You can buy lower-strength tablets from pharmacies. Higher-strength tablets are only available on prescription.

【6】Co-dydramol usually comes as tablets.

【7】Key facts
---------

【8】*   Co-dydramol takes up to 1 hour to work and keeps working for about 5 hours.
*   The most common side effects of co-dydramol are constipation and feeling sick or sleepy.
*   If you've bought co-dydramol from a pharmacy, do not use it for more than 3 days without talking to your doctor.
*   It's possible to become addicted to the dihydrocodeine in co-dydramol, but your doctor will explain how to reduce the risks of becoming addicted.
*   If you need to take co-dydramol for more than a few weeks, your treatment plan may include details of how and when to stop taking this medicine.

title: Nitrofurantoin
text:
【0】Side effects of nitrofurantoin
==============================

【1】Like all medicines, nitrofurantoin can cause side effects, although not everyone gets them.

【2】Common side effects
-------------------

【3】There are things you can do to help cope with these common side effects of nitrofurantoin.

【4】Feeling sick (nausea)

【5】Taking nitrofurantoin with or after a meal or snack should help prevent this. It may also help if you avoid rich or spicy food.

【6】Being sick (vomiting)

【7】Have frequent sips of fluids, such as water or squash, to avoid dehydration. Signs of dehydration include peeing less than usual or having strong-smelling pee. Do not take any other medicines to treat vomiting without speaking to a pharmacist or doctor.

【8】If you take contraceptive pills and you're being sick, your contraception may not protect you from pregnancy. Check the pill packet for advice.

【9】Diarrhoea

【10】Drink lots of fluids, such as water or squash, to avoid dehydration. Signs of dehydration include peeing less than usual or having strong-smelling pee. Do not take any other medicines to treat diarrhoea without speaking to a pharmacist or doctor.

【11】If you take contraceptive pills and you have severe diarrhoea for more than 24 hours, your contraception may not protect you from pregnancy. Check the pill packet for advice.

【12】Loss of appetite

【13】Eat when you would usually expect to be hungry. If it helps, eat smaller meals more often than usual. Snack when you're hungry. Have nutritious snacks that are high in calories and protein, such as dried fruit and nuts.

【14】Headaches

【15】Make sure you rest and drink plenty of fluids. Do not drink too much alcohol. Painkillers you can buy without a prescription, such as paracetamol and ibuprofen, are safe to take with nitrofurantoin. Speak to your doctor if these do not help or the headaches are severe.

【16】Dizziness or feeling sleepy

【17】If nitrofurantoin makes you feel dizzy, stop what you're doing and sit or lie down until you feel better. Do not drive a car or ride a bike while you're feeling dizzy or sleepy.

【18】Keep taking the medicine, but speak to a doctor if the advice on how to cope does not help and a side effect is still bothering you or does not go away.

【19】Nitrofurantoin may cause your pee to turn dark yellow or a brownish colour. This is normal and is not a reason to stop taking the medicine. Your pee will return to its usual colour once you stop taking nitrofurantoin.

【20】Serious side effects
--------------------

【21】Serious side effects are rare and happen in less than 1 in 1,000 people.

【22】Call a doctor or call 111 straight away if you have:

【23】*   a cough, coughing up blood or mucus, shortness of breath, pain when you breathe or a high temperature – these can be signs of lung problems
*   pale poo and dark pee together, or the whites of your eyes turn yellow or your skin turns yellow (this may be less obvious on brown or black skin) – this can be a sign of liver or gallbladder problems
*   bruising or bleeding you cannot explain (including nosebleeds), sore throat, a high temperature and feeling tired or generally unwell – these can be signs of blood problems
*   severe headaches

【24】### Immediate action required: Call 999 or go to A&E if:

【25】*   you get chest pain or difficulty breathing – these can be signs of lung problems
*   you get pins and needles, tingling sensations, numbness or weakness – these can be signs of nerve problems

【26】### Serious allergic reaction

【27】In rare cases, it's possible to have a serious allergic reaction to nitrofurantoin (anaphylaxis).

【28】#### Immediate action required: Call 999 now if:

【29】*   your lips, mouth, throat or tongue suddenly become swollen
*   you're breathing very fast or struggling to breathe (you may become very wheezy or feel like you're choking or gasping for air)
*   your throat feels tight or you're struggling to swallow
*   your skin, tongue or lips turn blue, grey or pale (if you have black or brown skin, this may be easier to see on the palms of your hands or soles of your feet)
*   you suddenly become very confused, drowsy or dizzy
*   someone faints and cannot be woken up
*   a child is limp, floppy or not responding like they normally do (their head may fall to the side, backwards or forwards, or they may find it difficult to lift their head or focus on your face)

【30】You or the person who's unwell may also have a rash that's swollen, raised, itchy, blistered or peeling.

【31】These can be signs of a serious allergic reaction and may need immediate treatment in hospital.

【32】Other side effects
------------------

【33】These are not all the side effects of nitrofurantoin. For a full list see the leaflet inside your medicines packet.

【34】Information:

【35】You can report any suspected side effect using the Yellow Card safety scheme.

【36】Visit Yellow Card for further information.

title: Rosuvastatin
text:
【0】About rosuvastatin
==================

【1】Rosuvastatin belongs to a group of medicines called statins. It works by working on the liver to stop it making cholesterol.

【2】Rosuvastatin is used to lower cholesterol if you have been diagnosed with high blood cholesterol. It's also taken to prevent heart disease, including heart attacks and strokes.

【3】Your doctor may also prescribe rosuvastatin if you have diabetes, kidney disease, or a family history of rheumatoid arthritis or heart disease.

【4】Rosuvastatin comes as tablets. It is available on prescription.

【5】Key facts
---------

【6】*   Rosuvastatin starts to work within a week to reduce cholesterol, but it can take up to a month to achieve its full effect. Your cholesterol levels should drop within 4 weeks if you take your medicine regularly, as prescribed.
*   Rosuvastatin can make you feel dizzy. If this happens, do not drive, cycle or use machines or tools until you feel better.
*   Speak to a doctor straight away if you get any unexplained muscle aches and pains, tenderness or weakness.
*   Keep taking rosuvastatin even if you feel well, as you'll still be getting the benefits. Most people with high cholesterol do not have any symptoms.
*   Do not take rosuvastatin if you're pregnant or trying to get pregnant.

title: Benign brain tumour (non-cancerous)
text:
【0】Treatment \- Benign brain tumour (non-cancerous)
================================================

【1】Contents
--------

【2】1.  Overview
2.  Symptoms
3.  Diagnosis
4.  Treatment
5.  Recovery

【3】**Benign (non-cancerous) brain tumours can usually be successfully removed with surgery and do not usually grow back.**

【4】It often depends on whether the surgeon is able to safely remove all of the tumour.

【5】If there's some left, it can either be monitored with scans or treated with radiotherapy.

【6】Rarely, some slow-growing non-cancerous tumours grow back after treatment and can change into malignant brain tumour (brain cancer), which are fast growing and likely to spread.

【7】You'll usually have follow-up appointments after finishing your treatment to monitor your condition and look for signs of the tumour returning.

【8】Your treatment plan
-------------------

【9】There are a number of different treatments for non-cancerous brain tumours.

【10】Some people only need repeated scans to monitor the tumour and assess any growth. This is usually the case when a tumour is found by chance.

【11】Some people will need surgery, particularly if they have severe or progressive symptoms, but sometimes non-surgical treatments are an option.

【12】A group of different specialists will be involved in your care. They will recommend what they think is the best treatment option for you, but the final decision will be yours.

【13】Before visiting hospital to discuss your treatment options, you may find it useful to write a list of questions you'd like to ask. For example, you may want to find out the advantages and disadvantages of particular treatments.

【14】Surgery
-------

【15】Surgery is the main treatment for non-cancerous brain tumours. The aim is to remove as much of the tumour as safely as possible without damaging the surrounding brain tissue.

【16】In most cases, a procedure called a craniotomy will be performed. Most operations are carried out under a general anaesthetic, which means you'll be asleep during the procedure.

【17】But in some cases you may need to be awake and responsive, in which case a local anaesthetic will be used.

【18】An area of your scalp will be shaved and a section of skull cut out as a flap to reveal the brain and tumour underneath.

【19】The surgeon will remove the tumour and fix the bone flap back into place with metal screws. The skin is closed with either sutures or staples.

【20】If it is not possible to remove the entire tumour, you may need further treatment with chemotherapy or radiotherapy.

【21】The Cancer Research UK website has more information about brain tumour surgery.

【22】Radiosurgery
------------

【23】Some tumours are located deep inside the brain and are difficult to remove without damaging surrounding tissue. In these cases, a special type of radiotherapy called stereotactic radiosurgery may be used.

【24】During radiosurgery, tiny beams of high-energy radiation are focused on the tumour to kill the abnormal cells.

【25】Treatment consists of one session, recovery is quick, and you can usually go home on the same day.

【26】Radiosurgery is only available in a few specialised centres in the UK. It's only suitable for some people, based on the characteristics, locations and size of their tumour.

【27】Chemotherapy and radiotherapy
-----------------------------

【28】Conventional chemotherapy is occasionally used to shrink non-cancerous brain tumours or kill any cells left behind after surgery. 

【29】Radiotherapy involves using controlled doses of high-energy radiation, usually X-rays, to kill the tumour cells.

【30】Chemotherapy is less frequently used to treat non-cancerous brain tumours. It's a powerful medicine that kills tumour cells, and can be given as a tablet, injection or drip.

【31】Side effects of these treatments can include tiredness, hair loss, nausea, and reddening of your skin.

【32】Read more about the side effects of radiotherapy and the side effects of chemotherapy.

【33】Medicine to treat symptoms
--------------------------

【34】You may also be given medicine to help treat some of your symptoms before or after surgery, including:

【35】*   anticonvulsants to prevent epileptic fits (seizures)
*   steroids to reduce swelling around the tumour, which can relieve some of your symptoms and make surgery easier
*   painkillers to treat headaches
*   anti-emetics to prevent vomiting

title: Prochlorperazine
text:
【0】How and when to take prochlorperazine \- Brand names: Stemetil, Buccastem
=========================================================================

【1】If you or your child have been prescribed prochlorperazine, follow your doctor's instructions about how and when to take it.

【2】Dosage
------

【3】The dose of prochlorperazine depends on what you're taking it for, but you'll usually take it 2 to 3 times a day.

【4】The dose for children aged 1 to 17 years old is based on their weight.

【5】How to take it
--------------

【6】Prochlorperazine tablets come as:

【7】*   standard tablets that you swallow whole with a drink of water
*   tablets that dissolve between your upper lip and gum (buccal tablets)

【8】You can take standard tablets with or without food.

【9】Buccal tablets work best if they're taken after meals. This gives them more time to dissolve.

【10】How long to take it for
-----------------------

【11】It's important to take prochlorperazine for the shortest possible time and at the lowest dose that works for you.

【12】You can take it long term if you need it, but only do this if your doctor advises it.

【13】If you take it for a long time and stop suddenly, it can cause withdrawal symptoms such as feeling or being sick and problems sleeping.

【14】Talk to your doctor if you want to stop taking prochlorperazine. They'll probably want to reduce your dose gradually to stop you having withdrawal symptoms.

【15】If you forget to take it
------------------------

【16】For motion sickness, if you miss your dose take it as soon as you remember.

【17】For anything else, skip the missed dose and take your next dose at the usual time.

【18】Never take 2 doses at the same time.

【19】If you take too much
--------------------

【20】Taking too much prochlorperazine can be dangerous.

【21】### Urgent advice: Contact 111 for advice now if:

【22】*   you take more than the recommended dose of prochlorperazine

【23】Go to 111 online or call 111. If you need advice for a child under the age of 5 years old, call 111.

【24】If you need to go to A&E, do not drive yourself. Get someone else to drive you or call for an ambulance.

【25】Take the prochlorperazine packet, or the leaflet inside it, plus any remaining medicine with you.

title: Glaucoma
text:
【0】Diagnosis \- Glaucoma
=====================

【1】Contents
--------

【2】1.  Overview
2.  Diagnosis
3.  Treatment

【3】**Glaucoma is usually picked up during a routine eye test, often before it causes any noticeable symptoms. Other tests are usually needed afterwards to diagnose and monitor the condition.**

【4】It's important to have regular eye tests so problems such as glaucoma can be diagnosed and treated as early as possible. Early treatment can help stop your vision becoming severely affected.

【5】You should have an eye test at least every 2 years. If you're at a higher risk of glaucoma – for example, if you have a close relative with it – you may be advised to have more frequent tests.

【6】You can get an eye test at a local opticians, and the tests are carried out by an optometrist. Find an optician near you.

【7】Some people can receive free eye tests on the NHS. Find out if you're entitled to free NHS eye tests.

【8】Tests to diagnose and monitor glaucoma
--------------------------------------

【9】There are different tests that can be carried out by an optometrist if they suspect you have glaucoma after a routine eye test.

【10】### Eye pressure test

【11】An eye pressure test (tonometry) uses an instrument called a tonometer to measure the pressure inside your eye.

【12】The optometrist will put a small amount of painkilling medicine (anaesthetic) and dye into the front of your eye. They will then shine a light into your eye and gently touch the surface of it with the tonometer.

【13】Some optometrists use a different instrument, which uses a puff of air and doesn't touch the eye, to check pressure.

【14】### Gonioscopy

【15】Gonioscopy is an examination to look at the front part your eye – the fluid-filled space between the coloured part (iris) and the clear window of the front of the eye (cornea). This is where the fluid should drain out of your eye.

【16】A gonioscopy can help to determine whether this area (the "angle") is open or closed (blocked), which can affect how fluid drains out of your eye. It will tell your optometrist what type of glaucoma you have.

【17】### Visual field test

【18】A visual field test (sometimes called perimetry) checks for missing areas of vision.

【19】You may be shown a sequence of light spots and asked to press a button to indicate which ones you can see. Some dots will appear at the edges of your vision (your peripheral vision), which is often the first area to be affected by glaucoma.

【20】If you can't see the spots in the periphery, it may mean glaucoma has damaged your vision.

【21】### Optic nerve assessment

【22】The optic nerve, which connects your eye to your brain, can become damaged in glaucoma, so an assessment may be carried out to see if it's healthy.

【23】For the test, eyedrops will be used to enlarge your pupils. Your eyes are then examined using either:

【24】*   a slit lamp (a microscope with a bright light)
*   optical coherence tomography – a type of scan where special rays of light are used to scan the back of your eye and produce an image of it

【25】The eyedrops used to widen your pupils could temporarily affect your ability to drive, so you'll need to make arrangements for getting home after your appointment.

【26】Referral to a specialist
------------------------

【27】If glaucoma is picked up during an eye test, you should be referred to a specialist eye doctor (ophthalmologist) for further tests. They will confirm your diagnosis and find out:

【28】*   how far the condition has developed
*   how much damage the glaucoma has done to your eyes
*   what may have caused the glaucoma

【29】They will then be able to advise on treatment. See treating glaucoma for more information.

【30】In some cases, your ophthalmologist will continue to treat you. But for less serious types of glaucoma, you may be referred back to the opticians.

title: Gonorrhoea
text:
【0】Diagnosis \- Gonorrhoea
=======================

【1】Contents
--------

【2】1.  Overview
2.  Symptoms
3.  Diagnosis
4.  Treatment
5.  Complications

【3】**The only way to find out if you have gonorrhoea is to be tested. If you suspect gonorrhoea or any other** **sexually transmitted infection (STI)****, it's important not to delay getting tested.**

【4】It's possible to be tested within a few days of having sex, but you may be advised to wait up to a week. You can be tested even if you do not have any symptoms.

【5】Early diagnosis and treatment of gonorrhoea reduces the risk of complications developing, such as pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) or infection in the testicles. Complications that arise from long-term infection are much more difficult to treat.

【6】Read more about the complications of gonorrhoea.

【7】Who should get tested
---------------------

【8】It's recommended you get tested if:

【9】*   you or your partner think you have symptoms of gonorrhoea
*   you've had unprotected sex with a new partner
*   you or your partner have had unprotected sex with other people
*   you have another STI
*   a sexual partner tells you they have an STI
*   during a vaginal examination, your nurse or doctor tells you the cells of your cervix are inflamed or there's discharge
*   you're pregnant or planning a pregnancy

【10】Where to get tested
-------------------

【11】There are several different places you can go to be tested for gonorrhoea:

【12】*   a sexual health clinic (sometimes also called a GUM clinic)
*   your GP surgery
*   a contraceptive and young people's clinic
*   a private clinic

【13】Find a sexual health clinic.

【14】It's possible to buy a gonorrhoea test from a pharmacy to do yourself at home. However, these tests vary in accuracy, so it's recommended that you go to your local sexual health service.

【15】All tests are free through the NHS, but you'll have to pay if you go to a private clinic.

【16】If you go to your GP practice, you may have to pay a prescription charge for any treatment.

【17】Testing for gonorrhoea
----------------------

【18】There are a number of different ways to test for gonorrhoea. In many cases, a swab will be used to remove a sample for testing, although men may only be asked to provide a urine sample.

【19】A swab looks a bit like a cotton bud, but it's smaller and rounded. It's wiped over parts of the body that may be infected to pick up samples of discharge. This only takes a few seconds and is not painful, although it may be a little uncomfortable.

【20】### Testing women

【21】For women, a doctor or nurse will usually take a swab to collect a sample from the vagina or cervix (entrance to the womb) during an internal examination. In some cases, a sample may also be taken from the urethra (the tube that carries urine out of the body).

【22】Sometimes, you may be asked to use a swab or tampon to collect a sample from inside your vagina yourself.

【23】Women are not usually asked to provide a urine sample to check for gonorrhoea because this is a less-accurate test for women.

【24】### Testing men

【25】Men will normally be asked to provide a urine sample or a swab may be used to pick up a sample of discharge from the end of the penis.

【26】If you're asked to provide a urine sample, it's important not to urinate for about 2 hours beforehand because this can wash the bacteria away and affect the results of the test.

【27】### Infections of the rectum, throat and eyes

【28】If there's a possibility that your rectum or throat is infected, the doctor or nurse may need to use a swab to collect a sample from these areas.

【29】If you have symptoms of conjunctivitis, such as red, inflamed eyes with discharge, a sample of the discharge may be collected from your eye.

【30】Getting the results
-------------------

【31】Some clinics may be able to carry out rapid tests, when the doctor can view the sample through a microscope and give you your test results straight away.

【32】Otherwise, you'll have to wait up to 2 weeks to get the results.

【33】Young people and sexual health clinics
--------------------------------------

【34】You can attend a sexual health clinic at any age and all results will be treated confidentially.

【35】If you're 13 to 16 years old, nobody in your household will be contacted without your permission. However, you may be encouraged to talk to your parents, guardian or another trusted adult.

【36】The situation is different for people under 13, because the law says that people of this age cannot consent (say yes) to sexual activity.

【37】If I use a sexual health service, will they tell my parents?

title: Transurethral resection of the prostate (TURP)
text:
【0】Recovery \- Transurethral resection of the prostate (TURP)
==========================================================

【1】Contents
--------

【2】1.  Overview
2.  How it's performed
3.  Recovery
4.  Risks
5.  Alternatives

【3】**Following a transurethral resection of the prostate (TURP), you may need to recover in hospital for1 to 3 days before you can go home.**

【4】While in hospital, you may be given fluids directly into a vein (intravenously) until you've recovered from the anaesthetic and are able to eat and drink.

【5】You shouldn't experience any severe pain, but there may be some discomfort and bladder spasms (contractions) from the catheter, which is left in place because your urethra (the tube that carries urine out of the body) will be swollen and sore.

【6】Before you're discharged, you'll be given advice about your recovery. A follow-up appointment to check your progress should be made for a few weeks later.

【7】Peeing after TURP
-----------------

【8】You won't be able to pee normally at first because your urethra will be swollen.

【9】The catheter used to flush out your bladder during the operation will be left in place for a while to allow you to pee until the swelling goes down.

【10】During the day after the operation, water may be pumped through the catheter to clean your bladder and get rid of any blood clots and other debris.

【11】This usually is not painful, but may make your bladder feel uncomfortably full.

【12】The catheter may be removed to check if you can pee before going home.

【13】It's normal to find peeing uncomfortable and difficult to control for at least a few days after the catheter is removed.

【14】If you still cannot pee, a catheter may need to be put back in.

【15】You'll be able to go home with the catheter still in place, and an appointment will be made to remove it a few days or weeks later. 

【16】See living with a urinary catheter for information about looking after your catheter.

【17】Recovering at home
------------------

【18】It's common to feel tired and under the weather for a week or two after having a TURP. Most men are up and about after 3 to 4 weeks recovery.

【19】For the first 3 to 4 weeks, you shouldn't lift or move any heavy objects (including shopping) or do any strenuous exercise. If possible, ask friends or family members if they can help around the house.

【20】Once you feel able, gentle exercise such as walking will help keep your blood circulating and lower your risk of getting a blood clot in your legs.

【21】Drinking plenty of water while you're recovering may help reduce the risk of getting a urinary tract infection (UTI) and can help clear any blood from your pee.

【22】You may also be advised to do some pelvic floor exercises to help improve your bladder control.

【23】Any pain can usually be treated by taking over-the-counter painkillers, such as paracetamol or ibuprofen.

【24】Returning to your normal activities
-----------------------------------

【25】It usually takes between 3 and 4 weeks to fully recover from a TURP. Your surgeon or GP will advise you about when it's safe to return to your normal activities.

【26】### Work

【27】When you can return to work will largely depend on your job. For example, someone who works in an office may be able to return to work sooner than someone who does heavy manual work.

【28】In most cases, you'll be advised to take around 3 or 4 weeks off work.

【29】### Driving

【30】Ask your surgeon or GP for advice on when it's safe for you to drive again.

【31】You should also speak to your insurer before driving again after having surgery.

【32】### Having sex

【33】It will probably be around 3 or 4 weeks after your operation before you feel comfortable enough to have sex.

【34】Blood in your pee
-----------------

【35】After having a TURP, it's normal to occasionally notice some blood in your urine. Around a week or two after the operation, the amount of blood may increase as the scab on your prostate falls off.

【36】Drinking plenty of fluids will help flush any blood or small blood clots out of your bladder.

【37】When to seek medical advice
---------------------------

【38】While you're recovering, you should contact a GP immediately or call 111 if:

【39】*   you have a high temperature
*   you have severe pain when peeing
*   you cannot pee
*   there's a lot of blood in your pee or this gets worse
*   there are blood clots in your pee

【40】These symptoms can be a sign of a problem, such as internal bleeding or a urinary infection, that needs to be treated.

【0】Pregnancy, breastfeeding and fertility while using hydrocortisone for piles and itchy bottom \- Brand names: Anusol, Anugesic, Germaloids, Perinal, Proctosedyl, Uniroid, Xyloproct
===================================================================================================================================================================================

【1】Hydrocortisone and pregnancy
----------------------------

【2】Hydrocortisone creams, ointments, sprays and suppositories for piles and itchy bottom can be used in pregnancy.

【3】Only a small amount of the medicine gets into your blood, and this will not harm your baby.

【4】Hydrocortisone and breastfeeding
--------------------------------

【5】Hydrocortisone creams, ointments, sprays and suppositories for piles and itchy bottom can be used while breastfeeding, but try to only use them for a short time.

【6】It's not known how much passes into breast milk, but it's likely to be a tiny amount, and your baby will not be able to absorb much of it into their body. It's unlikely to cause any side effects in your baby.

【7】Wash your hands after using the treatment and before picking up your baby.

【8】Treatments for piles and itchy bottom containing hydrocortisone may also contain other ingredients such as local anaesthetics. It's still OK to use them while breastfeeding.

【9】If you notice that your baby is not feeding as well as usual, is not putting on weight as you would expect, or if you have any other concerns about your baby, talk to your health visitor, midwife, pharmacist or doctor as soon as possible.

【10】Hydrocortisone and fertility
----------------------------

【11】There's no evidence that hydrocortisone treatments for piles and itchy bottom affect fertility in either men or women.

【12】Information:

【13】Find out more about how to treat piles in pregnancy.

【14】Find out more about how steroid medicines such as hydrocortisone can affect you and your baby in pregnancy on the Best Use of Medicines in Pregnancy (BUMPS) website.

title: Apixaban
text:
【0】How and when to take apixaban
=============================

【1】It's important to take apixaban as your doctor has told you.

【2】Dosage and strength
-------------------

【3】Apixaban comes as 2.5mg and 5mg tablets.

【4】Your dose of apixaban depends on why you're taking it. If you're unsure what dose you need to take, check with your doctor or pharmacist.

【5】The usual dose in adults if you:

【6】*   have a heart condition called atrial fibrillation is one 5mg tablet, taken twice a day. Your doctor may prescribe a lower dose of one 2.5mg tablet twice a day if you're over 80 years old, weigh less than 60kg (9st 6lb), or have kidney disease and are at higher risk of bleeding
*   have recently had a blood clot (within the last 6 months) is two 5mg tablets taken twice a day, for the first 7 days. After that, you'll take one 5mg tablet twice a day
*   need to reduce the risk of a future blood clot is one 2.5mg tablet taken twice a day
*   have had a hip or knee replacement is one 2.5mg tablet, taken twice a day. You'll usually take your first dose 12 to 24 hours after surgery

【7】How to take it
--------------

【8】You'll usually take apixaban tablets twice a day. Try to take it at the same time every day.

【9】Swallow the tablet with a drink of water. Apixaban can be taken with or without food.

【10】You can crush apixaban tablets and mix them with water, apple juice or apple purée. Swallow this mixture straight away.

【11】How long to take it for
-----------------------

【12】How long you need to take apixaban will depend on why you're taking it. If you have had:

【13】*   knee replacement surgery, you'll usually take it for 10 to 14 days
*   a hip replacement, you'll usually take it for 32 to 38 days
*   a blood clot (DVT or pulmonary embolism), you'll usually take it for at least 3 months

【14】Depending on what caused the blood clot, you might need to take it for longer.

【15】If you have a heart problem like atrial fibrillation, you might need to take apixaban long term or even for the rest of your life.

【16】Do not stop taking apixaban without talking to your doctor.

【17】If you stop taking apixaban, your risk of blood clots will return to what it was before. This can start happening again within a day or two of stopping. This means that you may be at increased risk of serious problems like stroke, heart attack, deep vein thrombosis or pulmonary embolism.

【18】If you forget to take it
------------------------

【19】Take your medicine as soon as you remember, unless it's nearly time for your next dose. In this case, skip the missed dose and take your next dose at the usual time.

【20】Do not take 2 doses to make up for a missed one.

【21】It's very important that you remember to take apixaban every day. If you often forget doses, it may help to set an alarm to remind you. You could also ask your pharmacist for advice on other ways to help you remember to take your medicine.

【22】If you take too much
--------------------

【23】Taking too much apixaban puts you at risk of bleeding.

【24】### Urgent advice: Contact 111 for advice now if:

【25】*   you take more than your prescribed dose of apixaban

【26】Go to 111.nhs.uk or call 111

【27】If you go to A&E, do not drive yourself. Get someone else to drive you or call for an ambulance.

【28】Take the apixaban packet, or leaflet inside it, plus any remaining medicine with you.

【29】Anticoagulant alert card
------------------------

【30】Your doctor or pharmacist will give you an anticoagulant alert card.

【31】Carry this with you all the time. It tells healthcare professionals that you're taking an anticoagulant. This can be useful for them to know in case of a medical emergency.

【32】If you need any medical or dental treatment, show your anticoagulant alert card to the nurse, doctor or dentist. This includes before you have vaccinations and routine sessions with the dental hygienist.

【33】Your doctor may advise you to stop taking apixaban or reduce your dose for a short time.

【34】Changes to your medicine
------------------------

【35】### Switching from apixaban to warfarin

【36】If you need to switch from apixaban to warfarin, you may need to take both medicines together for a few days.

【37】Your doctor, or anticoagulant clinic, will do a blood test called the international normalised ratio (INR) to check how quickly your blood's clotting.

【38】This is to help decide exactly when you should stop taking apixaban.

【39】### Switching from warfarin to apixaban

【40】If you need to switch from warfarin to apixaban, your doctor will advise you when to stop taking warfarin. This will probably be a few days before you start apixaban.

【41】Your doctor, or anticoagulant clinic, will do a blood test called the international normalised ratio (INR) to check how quickly your blood's clotting.

【42】This is to help decide exactly when you should start taking apixaban.

title: 8 tips for healthy eating
text:
【0】8 tips for healthy eating
=========================

【1】These 8 practical tips cover the basics of healthy eating and can help you make healthier choices.

【2】The key to a healthy diet is to eat the right amount of calories for how active you are so you balance the energy you consume with the energy you use.

【3】If you eat or drink more than your body needs, you'll put on weight because the energy you do not use is stored as fat. If you eat and drink too little, you'll lose weight.

【4】You should also eat a wide range of foods to make sure you're getting a balanced diet and your body is receiving all the nutrients it needs.

【5】It's recommended that men have around 2,500 calories a day (10,500 kilojoules). Women should have around 2,000 calories a day (8,400 kilojoules).

【6】Most adults in the UK are eating more calories than they need and should eat fewer calories.

【7】1\. Base your meals on higher fibre starchy carbohydrates
---------------------------------------------------------

【8】Starchy carbohydrates should make up just over a third of the food you eat. They include potatoes, bread, rice, pasta and cereals.

【9】Choose higher fibre or wholegrain varieties, such as wholewheat pasta, brown rice or potatoes with their skins on.

【10】They contain more fibre than white or refined starchy carbohydrates and can help you feel full for longer.

【11】Try to include at least 1 starchy food with each main meal. Some people think starchy foods are fattening, but gram for gram the carbohydrate they contain provides fewer than half the calories of fat.

【12】Keep an eye on the fats you add when you're cooking or serving these types of foods because that's what increases the calorie content – for example, oil on chips, butter on bread and creamy sauces on pasta.

【13】2\. Eat lots of fruit and veg
-----------------------------

【14】It's recommended that you eat at least 5 portions of a variety of fruit and veg every day. They can be fresh, frozen, canned, dried or juiced.

【15】Getting your 5 A Day is easier than it sounds. Why not chop a banana over your breakfast cereal, or swap your usual mid-morning snack for a piece of fresh fruit?

【16】A portion of fresh, canned or frozen fruit and vegetables is 80g. A portion of dried fruit (which should be kept to mealtimes) is 30g.

【17】A 150ml glass of fruit juice, vegetable juice or smoothie also counts as 1 portion, but limit the amount you have to no more than 1 glass a day as these drinks are sugary and can damage your teeth.

【18】3\. Eat more fish, including a portion of oily fish
---------------------------------------------------

【19】Fish is a good source of protein and contains many vitamins and minerals.

【20】Aim to eat at least 2 portions of fish a week, including at least 1 portion of oily fish.

【21】Oily fish are high in omega-3 fats, which may help prevent heart disease. 

【22】Oily fish include:

【23】*   salmon
*   trout
*   herring
*   sardines
*   pilchards
*   mackerel

【24】Non-oily fish include:

【25】*   haddock
*   plaice
*   coley
*   cod
*   tuna
*   skate
*   hake

【26】You can choose from fresh, frozen and canned, but remember that canned and smoked fish can be high in salt.

【27】Most people should be eating more fish, but there are recommended limits for some types of fish.

【28】Find out more about fish and shellfish

【29】4\. Cut down on saturated fat and sugar
---------------------------------------

【30】### Saturated fat

【31】You need some fat in your diet, but it's important to pay attention to the amount and type of fat you're eating.

【32】There are 2 main types of fat: saturated and unsaturated. Too much saturated fat can increase the amount of cholesterol in the blood, which increases your risk of developing heart disease.

【33】On average, men should have no more than 30g of saturated fat a day. On average, women should have no more than 20g of saturated fat a day.

【34】Children under the age of 11 should have less saturated fat than adults, but a low-fat diet is not suitable for children under 5.

【35】Saturated fat is found in many foods, such as:

【36】*   fatty cuts of meat
*   sausages
*   butter
*   hard cheese
*   cream
*   cakes
*   biscuits
*   lard
*   pies

【37】Try to eat less saturated fat and choose foods that contain unsaturated fats instead, such as vegetable oils and spreads, oily fish and avocados.

【38】For a healthier choice, use a small amount of vegetable or olive oil, or reduced-fat spread instead of butter, lard or ghee.

【39】When you're having meat, choose lean cuts and cut off any visible fat.

【40】All types of fat are high in energy, so they should only be eaten in small amounts.

【41】### Sugar

【42】Regularly consuming foods and drinks high in sugar increases your risk of obesity and tooth decay.

【43】Sugary foods and drinks are often high in energy (measured in kilojoules or calories), and if consumed too often can contribute to weight gain. They can also cause tooth decay, especially if eaten between meals.

【44】Free sugars are any sugars added to foods or drinks, or found naturally in honey, syrups and unsweetened fruit juices and smoothies.

【45】This is the type of sugar you should be cutting down on, rather than the sugar found in fruit and milk.

【46】Many packaged foods and drinks contain surprisingly high amounts of free sugars.

【47】Free sugars are found in many foods, such as:

【48】*   sugary fizzy drinks
*   sugary breakfast cereals
*   cakes
*   biscuits
*   pastries and puddings
*   sweets and chocolate
*   alcoholic drinks

【49】Food labels can help. Use them to check how much sugar foods contain.

【50】More than 22.5g of total sugars per 100g means the food is high in sugar, while 5g of total sugars or less per 100g means the food is low in sugar.

【51】Find out how to cut down on sugar in your diet

【52】5\. Eat less salt: no more than 6g a day for adults
---------------------------------------------------

【53】Eating too much salt can raise your blood pressure. People with high blood pressure are more likely to develop heart disease or have a stroke.

【54】Even if you do not add salt to your food, you may still be eating too much.

【55】About three-quarters of the salt you eat is already in the food when you buy it, such as breakfast cereals, soups, breads and sauces.

【56】Use food labels to help you cut down. More than 1.5g of salt per 100g means the food is high in salt.

【57】Adults and children aged 11 and over should eat no more than 6g of salt (about a teaspoonful) a day. Younger children should have even less.

【58】Get tips for a lower salt diet

【59】6\. Get active and be a healthy weight
--------------------------------------

【60】As well as eating healthily, regular exercise may help reduce your risk of getting serious health conditions. It's also important for your overall health and wellbeing.

【61】Read more about the benefits of exercise and physical activity guidelines for adults.

【62】Being overweight or obese can lead to health conditions, such as type 2 diabetes, certain cancers, heart disease and stroke. Being underweight could also affect your health.

【63】Most adults need to lose weight by eating fewer calories.

【64】If you're trying to lose weight, aim to eat less and be more active. Eating a healthy, balanced diet can help you maintain a healthy weight.

【65】Check whether you're a healthy weight by using the BMI healthy weight calculator.

【66】Lose weight with the NHS weight loss plan, a 12-week weight loss guide that combines advice on healthier eating and physical activity.

【67】If you're underweight, see underweight adults. If you're worried about your weight, ask your GP or a dietitian for advice.

【68】7\. Do not get thirsty
----------------------

【69】You need to drink plenty of fluids to stop you getting dehydrated. The government recommends drinking 6 to 8 glasses every day. This is in addition to the fluid you get from the food you eat. 

【70】All non-alcoholic drinks count, but water, lower fat milk and lower sugar drinks, including tea and coffee, are healthier choices. 

【71】Try to avoid sugary soft and fizzy drinks, as they're high in calories. They're also bad for your teeth. 

【72】Even unsweetened fruit juice and smoothies are high in free sugar.

【73】Your combined total of drinks from fruit juice, vegetable juice and smoothies should not be more than 150ml a day, which is a small glass.

【74】Remember to drink more fluids during hot weather or while exercising.

【75】8\. Do not skip breakfast
-------------------------

【76】Some people skip breakfast because they think it'll help them lose weight.

【77】But a healthy breakfast high in fibre and low in fat, sugar and salt can form part of a balanced diet, and can help you get the nutrients you need for good health.

【78】A wholegrain lower sugar cereal with semi-skimmed milk and fruit sliced over the top is a tasty and healthier breakfast.

【79】Further information
-------------------

【80】*   The Eatwell Guide can help you get the right balance of the 5 main food groups. The guide shows you how much of what you eat should come from each food group.
*   Read more about eating a balanced diet and understanding calories.

【81】More in How to eat a balanced diet
----------------------------------

【82】*   Eating a balanced diet

*   The vegetarian diet

title: Frostbite
text:
【0】Overview \- Frostbite
=====================

【1】Contents
--------

【2】1.  Overview
2.  Symptoms
3.  Treatment

【3】**Frostbite is damage to skin and tissue caused by exposure to freezing temperatures – typically any temperature below -0.55C (31F).**

【4】Frostbite can affect any part of your body, but the extremities, such as the hands, feet, ears, nose and lips, are most likely to be affected.

【5】The symptoms of frostbite usually begin with the affected parts feeling cold and painful.

【6】If exposure to the cold continues, you may feel pins and needles before the area becomes numb as the tissues freeze.

【7】When to get medical attention
-----------------------------

【8】If you think you or someone else may have frostbite, call your GP or NHS 111 for advice.

【9】If the symptoms are more severe or there are signs of hypothermia, such as constant shivering or fast breathing (hyperventilation), go immediately to your nearest A&E.

【10】A doctor will examine the affected area, check your vital signs, and ask how you got frostbite.

【11】You may need a follow-up appointment or referral to a specialist, as the full extent of a frostbite injury often isn't apparent until a few days later.

【12】Treating frostbite
------------------

【13】A person with frostbite should be taken to a warm environment as soon as possible. This is to limit the effects of the injury and because it's also likely they'll have hypothermia. Don't put pressure on the affected area.

【14】The frostbitten area should be warmed up by a healthcare professional. This is usually done by immersing the affected area in warm – but not hot – water. 

【15】A bath of water at 37C to 39C (98.6F to 102.2F) is recommended for rewarming. The rewarming process is often painful, and regular strong painkillers may be needed.

【16】It's important not to rewarm the affected area if there's a chance of it freezing again, as this can lead to further tissue damage.

【17】If frostbite is severe, the loss of blood supply to the tissue may cause it to die (gangrene). A type of surgery called debridement may be needed to remove the dead tissue. Amputation may be needed if frostbite is severe.

【18】Read more about treating frostbite.

【19】What causes frostbite?
----------------------

【20】The body responds to cold temperatures by narrowing the blood vessels. Blood flow to the extremities slows down so flow to the vital organs can be increased.

【21】As the blood is redirected away from the extremities, these parts of the body get colder, and fluid in the tissue can freeze into ice crystals.

【22】The ice crystals can cause severe cell and tissue damage in the affected area. The low blood flow also deprives the tissues of oxygen. If blood flow can't be restored, the tissue will eventually die.

【23】### At-risk groups

【24】Certain groups of people are at greater risk of getting frostbite.

【25】They include:

【26】*   people who take part in winter and high-altitude sports, such as mountaineers and skiers
*   anyone stranded in extreme cold weather conditions
*   anyone who works outdoors in harsh conditions for long periods of time, such as soldiers, sailors and rescue workers
*   homeless people
*   the very young and very old, as their bodies are less able to regulate body temperature
*   people with conditions that cause blood vessel damage or circulation problems, such as diabetes and Raynaud's phenomenon
*   anyone taking medicine that constricts the blood vessels, including beta blockers – smoking can also constrict the blood vessels

【27】People who've taken drugs or drunk alcohol are also vulnerable to frostbite. Taking drugs or being drunk can lead to risky behaviour, not responding normally to cold, or falling asleep outside in cold weather.

【28】As you'd expect, cases of frostbite in England often rise during particularly cold winters. For example, during the very cold winter of 2010-11, there were 111 hospital admissions for frostbite. In most years, there are around 30 to 60 cases every winter.

【29】Preventing frostbite
--------------------

【30】Most of the time frostbite can be prevented by taking precautions during cold weather.

【31】Avoid unnecessary exposure to cold temperatures. The combination of wind and cold temperatures (wind chill) can also cause a rapid drop in temperature, so avoid going out when it's cold and windy, if possible. 

【32】It's also important to know what the early symptoms of frostbite are, particularly the tingling sensation of frostnip.

【33】Wear appropriate clothing that protects your extremities, such as:

【34】*   well-insulated boots and a thick pair of well-fitting socks
*   mittens – they provide better protection against very cold weather than gloves
*   a warm, weatherproof hat that covers your ears – it's important to protect your head from the cold
*   multiple thin layers of warm, loose-fitting clothing – these act as insulation

【35】You should also try to keep dry and remove any wet clothing as soon as you can. 

【36】If you're travelling during cold weather, plan for emergencies. For example, if you're driving in icy conditions, make sure you keep a warm blanket and some spare clothes in the boot of your car in case you break down. 

【37】If you're travelling by foot, always let others know where you're going and what time you'll be back. Take a fully charged mobile phone with you so you can call for help if you have an accident, such as a fall.

【38】Be careful when drinking alcohol during very cold weather. Drinking too much increases your risk of falling asleep in the cold, a common cause of frostbite. Alcohol also causes you to lose heat at a faster rate.

【39】Smoking also makes you more vulnerable to the effects of the cold because nicotine can narrow your blood vessels.

【40】Complications of frostbite
--------------------------

【41】If some of your tissue dies, the dead tissue will no longer have a blood supply. This can make the affected body part very vulnerable to infection because your body relies on white blood cells to ward off infections.

【42】People with frostbite are at risk of bacterial wound infections, such as tetanus. More seriously, this infection can spread into the blood (sepsis), which requires treatment with antibiotics. Both conditions require hospital admission. 

【43】Read more about treating tetanus and treating sepsis.

【44】### Hypothermia

【45】Severe frostbite is often associated with hypothermia, which is a dangerous drop in body temperature below 35C (95F).

【46】Initial symptoms can include:

【47】*   constant shivering
*   tiredness
*   low energy
*   cold or pale skin
*   fast breathing (hyperventilation)

【48】Someone with severe hypothermia may be unconscious and have shallow breathing and a weak pulse. 

【49】Read more about how hypothermia is treated.

title: Sotrovimab (Xevudy)
text:
【0】Pregnancy, breastfeeding and fertility while having sotrovimab
==============================================================

【1】Sotrovimab and pregnancy
------------------------

【2】There is little information about the use of sotrovimab in pregnancy.

【3】It is an antibody that is likely to cross the placenta and the effect on your baby is unknown. However, similar antibodies are given during pregnancy for different reasons (such as anti-D injections depending on your blood type), and are safe.

【4】Sotrovimab has not yet been studied in pregnancy, so the risks and benefits of the treatment for you and your baby are currently unknown. Sotrovimab has been shown to be effective at treating COVID-19 outside of pregnancy and it's likely that it will be effective during pregnancy too.

【5】If you're pregnant, you and your baby are at greater risk from severe coronavirus (COVID-19) infection, and so you may benefit from having sotrovimab despite there being little information on its use.

【6】Speak to your doctor who will be able to discuss whether taking this medicine is right for you, based on your health and your personal risk from COVID-19.

【7】Sotrovimab and breastfeeding
----------------------------

【8】If your doctor or health visitor says that your baby is healthy, it's OK to have sotrovimab while breastfeeding.

【9】There is no information about whether sotrovimab gets into breast milk, but it would only be expected to pass through in tiny amounts.

【10】Your baby will not be able to absorb a lot of this medicine from your breast milk into their body, and so it's unlikely to cause any side effects in your baby.

【11】You can continue to breastfeed if you have COVID-19.

【12】If you notice that your baby is not feeding as well as usual, or if you have any other concerns about your baby, then talk to your health visitor, midwife, pharmacist or doctor as soon as possible.

【13】Sotrovimab and fertility
------------------------

【14】It's not known whether having sotrovimab will affect fertility in either men or women.

【15】Non-urgent advice: Tell your doctor if you're:
----------------------------------------------

【16】*   trying to get pregnant
*   pregnant
*   breastfeeding

【0】Taking trazodone with other medicines and herbal supplements
