【1】Cautions with other medicines
-----------------------------

【2】Many medicines can affect the way trazodone works, and trazodone can do the same to other medicines. Both can increase the chances of you having side effects.

【3】Tell your doctor if you're taking any of these medicines before you start trazodone:

【4】*   tranylcypromine, phenelzine or isocarboxazid (for depression), or selegiline (for Parkinson's disease) if you have taken any of these medicines within the last 2 weeks
*   antidepressants, such as amitriptyline or fluoxetine
*   antifungal medicines, such as ketoconazole or itraconazole
*   epilepsy medicines, such as carbamazepine or phenytoin
*   medicines for high blood pressure, such as clonidine
*   sleeping pills, tranquilisers or other sedatives
*   digoxin, a heart medicine
*   erythromycin, an antibiotic
*   levodopa, used to treat Parkinson's disease
*   ritonavir, used to treat HIV infections
*   warfarin, used to prevent blood clots

【5】Mixing trazodone with herbal remedies and supplements
-----------------------------------------------------

【6】Do not take St John's wort, the herbal remedy for depression, while you're being treated with trazodone as this will increase your risk of side effects.

【7】There's not enough information to say that other herbal remedies and supplements are safe to take with trazodone. They're not tested in the same way as pharmacy and prescription medicines. They're generally not tested for the effect they have on other medicines.

【9】Tell your doctor or pharmacist if you're taking any other medicines, including herbal remedies, vitamins or supplements.

title: Mirtazapine
text:
【0】Common questions about mirtazapine
==================================

【1】How does mirtazapine work?

【2】Mirtazapine is a type of antidepressant medicine.

【3】It works by increasing the activity of mood-enhancing chemicals called noradrenaline and serotonin in your brain.

【4】When will I feel better?

【5】You may see an improvement in your symptoms after a week although it usually takes between 4 and 6 weeks before you feel the full benefits. That's because it takes around a week for mirtazapine levels to build up in your body, and then a few weeks longer for your body to adapt and get used to it.

【6】Do not stop taking mirtazapine just because you feel it is not helping your symptoms. Give the medicine at least 6 weeks to work.

【7】How will it make me feel?

【8】Antidepressants like mirtazapine help to gradually lift your mood so you feel better.

【9】You may notice that you sleep better and get on with people more easily because you're less anxious. You'll hopefully be more relaxed about things that used to worry you.

【10】Mirtazapine will not change your personality, it will simply help you feel like yourself again.

【11】Do not expect to feel better overnight, though. Some people feel worse during the first few weeks of treatment before they begin to feel better.

【12】Are there any long-term side effects?

【13】Mirtazapine is generally safe to take for a long time. There do not seem to be any lasting harmful effects from taking it for many months or years.

【14】What will happen if I stop taking it?

【15】If you've been feeling better for 6 months or more, your doctor may suggest coming off mirtazapine.

【16】Your doctor will probably recommend reducing your dose gradually over several weeks, or longer if you've been taking mirtazapine for a long time.

【17】This is to help prevent you getting any withdrawal symptoms as you come off the medicine.

【18】Side effects can include:

【19】*   feeling anxious, dizzy or sick
*   numbness or tingling in your hands or feet
*   headaches
*   shaking

【20】### Important

【21】Do not stop taking mirtazapine suddenly, or without talking to your doctor first.

【22】How does mirtazapine compare with other antidepressants?

【23】Mirtazapine is not any better or worse than other antidepressants. Sometimes people get on better with one antidepressant than another.

【24】If you're not feeling any better after 6 weeks, talk to your doctor. They may suggest that you try a different medicine.

【25】Are there other treatments for depression?

【26】Taking antidepressants, including mirtazapine, is just one of many ways to treat depression.

【27】Other treatments that may help include:

【28】*   talking therapy such as cognitive behavioural therapy
*   exercise programmes
*   help to get a good night's sleep

【29】Choosing a treatment that's most suitable for you depends on:

【30】*   how long you've had depression
*   your symptoms
*   whether you've had depression before
*   whether previous treatment has worked
*   how likely you are to stick with your treatment
*   the potential side effects
*   your preferences and priorities

【31】Will it affect my contraception?

【32】Mirtazapine will not affect any type of contraception, including the combined pill or emergency contraception.

【33】However, if mirtazapine makes you sick (vomit) or have severe diarrhoea for more than 24 hours, your contraceptive pills may not protect you from pregnancy. Look on the pill packet to find out what to do.

【34】Read more about what to do if you're on the pill and you're being sick or have diarrhoea.

【35】Can I drive or ride a bike?

【36】Some people cannot concentrate properly while they are taking mirtazapine. It can also make you feel sleepy.

【37】When you first start taking mirtazapine, it's a good idea to stop driving and cycling for the first few days until you know how this medicine makes you feel.

【38】It's an offence to drive a car if your ability to drive safely is affected. It's your responsibility to decide if it's safe to drive. If you're in any doubt, do not drive.

【39】Talk to your doctor or pharmacist if you're unsure whether it's safe for you to drive while taking mirtazapine. GOV.UK has more information on the law on drugs and driving.

【40】Can I drink alcohol while taking mirtazapine?

【41】You can drink alcohol while taking mirtazapine but it may make you feel sleepy and unsteady on your feet.

【42】It might be best to stop drinking alcohol for the first few days of treatment until you see how the medicine affects you.

【43】Drinking alcohol every day or in large amounts can make your symptoms worse. It also makes it harder for mirtazapine to work properly.

【44】Is there any food or drink I need to avoid?

【45】You can eat and drink normally while taking mirtazapine.

【46】Will I gain or lose weight?

【47】Mirtazapine can make you feel more hungry than usual, so you may put on weight.

【48】If you start to have problems with your weight while taking mirtazapine, talk to your doctor or pharmacist.

【49】Will recreational drugs affect it?

【50】Taking cannibis with mirtazapine can make you feel very sleepy, especially if you've just started taking mirtazapine.

【51】It can be dangerous to take mirtazapine with:

【52】*   methadone
*   stimulants like MDMA (ecstasy) or cocaine
*   hallucinogens like LSD
*   novel psychoactive substances (which used to be known as legal highs) like mephedrone

【53】Find out about the side effects of some recreational drugs on the Frank website.

【54】### Important

【55】Mirtazapine has not been properly tested with recreational drugs. Talk to your doctor if you think you might use recreational drugs while taking mirtazapine.

title: Budesonide nasal spray
text:
【0】Common questions about budesonide nasal spray \- Brand name: Benacort
=====================================================================

【1】How does budesonide nasal spray work?

【2】Budesonide nasal spray is a corticosteroid, or steroid medicine.

【3】It works by reducing the swelling, mucus, itching and irritation you can get in your nose when you have allergies or hay fever.

【4】It can take a little longer to work than antihistamine sprays, but the effects last for longer.

【5】If you're using it to treat nasal polyps, it can reduce the swelling and irritation of the lining of your nose so your polyps shrink.

【6】When will I feel better?

【7】When you first use budesonide nasal spray, your symptoms will not get better straight away. It takes a few days for it to start working and can take several weeks for it to reach its full effect.

【8】If you bought the spray from a pharmacy or shop, check the leaflet that comes with it. This will tell you when to speak to your doctor or pharmacist if you feel no better after using the spray. This is usually after 7 to 14 days.

【9】If you use the spray for hay fever, it's best to start using it at least a couple of weeks before the hay fever season starts. Many people notice they get symptoms around the same time each year.

【10】If you use the spray for nasal polyps, it can take 1 to 2 months for your symptoms to improve.

【11】Are there any long-term side effects?

【12】Budesonide nasal spray is unlikely to have any lasting harmful effects if you follow the instructions that come with it, or use it as your doctor recommends.

【13】However, children and teenagers need to have their height and weight monitored carefully if they're using budesonide nasal spray for a long time. This is to make sure the steroid is not affecting their growth.

【14】The nasal spray delivers a small amount of steroid medicine exactly where you need it. This limits the amount of steroid reaching the rest of your body. It also keeps the risk of side effects as low as possible.

【15】Do I need a steroid card?

【16】You may need a steroid card if you're regularly using budesonide nasal spray with other steroids, such as a steroid inhaler. This can cause your adrenal glands to make less of the hormones your body needs, such as cortisol (known as the stress hormone). This is known as adrenal insufficiency.

【17】Your doctor or pharmacist will assess your risk of adrenal insufficiency based on the type and dose of steroids you're taking and may recommend that you carry a steroid emergency card (red card). This card is the size of a credit card and fits in your wallet or purse.

【18】Will it affect my contraception?

【19】Budesonide does not affect any type of contraception, including the combined pill and emergency contraception.

【20】Can I drive or ride a bike?

【21】For most people, using budesonide nasal spray will not affect their ability to drive a car or cycle.

【22】Can I drink alcohol while using budesonide nasal spray?

【23】Yes, you can drink alcohol if you're using budesonide nasal spray.

title: Bullous pemphigoid
text:
【0】Bullous pemphigoid
==================

【1】Bullous pemphigoid is a rare skin condition that mainly affects older people. It usually starts with an itchy, raised rash. As the condition develops, large blisters can form on the skin.

【2】It may last a few years and sometimes causes serious problems, but treatment can help manage the condition in most cases.

【3】Check if you have bullous pemphigoid
------------------------------------

【4】Bullous pemphigoid mainly affects people over 60.

【5】It usually starts as sore, itchy patches. On white skin the patches look red or pink. On brown and black skin they may look dark reddish-brown.

【6】Credit:

【7】DR P. MARAZZI/SCIENCE PHOTO LIBRARY https://www.sciencephoto.com/media/711904/view

【8】It can affect large areas of the body or limbs.

【9】Credit:

【10】ISM/SCIENCE PHOTO LIBRARY https://www.sciencephoto.com/media/880176/view

【11】After a few weeks, small blisters may appear.

【12】Credit:

【13】DR P. MARAZZI/SCIENCE PHOTO LIBRARY https://www.sciencephoto.com/media/711900/view

【14】The blisters can grow quite big and may contain blood.

【15】Credit:

【16】DR P. MARAZZI/SCIENCE PHOTO LIBRARY https://www.sciencephoto.com/media/260961/view

【17】Not everyone gets blisters. If you do, they may keep coming and going for months or years.

【18】### Non-urgent advice: See a GP if:

【19】*   you have an itchy rash that does not go away in a few weeks
*   you have lots of blisters, or big, painful blisters
*   you have blisters that keep coming back
*   your skin is hot, swollen and red or a blister is filled with pus or blood

【20】A GP can check what the cause might be.

【21】If they think it could be bullous pemphigoid, they may refer you to a specialist for tests and treatment.

【22】Treatment for bullous pemphigoid
--------------------------------

【23】Bullous pemphigoid eventually goes away on its own, but it can last a few years.

【24】Treatment can help your skin heal, stop new patches or blisters appearing, and reduce the chance of your skin getting infected.

【25】The main treatments are:

【26】*   steroid creams
*   steroid tablets
*   antibiotics

【27】Your skin should eventually heal without scarring, but it might be a bit darker than it was before.

【28】### Important

【29】Do not burst your blisters – your skin might get infected. If a blister is in an annoying place (like the bottom of your foot), your doctor can drain it with a needle.

【30】#### Bullous pemphigoid can be serious

【31】Even with treatment, bullous pemphigoid can sometimes cause serious problems. And it can sometimes be fatal in people with a weakened immune system or pre-existing condition.

【32】The main risks are:

【33】*   skin infections – these can be very serious if they get deeper into your body (sepsis)
*   side effects of steroid treatment – including high blood pressure, weakened bones and a higher chance of getting infections

【34】Steroids will be used as little as possible, and at the lowest possible dose, to help avoid side effects.

【35】Make sure you attend any check-ups your doctor recommends so any problems can be found and treated early.

【36】Causes of bullous pemphigoid
----------------------------

【37】Bullous pemphigoid is caused by a problem with the immune system (the body's defence against infection). Instead of attacking germs, it attacks and damages the skin.

【38】It's not known why this happens. Sometimes it's been linked to skin damage (such as sunburn) or taking certain medicines.

【39】Bullous pemphigoid is not:

【40】*   contagious – it cannot be spread to other people
*   caused by an allergy
*   affected by diet or lifestyle

title: Blood pressure test
text:
【0】Blood pressure test
===================

【1】**A blood pressure test checks if your blood pressure is healthy, or if it's high or low.**

【2】Blood pressure is the term used to describe the strength with which your blood pushes on the sides of your arteries as it's pumped around your body.

【3】Low blood pressure (hypotension) is not usually a problem, although it can cause dizziness and fainting in some people.

【4】High blood pressure (hypertension) can increase your risk of developing serious problems, such as heart attacks and strokes, if it's not treated.

【5】Having this quick test is the only way to find out what your blood pressure is _–_ and it could save your life.

【6】When and where to get your blood pressure tested
------------------------------------------------

【7】You should have a blood pressure test if you're worried about your blood pressure at any time.

【8】If you're over 40, you can have this test done as part of an NHS Health Check, which is offered to adults in England aged 40 to 74 every 5 years.

【9】If you have been diagnosed with high or low blood pressure, or you have a high risk of developing either, you may need more frequent checks of your blood pressure.

【10】You can get your blood pressure tested at a number of places, including:

【11】*   most pharmacies
*   your local GP surgery
*   some workplaces

【12】Information:

【13】### Get a free blood pressure check

【14】If you're aged 40 and over, and are eligible, you may be able to get a free blood pressure check at a local pharmacy.

【15】Find a pharmacy that offers free blood pressure checks

【16】How blood pressure is tested
----------------------------

【17】Blood pressure machines vary, but they're all a type of measuring device, which often have an arm cuff attached to it.

【18】The cuff is usually wrapped around your upper arm and filled with air until it feels tight. This can feel uncomfortable but it only lasts a few seconds.

【19】It's important to relax and not talk during this time, because this is when your blood pressure is measured.

【20】If a healthcare professional is doing this for you, they may also use a stethoscope to record your blood pressure.

【21】An automatic device usually picks up the measurements from sensors in the arm cuff, which are sent to a digital display.

【22】You should get the results straight away.

【23】How blood pressure is measured
------------------------------

【24】Blood pressure is measured in millimetres of mercury (mmHg) and is given as 2 numbers:

【25】*   systolic pressure – the pressure when your heart pushes blood out around your body
*   diastolic pressure – the pressure when your heart rests between beats and blood is pushed around your heart

【26】The highest number is always the systolic pressure and it's always given first. For example, a blood pressure given as "120 over 80" or 120/80mmHg means a systolic pressure of 120mmHg and a diastolic pressure of 80mmHg.

【27】Understanding your blood pressure reading
-----------------------------------------

【28】Your blood pressure reading can tell you how healthy your blood pressure is.

【29】Information:

【30】If you have a recent blood pressure reading use the NHS Check your blood pressure tool to understand what your reading means. You'll also get information about what to do next.

【31】As a general guide:

【32】*   normal blood pressure is considered to be between 90/60mmHg and 120/80mmHg (this applies if it's measured at home or at a pharmacy, GP surgery or clinic)
*   high blood pressure is considered to be 135/85 or higher if your reading was taken at home, or 140/90mmHg or higher if your reading was taken at a pharmacy, GP surgery or clinic
*   low blood pressure is considered to be 89/59mmHg or lower

【33】If your reading is between 120/80mmHg and 140/90mmHg, you may be at risk of developing high blood pressure in the future. There are things you can do to help prevent high blood pressure.

【34】Testing your blood pressure at home
-----------------------------------

【35】Your GP may suggest 24-hour or ambulatory blood pressure monitoring (ABPM) if they think you may have high blood pressure (hypertension).

【36】ABPM tests your blood pressure regularly over 24 hours, by using a cuff attached to a portable device that's worn on your waist.

【37】You can continue with your daily activities during this time.

【38】If you want to regularly check your blood pressure at home, you can buy a machine.

【39】### Blood pressure devices for home use

【40】If you want to check your blood pressure regularly at home, you can buy a digital blood pressure machine.

【41】Choose a machine that measures your blood pressure at your upper arm, not your wrist or finger.

【42】Let your GP know you're doing this.

【43】Information:

【44】Find out more:

【45】*   The British Heart Foundation: How to choose a blood pressure monitor and measure your blood pressure at home
*   Blood Pressure UK: How to measure your blood pressure at home

title: Hand tendon repair
text:
【0】Recovery \- Hand tendon repair
==============================

【1】Contents
--------

【2】1.  Overview
2.  How it's performed
3.  Recovery
4.  Risks

【3】**When you can return home after having hand surgery will depend on how badly your hand was damaged.**

【4】You may be able to go home on the same day, after you have recovered from any anaesthetic and arrangements have been made for your aftercare.

【5】After the operation
-------------------

【6】If you had a general anaesthetic, you'll wake up in the recovery room after your operation. You may have an oxygen mask on your face and feel a bit drowsy.

【7】If you had a regional or local anaesthetic, you'll be able to go back to the ward sooner, but your arm will be numb and floppy for several hours.

【8】It's normal for your hand to be elevated in a sling (a large, supportive bandage) to help reduce swelling.

【9】Following the operation, your hand is likely to be bruised and swollen and, when the anaesthetic wears off, it'll be painful.

【10】You may need to take painkillers, such as ibuprofen, paracetamol or codeine, for up to 2 weeks.

【11】Before leaving hospital, you'll be advised to keep your hand above the level of your heart whenever possible to help reduce swelling.

【12】For example, you may be advised to raise your arm on cushions while seated or to hold your arm up to your other shoulder while standing and walking.

【13】You won't be able to drive for several weeks after the operation, so you'll need to arrange for someone to pick you up and take you home from the hospital.

【14】If you live on your own and had a general anaesthetic, you may be advised to stay in hospital overnight.

【15】You may also need to stay overnight if you need hand therapy in hospital before you go home.

【16】Recovery and rehabilitation
---------------------------

【17】Before you leave hospital, a hand therapist may replace the rigid plaster splint (a support designed to protect the hand) fitted during the operation with a lighter and more flexible plastic one.

【18】This splint will help prevent the repaired tendons being overstretched.

【19】You'll usually be advised to wear the splint at all times for 3 to 6 weeks, possibly followed by just wearing it at night for a further couple of weeks.

【20】Your hand therapist will tell you how to look after your splint and what to do if you develop any problems with it.

【21】It's important to avoid getting the splint wet, so covering it with a plastic bag while having a bath or shower will usually be recommended.

【22】You'll be taught a number of different hand exercises after the operation, either before you leave hospital or at an appointment a few days later.

【23】The exercises will help prevent the repaired tendons getting stuck to surrounding tissue, which would reduce your range of hand movements.

【24】The specific exercises recommended by your hand therapist or surgeon will vary according to the type of tendon repair you had.

【25】If you smoke, it's highly recommended that you stop. Smoking can impair the blood circulation in your hand and delay your recovery time.

【26】Read more about stopping smoking.

【27】Returning to work and activities
--------------------------------

【28】How quickly you can return to work and resume normal daily activities will depend on the nature of your job, as well as the type and location of your injury.

【29】The repaired tendon will usually be back to full strength after about 12 weeks, but it can take up to 6 months to regain the full range of movement.

【30】Some people may never be able to move the affected finger or thumb as much as before it was damaged.

【31】In general, most people are able to:

【32】*   resume light activities, such as using a keyboard or writing with a pen, after 6 to 8 weeks
*   drive a car, motorcycle or heavy goods vehicle (HGV) after 8 to 10 weeks
*   resume medium activities, such as light lifting or shelf stacking, after 8 to 10 weeks
*   resume heavy activities, such as heavy lifting or building work, after 10 to 12 weeks
*   resume sporting activities after 10 to 12 weeks

【33】Your hand therapist or surgeon will be able to give you a more detailed estimate of your likely recovery time.

【34】It's vital that you follow all the instructions and advice given to you regarding the use of your hands during your recovery period.

【35】If you attempt to use the repaired tendons before they have fully healed, it could cause the repair to rupture (break or split).

【36】Take care
---------

【37】After having hand surgery, you should be careful when carrying out everyday activities such as:

【38】*   squeezing toothpaste tubes or shampoo bottles
*   getting out of the bath
*   opening doors
*   getting dressed and undressed, as your hand can catch on your clothing

title: Acute myeloid leukaemia
text:
【0】Complications \- Acute myeloid leukaemia
========================================

【1】Contents
--------

【2】1.  Overview
2.  Symptoms
3.  Causes
4.  Diagnosis
5.  Treatment
6.  Complications

【3】**If you have acute myeloid leukaemia (AML), you may experience complications. These can be caused by the condition itself, although they can also occur as a side effect of treatment.**

【4】Weakened immune system
----------------------

【5】Having a weakened immune system is a common complication of AML.

【6】Even if your blood is restored to normal working order with treatment, many of the medicines that are used to treat AML can temporarily weaken your immune system.

【7】This means you're more vulnerable to developing an infection, and any infection you develop could be more serious than usual.

【8】Complications arising from infection are very common in people with AML. But if treated early, nearly all infections respond to appropriate treatment.

【9】You may be advised to:

【10】*   take regular doses of antibiotics to prevent bacterial infections
*   maintain good personal and dental hygiene
*   avoid contact with anyone who's known to have an infection – even if it's a type of infection that you were previously immune to, such as chickenpox or measles
*   check with your GP to make sure your vaccinations are up-to-date – you will not be able to have any vaccine that contains "live" viruses or bacteria, such as the shingles vaccine and MMR vaccine (against measles, mumps and rubella)

【11】Report any possible symptoms of an infection to your treatment unit immediately as prompt treatment may be needed to prevent complications.

【12】Symptoms of an infection can include:

【13】*   a sore throat
*   a high temperature, and feeling hot or shivery (fever)
*   flu-like symptoms, such as headaches, aching muscles and tiredness
*   breathlessness or a cough
*   pain when peeing

【14】Bleeding
--------

【15】If you have AML, you might bleed and bruise more easily because of the low levels of platelets (clot-forming cells) in your blood. Bleeding may also be excessive.

【16】People with advanced AML are more vulnerable to excessive bleeding inside their body.

【17】Serious bleeding can occur:

【18】*   inside the skull (intracranial haemorrhage) – causing symptoms such as a severe headache, stiff neck, vomiting and confusion
*   inside the lungs (pulmonary haemorrhage) – causing symptoms such as coughing up blood, breathing difficulties and a bluish skin tone (cyanosis)
*   inside the stomach (gastrointestinal haemorrhage) – causing symptoms such as vomiting blood and passing poos that are very dark or tar-like in colour

【19】All these types of haemorrhage should be regarded as medical emergencies.

【20】Dial 999 immediately and ask for an ambulance if you think a haemorrhage is occurring.

【21】Infertility
-----------

【22】Most treatments used to treat AML can cause infertility. This is often temporary, but in some cases can be permanent.

【23】People particularly at risk of permanent infertility are those who have received high doses of chemotherapy and radiotherapy in preparation for a bone marrow or stem cell transplant.

【24】Your treatment team can talk to you about the risk of infertility in your specific circumstances and discuss any fertility options before you begin your treatment.

title: Hand tendon repair
text:
【0】Overview \- Hand tendon repair
==============================

【1】Contents
--------

【2】1.  Overview
2.  How it's performed
3.  Recovery
4.  Risks

【3】**If any of the tendons in your hand are damaged, surgery may be needed to repair them and help restore movement in the affected fingers or thumb.**

【4】What are tendons?
-----------------

【5】Tendons are tough cords of tissue that connect muscles to bones.

【6】When a group of muscles contract (tighten), the attached tendons will pull on certain bones, allowing you to make a wide range of movements.

【7】There are 2 groups of tendons in the hand:

【8】*   **extensor tendons** – which run from the forearm across the back of your hand to your fingers and thumb, allowing you to straighten your fingers and thumb
*   **flexor tendons** – which run from your forearm through your wrist and across the palm of your hand, allowing you to bend your fingers

【9】Surgery can often be used to repair damage to both these groups of tendons.

【10】When hand tendon repair is needed
---------------------------------

【11】Hand tendon repair is needed when 1 or more tendons in your hand rupture (break or split) or are cut, leading to the loss of normal hand movements.

【12】If your extensor tendons are damaged, you'll be unable to straighten 1 or more fingers. If your flexor tendons are damaged, you'll be unable to bend 1 or more fingers.

【13】Tendon damage can also cause pain and swelling (inflammation) in your hand.

【14】Sometimes, damage to the extensor tendons can be treated without the need for surgery, using a rigid support called a splint that's worn around the hand.

【15】Common causes of tendon injuries include:

【16】*   **cuts** – cuts across the back or palm of your hand can result in injury to your tendons
*   **sports injuries** – extensor and flexor tendons can be injured when playing sports like rugby, and the pulleys holding flexor tendons can rupture if you do a lot of strenuous gripping like in rock climbing
*   **animal and human bites** – these type of bites can cause tendon damage, and a person may damage their hand tendon after punching another person in the teeth
*   **crushing injuries** – jamming a finger in a door or crushing a hand in a car accident can divide or rupture a tendon
*   **rheumatoid arthritis** – rheumatoid arthritis can cause tendons to become inflamed which, if severe, can lead to them rupturing

【17】Tendon repair surgery
---------------------

【18】Tendon repair may involve a surgeon making a cut (incision) in your wrist, hand or finger so they can locate the ends of the divided tendon and stitch them together.

【19】Extensor tendons are easier to reach, so repairing them is relatively straightforward.

【20】Read more about how hand tendon repair is performed.

【21】Recovering from surgery
-----------------------

【22】Both types of tendon surgery require a lengthy period of recovery (rehabilitation) because the repaired tendons will be weak until the ends heal together.

【23】Depending on the location of the injury, it can take up to 3 months for the repaired tendon to regain its previous strength.

【24】Rehabilitation involves protecting your tendons from overuse using a hand splint. You'll usually need to wear a hand splint for several weeks after surgery.

【25】You'll also need to perform hand exercises regularly during your recovery to stop the repaired tendons sticking to nearby tissue, which can prevent you being able to fully move your hand.

【26】When you can return to work will depend on your job. Light activities can often be resumed after 6 to 8 weeks, and heavy activities and sport after 10 to 12 weeks.

【27】Read more about recovering from hand tendon repair.

【28】Results
-------

【29】After an extensor tendon repair you should have a working finger or thumb, but you may not regain full movement.

【30】The outcome is often better when the injury is a clean cut to the tendon, rather than one that involves crushing or damage to the bones and joints.

【31】A flexor tendon injury is generally more serious because they're often put under more strain than extensor tendons.

【32】After a flexor tendon repair, it's quite common for some fingers to not regain full movement. But the tendon repair will still give a better result than not having surgery.

【33】Complications can sometimes develop after surgery, such as infection or the repaired tendon snapping or sticking to nearby tissue. In these circumstances, further treatment may be required.

title: Termination for foetal anomaly
text:
【0】Termination for foetal anomaly
==============================

【1】If tests show your baby has a serious anomaly, find out as much as you can from your doctor about the condition and how it might affect your baby.

【2】Hearing the diagnosis can be very shocking and you may find it hard to take in. You may need to go back and talk to the doctor with your partner or someone close to you.

【3】Spend some time thinking things through. The charity Antenatal Results and Choices offers information and support for people who have received a diagnosis after antenatal screening. Its helpline is answered by trained staff:

【4】*   Monday to Friday, 10am to 5.30pm
*   on 020 7713 7486

【5】You may be offered a termination to end the pregnancy. Some couples wish to continue with the pregnancy and prepare for the needs of their newborn baby, while others decide to terminate the pregnancy (have an abortion).

【6】What happens
------------

【7】There are 2 main types of termination:

【8】*   medical termination – taking medicine to end the pregnancy
*   surgical termination – a procedure to remove the pregnancy

【9】You should be offered a choice of which method you would prefer whenever possible.

【10】A medical termination allows for a detailed examination of the baby (post-mortem) that can help find out the exact nature of the baby's abnormalities.

【11】Tests can be done after both a medical and surgical termination to see if the baby was carrying a genetic disorder.

【12】This may help your doctor to determine the chance of a future baby having a similar problem.

【13】Medical termination
-------------------

【14】A medical termination involves taking medicine to end the pregnancy. It doesn't require surgery or an anaesthetic, and can be used at any stage of pregnancy.

【15】It involves the following steps:

【16】1.  Taking a medicine to stop an essential pregnancy hormone. Without this hormone, the pregnancy can't continue.
2.  Usually 24 to 48 hours later, you have another appointment where you take a second medicine – either a tablet that you take by mouth or put inside your vagina. You may need more than 1 dose.
3.  The lining of the womb breaks down, causing bleeding and loss of the pregnancy. This may take several hours.

【17】When a medical termination is carried out after 9 weeks of pregnancy, you're more likely to need to stay overnight in the clinic or hospital.

【18】Occasionally, the pregnancy doesn't pass and a small operation is needed to remove it.

【19】Surgical termination
--------------------

【20】Surgical termination involves having a procedure with either:

【21】*   local anaesthetic (where the area is numbed)
*   conscious sedation (where you're relaxed but awake)
*   general anaesthetic (where you're asleep)

【22】There are 2 methods.

【23】### Vacuum or suction aspiration

【24】This can be used up to 14 weeks of pregnancy. It involves inserting a tube through the entrance to the womb (the cervix). The pregnancy is then removed using suction.

【25】Vacuum aspiration takes 5 to 10 minutes, and you can usually go home a few hours later.

【26】### Dilatation and evacuation (D&E)

【27】This is used from after 14 weeks of pregnancy. It involves inserting special instruments called forceps through the cervix and into the womb to remove the pregnancy.

【28】D&E is usually carried out under sedation or general anaesthetic. It normally takes 10 to 20 minutes, and you might be able to go home the same day.

【29】Seeing and holding your baby
----------------------------

【30】You may wish to think beforehand about whether you want to see and perhaps hold your baby, and whether you want to give your baby a name.

【31】If you don't want to see the baby, you could ask hospital staff to take a photograph for you in case you change your mind in the future. The photograph can be kept in your notes.

【32】Holding your baby or having a photograph is only possible with a medical termination of pregnancy.

【33】Having a funeral
----------------

【34】You may wish to think about having a burial or cremation for your baby. Talk to the doctor or nurse at your hospital about your options.

【35】After a termination
-------------------

【36】It can help to talk. If your family and friends find it difficult to understand what you're going through, you could make contact with people who have had a similar experience. Antenatal Results and Choices can help.

【37】Visit healthtalk.org to watch video interviews with parents talking about their decision to end their pregnancy because of foetal anomaly.

【38】More in Support
---------------

【39】*   Domestic abuse in pregnancy
*   Feelings, relationships and pregnancy
*   Having a baby that might be born with a condition
*   Teenage pregnancy support
*   Termination for foetal anomaly

title: Allopurinol
text:
【0】Common questions about allopurinol \- Brand names: Zyloric, Uricto
==================================================================

【1】How does allopurinol work?

【2】Allopurinol works by reducing the amount of uric acid made by body cells.

【3】If you have gout, it helps prevent uric acid crystals building up in the joints, which makes them swollen and painful.

【4】It is also used to support some cancer treatments. Such treatments kill cancer cells but uric acid is then released from these cells. The build-up of uric acid into crystals can damage the kidneys.

【5】Allopurinol can also help to treat kidney stones, when the waste products in the blood (including uric acid) make crystals that collect inside the kidneys.

【6】Allopurinol reduces the symptoms caused by the build-up of uric acid in these conditions.

【7】When will I feel better?

【8】Allopurinol does not work straight away. It may take several weeks to reduce the level of uric acid. You may have more gout attacks for some time after starting allopurinol.

【9】Are there any long-term side effects?

【10】Allopurinol is considered very safe to take for a long period of time. There are unlikely to be any long-term effects.

【11】What will happen if I stop taking it?

【12】If you stop allopurinol treatment suddenly, there's a high risk that your gout may get worse or you'll get serious side effects.

【13】Only stop taking allopurinol if a doctor tells you to. A doctor will help you to reduce your dose slowly so you do not get serious side effects.

【14】Are there any other medicines for gout?

【15】There are 2 types of medicines used for gout treatment – some stop the gout attack and some prevent further gout attacks.

【16】Medicines that treat an attack of gout include:

【17】*   diclofenac
*   etoricoxib
*   indomethacin
*   ketoprofen
*   naproxen
*   sulindac
*   colchicine
*   steroids
*   canakinuma

【18】Medicines that treat gout long-term in a similar way to allopurinol include:

【19】*   febuxostat
*   sulfinpyrazone
*   benzbromarone

【20】What happens if I take allopurinol when I'm having cancer treatment?

【21】Some cancer treatments can cause an increase in uric acid levels in the blood which can then trigger gout attacks. Allopurinol should be started before these particular cancer treatments to prevent the build-up of uric acid.

【22】However, some cancer treatments can cause changes in the blood which can be made worse if you take allopurinol. Your doctor will monitor you carefully and take blood tests if you are at risk.

【23】What effect does allopurinol have on the kidneys and liver?

【24】It's rare for allopurinol to affect the liver or kidneys.

【25】However, if you have serious problems with your kidneys then you may be at greater risk of an allergic reaction to allopurinol. A doctor may prescribe a lower dose of allopurinol.

【26】Allopurinol can also inflame the liver.

【27】Will it affect my sex life?

【28】Allopurinol is not commonly known to affect sex.

【29】However, rarely it can cause breasts to get larger (in both men and women) or erection problems (erectile dysfunction).

【30】Talk to a doctor if you get any of these symptoms.

【31】Will it affect my contraception?

【32】Allopurinol does not affect any type of contraception including the combined pill or emergency contraception.

【33】But if allopurinol makes you vomit, your contraceptive pills may not protect you from pregnancy. Check the pill packet to find out what to do.

【34】Find out more about what to do if you're taking the pill and you're being sick

【35】Can I drive or ride a bike?

【36】Some people may feel sleepy when taking allopurinol.

【37】Do not drive a car, ride a bike, or operate machinery if allopurinol makes you feel sleepy or unable to concentrate or make decisions. This may be more likely when you first start taking allopurinol, but could happen at any time – for example, when starting another medicine.

【38】It's an offence to drive a car if your ability to drive safely is affected. It's your responsibility to decide if it's safe to drive. If you're in any doubt, do not drive.

【39】Talk to a doctor or pharmacist if you're unsure whether it's safe for you to drive while taking allopurinol. GOV.UK has more information on the law on drugs and driving.

【40】Is there any food and drink I need to avoid?

【41】There are no foods or drink you need to avoid while taking allopurinol. However, drinking alcohol can trigger an attack of gout.

【42】Reducing certain types of food and drink may help to stop gout coming back. It's a good idea not to have too much:

【43】*   red meat, kidneys, liver, or seafood
*   sugary drinks and snacks
*   fatty foods
*   alcohol

【44】Can I drink alcohol while taking allopurinol?

【45】Yes, you can drink alcohol while taking allopurinol. Alcohol does not affect how this medicine works.

【46】However, drinking alcohol increases the level of uric acid in your blood. This can trigger an attack of gout or make it worse.

【47】It's best to stick to the national guidelines of no more than 14 units of alcohol a week. A standard glass of wine (175ml) is 2 units. A pint of lager or beer is usually 2 to 3 units of alcohol.

【48】Can lifestyle changes help gout?

【49】There are lifestyle changes you can make to help stop getting further attacks of gout or reduce the chance of it returning:

【50】*   make sure you're a healthy weight
*   eat well – cut saturated fat and increase fibre, fruits, vegetables, wholegrains and fish
*   quit smoking
*   cut down on alcohol
*   try to exercise every day

【51】More in Allopurinol
-------------------

【52】*   About allopurinol
*   Who can and cannot take it
*   How and when to take it
*   Side effects
*   Pregnancy, breastfeeding and fertility
*   Taking allopurinol with other medicines and herbal supplements

title: Guillain-Barré syndrome
text:
【0】Diagnosis \- Guillain-Barré syndrome
====================================

【1】Contents
--------

【2】1.  Overview
2.  Symptoms
3.  Causes
4.  Diagnosis
5.  Treatment
6.  Recovery

【3】**Guillain-Barré syndrome can be difficult to diagnose because several other conditions can cause similar symptoms.**

【4】A GP will refer you to a hospital specialist if they think you might have it or they are not sure what's causing your symptoms.

【5】Examination
-----------

【6】A GP or specialist may:

【7】*   ask about your symptoms, such as how long they've lasted and whether they're getting worse – muscle weakness that's getting worse over time is a common sign of Guillain-Barré syndrome
*   examine your hands, feet or limbs to check for symptoms such as numbness
*   ask if you've recently been ill – Guillain-Barré syndrome often follows an infection such as food poisoning or flu
*   check your reflexes, such as whether your leg twitches when your knee is tapped in a particular place – people with Guillain-Barré syndrome usually have no or reduced reflexes

【8】Nerve tests
-----------

【9】In hospital, 2 tests may be carried out to see how well your nerves are working.

【10】These are:

【11】*   electromyography (EMG) – tiny needles are inserted into your muscles and electrical recordings are taken to see how they react when nearby nerves are activated
*   nerve conduction studies – small discs (electrodes) are stuck on your skin and minor electric shocks are used to activate the nerves and measure how quickly these signals travel along them

【12】In people with Guillain-Barré syndrome, these tests will usually show that signals are not travelling along the nerves properly.

【13】Lumbar puncture
---------------

【14】A lumbar puncture is a procedure to remove some fluid from around the spinal cord (the nerves running up the spine) using a needle inserted into the lower part of the spine.

【15】The sample of fluid will be checked for signs of problems that can cause similar symptoms to Guillain-Barré syndrome, such as an infection.

title: Hydrocortisone
text:
【0】Hydrocortisone
==============

【1】On this page
------------

【2】1.  About hydrocortisone
2.  Skin problems: hydrocortisone cream, ointment or lotion
3.  Piles and itchy bottom: hydrocortisone cream, ointment or suppositories
4.  Mouth ulcers: hydrocortisone tablets that melt on the inside of your mouth
5.  Painful joints: hydrocortisone injections
6.  Adrenal gland conditions: hydrocortisone tablets

【3】1\. About hydrocortisone
------------------------

【4】Hydrocortisone is a steroid (corticosteroid) medicine.

【5】It works by calming down your body’s immune response to reduce pain, itching and swelling (inflammation).

【6】It can also be used as hormone replacement for people who do not have enough of the natural stress hormone, cortisol.

【7】Hydrocortisone is used to treat many health problems. The medicine comes in different forms, including skin creams for the body and scalp, injections and tablets. The type of hydrocortisone you use will depend on your health problem.

【8】2\. Skin problems: hydrocortisone cream, ointment or lotion
-----------------------------------------------------------

【9】If you're treating a skin problem with hydrocortisone, it will usually be with a cream, ointment or lotion. These can be used for skin problems like:

【10】*   eczema and contact dermatitis (when the skin reacts to something it touches)
*   prickly heat rash
*   reactions to insect bites and stings
*   psoriasis
*   nappy rash

【11】Find out more about hydrocortisone for skin.

【12】3\. Piles and itchy bottom: hydrocortisone cream, ointment or suppositories
---------------------------------------------------------------------------

【13】Hydrocortisone comes as cream, ointment or suppositories specially for inside and around the anus (bottom). It can be used to treat:

【14】*   piles (haemorrhoids)
*   an itchy bottom

【15】Find out more about hydrocortisone treatments for piles and itchy bottom.

【16】4\. Mouth ulcers: hydrocortisone tablets that melt on the inside of your mouth
------------------------------------------------------------------------------

【17】Buccal tablets stick gently to the inside of your mouth and release hydrocortisone as they dissolve. Buccal tablets relieve the pain of mouth ulcers.

【18】Find out more about hydrocortisone buccal tablets.

【19】5\. Painful joints: hydrocortisone injections
---------------------------------------------

【20】Hydrocortisone injections are used to treat swollen and painful joints in people with injuries and arthritis. They help to reduce pain and swelling (inflammation).

【21】Injections are also used to treat painful tendons and bursitis.

【22】Find out more about hydrocortisone injections.

【23】6\. Adrenal gland conditions: hydrocortisone tablets
----------------------------------------------------

【24】You may take hydrocortisone tablets if your body does not make enough cortisol – for example if you have Addison's disease, or if you've had your adrenal glands taken out.

【25】The tablets can also be prescribed for hypopituitarism, a rare condition affecting the pituitary gland.

【26】Find out more about hydrocortisone tablets.

title: Paget's disease of the nipple
text:
【0】Overview \- Paget's disease of the nipple
=========================================

【1】Contents
--------

【2】1.  Overview
2.  Diagnosis
3.  Treatment
4.  Reducing the risk

【3】**Paget's disease of the nipple, also known as Paget's disease of the breast, is a rare condition associated with breast cancer**.

【4】It causes eczema-like changes to the skin of the nipple and the area of darker skin surrounding the nipple (areola). It's usually a sign of breast cancer in the tissue behind the nipple.

【5】About 1 to 4% of women with breast cancer have Paget's disease of the nipple. It can also affect men, but this is extremely rare.

【6】The term Paget's disease of the nipple is used to distinguish the condition from Paget's disease of the bone (where bones become weak and deformed).

【7】Symptoms of Paget's disease of the nipple
-----------------------------------------

【8】Paget's disease of the nipple always starts in the nipple and may extend to the areola. It appears as a red, scaly rash on the skin of the nipple and areola.

【9】The affected skin is often sore and inflamed, and it can be itchy or cause a burning sensation. The nipple can sometimes be ulcerated.

【10】Credit:

【11】CID, ISM /SCIENCE PHOTO LIBRARY https://www.sciencephoto.com/media/459439/view

【12】The rash is often similar in appearance to other skin conditions, such as eczema or psoriasis. If you scratch it, or if it's left untreated, it can bleed, become ulcerated or scab over.

【13】If you're experiencing itchiness, burning or bleeding but the nipple looks normal and is not red or scaly, it's unlikely to be Paget's disease of the nipple. However, you should still have it checked by a doctor.

【14】Around half of all women diagnosed with Paget's disease of the nipple have a lump behind the nipple. In 9 out of 10 cases this is an invasive breast cancer.

【15】Invasive cancer is where cancerous cells invade the surrounding breast tissue. Some women with Paget's disease have invasive breast cancer but do not have a lump.

【16】However, most women with Paget's disease who do not have a lump have non-invasive cancer.

【17】This is where the cancerous cells are contained in 1 or more areas of the breast and have not spread.

【18】Causes of Paget's disease of the nipple
---------------------------------------

【19】The cause of Paget's disease of the nipple is unknown. Some women appear to be more at risk of developing breast cancer, but not specifically Paget's disease. There are no known causes that lead to a specific type of breast cancer.

【20】In terms of risk factors, you're more likely to develop breast cancer if you:

【21】*   are older – the risk of developing breast cancer increases with age
*   have close relatives with breast cancer
*   have had breast cancer before
*   have had a type of benign (non-cancerous) breast disease before – certain types of benign breast disease may be associated with an increased risk of breast cancer, but this is only seen in a very small number of women
*   are overweight or living with obesity, particularly if you've been through the menopause (you can use the BMI calculator to check if you're a healthy weight)
*   drink a lot of alcohol – your risk can increase with the amount of alcohol you drink

【22】Read more about the risk factors for breast cancer.

【23】Diagnosing Paget's disease of the nipple
----------------------------------------

【24】You should see your GP if you notice any changes in the skin of your nipple or areola.

【25】As Paget's disease of the nipple is associated with breast cancer, the sooner it's diagnosed, the better the outcome is likely to be.

【26】Also see your GP if you develop a lump in your breast. Although most breast lumps are not cancerous, it's important to have them checked out.

【27】A biopsy is used to confirm a suspected diagnosis of Paget's disease of the nipple. A small tissue sample (punch biopsy of the skin) will be taken from your nipple and examined under a microscope to see if it's cancerous.

【28】If the results of the biopsy indicate Paget's disease, you'll have a mammogram (a low-dose breast X-ray) to investigate further.

【29】Read more about diagnosing Paget's disease of the nipple.

【30】Treating Paget's disease of the nipple
--------------------------------------

【31】Surgery is the main treatment for Paget's disease of the nipple. Depending on whether the cancer has spread, surgery will either involve removing the whole breast (a mastectomy), or the nipple and areola with the breast tissue underneath them (a central excision).

【32】If the whole of your breast is removed, breast reconstruction surgery can be used to create a breast shape to match your remaining breast.

【33】You may also need further treatment if you have invasive breast cancer. This may be a combination of:

【34】*   chemotherapy – where powerful medicine is used to destroy cancerous cells
*   radiotherapy – where controlled doses of high-energy radiation are used to destroy cancerous cells
*   targeted or hormone therapy – which lowers the risk of cancer returning in the same breast (and affecting the other breast), and it lowers the risk of cancerous cells spreading elsewhere in the body

【35】If Paget's disease is detected and treated in its early stages, there's a good chance of a full recovery.

【36】Read more about treating Paget's disease of the nipple.

【37】Reducing the risk of breast cancer, including Paget's disease of the nipple
---------------------------------------------------------------------------

【38】Modifying certain lifestyle factors, such as reducing the amount of alcohol you drink and making sure you exercise regularly, may reduce your risk of developing certain types of cancer, including breast cancer.

【39】Breast cancer screening is also used to help detect breast cancer early. In the UK, the NHS Breast Screening Programme provides free breast screening every 3 years for all women aged 50 to 70.

【40】In some areas, women aged 47 to 49 and 71 to 73 are also invited for screening as part of a study looking at whether the age range for breast screening should be extended.

【41】Read more about reducing the risks of breast cancer.

title: Adalimumab
text:
【0】About adalimumab
================

【1】How to say adalimumab: AH-dah-lee-mu-mab.

【2】Adalimumab is a biological medicine. This means it's made from proteins or other substances produced by the body. It's used to reduce swelling (inflammation) by acting on your immune system.

【3】Adalimumab is used to treat inflammation of the:

【4】*   joints (rheumatoid arthritis, polyarticular juvenile idiopathic arthritis and active enthesitis-related arthritis)
*   skin (plaque psoriasis and hidradenitis suppurativa)
*   joints and skin (psoriatic arthritis)
*   spine, causing back pain (axial spondyloarthritis and ankylosing spondylitis)
*   gut and ulcers in the lining of the gut (Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis)
*   layer beneath the white of the eyeball (non-infectious uveitis)

【5】Humira is the brand name of the original adalimumab medicine. There are now 5 newer versions of adalimumab, known by the brand names Amgevita, Hyrimoz, Idacio, Imraldi and Yuflyma.

【6】These newer medicines are biosimilars. A biosimilar is a similar version of the original biological medicine. It works in the same way, by blocking part of your immune system to reduce inflammation.

【7】If you switch, your body should respond the same way as if you'd stayed on Humira. You should not notice any difference.

【8】Adalimumab is available on prescription. It comes as a pre-filled syringe or an injection pen that you inject under the skin. If you're switching from Humira to a different brand of adalimumab, the way the injection pen or syringe works might be different.

【9】Key facts
---------

【10】*   Adalimumab is given by an injection under your skin. It works by blocking part of your immune system to reduce inflammation.
*   It takes a few weeks for adalimumab to work. It may take longer depending on your condition.
*   Adalimumab can make you more likely to get infections. Tell your doctor if you get an infection, such as coronavirus (COVID-19), or if you come into contact with anyone who has shingles, chickenpox or measles. These infections can make you very ill.
*   If you need to have a vaccine, ask your doctor or pharmacist whether it's a live vaccine and if there's an alternative inactivated vaccine available. Adalimumab may increase the risk of getting an infection caused by a live vaccine.
*   You might feel dizzy or have blurred vision after taking adalimumab. If you have any of these symptoms, do not drive, cycle or use machinery or tools.
*   When you start taking adalimumab you'll be given a patient alert card. Carry this with you all the time. It tells healthcare professionals that you're taking adalimumab. If you do not have a patient alert card, you can ask your specialist for one.

title: Your body after the birth
text:
【0】Your body after the birth
=========================

【1】**Advice about stitches, piles, bleeding and other physical changes after birth, plus tips to help you make a healthy recovery.**

【2】If you've had a caesarean, see recovering from a caesarean.

【3】Stitches
--------

【4】If you've had stitches after tearing or an episiotomy (cut), bathe them every day to help prevent infection. Have a bath or shower with plain warm water then carefully pat yourself dry.

【5】If your stitches are sore or uncomfortable, tell your midwife.

【6】Painkillers can help. If you're breastfeeding, check with your pharmacist, midwife or GP before you buy over-the-counter painkillers.

【7】Stitches usually dissolve by the time the cut or tear has healed, but sometimes they have to be taken out.

【8】Going to the toilet
-------------------

【9】At first, the thought of peeing can be a bit frightening – because of the soreness. Drinking lots of water dilutes your urine, which may make it sting less.

【10】Tell your midwife if:

【11】*   you're finding it really difficult to pee
*   you feel very sore
*   you notice an unpleasant smell

【12】You probably won't have a poo for a few days after the birth, but it's important not to let yourself get constipated.

【13】Eat plenty of fresh fruit, vegetables, salad, wholegrain cereals and wholemeal bread, and drink plenty of water.

【14】If you've had stitches, it's very unlikely you'll break them, or open up the cut or tear again.

【15】It might feel better if you hold a pad of clean tissue over the stitches when pooing. Try not to strain.

【16】Talk to your midwife or GP if you have constipation that won't go away. A gentle laxative may help.

【17】Also tell your midwife or GP if poo is leaking or you're pooing when you don't mean to.

【18】Bladder control
---------------

【19】After having a baby, it's quite common to leak a bit of pee if you laugh, cough or move suddenly.

【20】Pelvic floor exercises can help with this but tell your GP at your postnatal check if they aren't. They may refer you to a physiotherapist.

【21】Piles
-----

【22】Piles are very common after birth but usually disappear within a few days.

【23】Eat plenty of fresh fruit, vegetables, salad, wholegrain cereals and wholemeal bread, and drink plenty of water. This should make pooing easier and less painful.

【24】Try not to push or strain – this will make the piles worse.

【25】Let your midwife know if you feel very uncomfortable. They can give you a cream to soothe the piles.

【26】Bleeding after birth (lochia)
-----------------------------

【27】You'll bleed from your vagina after the birth. It will be quite heavy at first, and you'll need super-absorbent sanitary towels. Change them regularly, washing your hands before and afterwards.

【28】It isn't a good idea to use tampons until after your 6-week postnatal check because they could increase your chance of getting an infection.

【29】See when you can start using tampons after birth.

【30】You may notice the bleeding is redder and heavier when you breastfeed. This happens because breastfeeding makes your womb contract. You may also feel cramps similar to period pains.

【31】The bleeding will carry on for a few weeks. It will gradually turn a brownish colour and decrease until it finally stops.

【32】If you're losing blood in large clots, tell your midwife. You may need some treatment.

【33】**When will my periods start again after pregnancy?**
-----------------------------------------------------

【34】It's hard to be exact about when your periods will start again, as everyone is different.

【35】If you bottle feed your baby, or combine bottle feeding with breastfeeding, your first period could start as soon as 5 to 6 weeks after you give birth.

【36】If you fully breastfeed (including at night) without any bottle feeding, your periods may not start again until you start to reduce breastfeeding.

【37】How soon after giving birth can I get pregnant?
-----------------------------------------------

【38】You can get pregnant as little as 3 weeks after the birth of your baby, even if you're breastfeeding and your periods have not started again yet.

【39】Find out more about when you can use contraception after having a baby.

【40】**How soon can I use tampons after giving birth?**
--------------------------------------------------

【41】You should not use tampons until you've had your 6-week postnatal check. This is because you'll still have a wound where the placenta joined with the wall of your womb, and you may also have tears or cuts in or around your vagina.

【42】Using internal sanitary products like tampons and menstrual cups before this wound has healed could increase your chance of getting an infection.

【43】Use maternity pads or sanitary towels during this time while your body is still healing.

【44】Breasts
-------

【45】To begin with, your breasts will produce a yellowish liquid called colostrum for your baby.

【46】On the third or fourth day, they may feel tight and tender as they start to produce milk.

【47】Wearing a supportive nursing bra may help. Speak to your midwife if you're very uncomfortable.

【48】Read more about breastfeeding in the first few days.

【49】Tummy
-----

【50】After delivery, your tummy will probably still be a lot bigger than before pregnancy. This is partly because your muscles have stretched.

【51】If you eat a balanced diet and get some exercise, your shape should gradually return.

【52】Breastfeeding helps because it makes your womb contract. You may feel quite painful period-like cramps while you're feeding.

【53】You could also try these gentle postnatal tummy exercises.

【54】Is it something serious?
------------------------

【55】Tell your midwife, health visitor or GP straight away if you get any of these symptoms.

【56】A table listing symptoms of something that might be serious. If you have any of these symptoms you should tell your GP straight away. The symtoms are Pain, swelling or redness in the calf muscle of one leg, Sudden or very heavy blood loss from your vagina, possibly feeling faint, rapid heart beat, high temperature, sore and tender tummy, or Headache, changes in your vision, vomiting.

| Symptoms | What it could be |
| --- | --- |
| Pain, swelling or redness in the calf muscle of one leg | deep vein thrombosis (DVT) |
| Pain in your chest, difficulty breathing | pulmonary embolism |
| Sudden or very heavy blood loss from your vagina, possibly feeling faint, rapid heart beat | postpartum haemorrhage |
| High temperature, sore and tender tummy | infection |
| Headache, changes in your vision, vomiting | pre-eclampsia |

--------------------------------------------------

title: Temazepam
text:
【0】How and when to take temazepam
==============================

【1】Follow your doctor's advice, and the instructions that come with your medicine.

【2】Dosage and strength
-------------------

【3】Temazepam comes as 10mg and 20mg tablets. Temazepam liquid contains 10mg of temazepam in each 5ml.

【4】The usual dose of temazepam for sleep problems is 10mg to 20mg, taken once a day.

【5】In some cases, your doctor may prescribe a higher dose of 30mg to 40mg.

【6】If you're over 65 and at risk of falling over, your dose may be lower.

【7】How to take it
--------------

【8】You'll usually take temazepam once a day, half an hour before bedtime.

【9】It's important to take it exactly as your doctor has told you. Your doctor may recommend taking it only 2 or 3 nights a week.

【10】Take temazepam tablets or liquid with a drink of water. You can take it with or without food.

【11】Liquid temazepam comes with a plastic syringe or spoon to help you take the right amount. If you do not have a syringe or spoon, ask your pharmacist for one. Do not use a kitchen teaspoon as it will not measure the right amount.

【12】How long to take it for
-----------------------

【13】You'll usually only take temazepam for a short time, from a few days to 4 weeks.

【14】If you forget to take it
------------------------

【15】If you forget to take it by bedtime, just skip the missed dose and start again the next night.

【16】If you take too much
--------------------

【17】Taking more than your prescribed dose of temazepam can be dangerous. It can make you very sleepy, and affect your balance and speech. You could have difficulty breathing, especially if you have taken other medicines or alcohol at the same time.

【18】### Urgent advice: Contact 111 for advice now if:

【19】*   you take more than your prescribed dose of temazepam

【20】Go to 111.nhs.uk or call 111

【21】If you need to go to A&E, do not drive yourself. Get someone else to drive you or call for an ambulance.

【22】Take the temazepam packet or the leaflet inside it, plus any remaining medicine, with you.

title: Sodium cromoglicate eye drops
text:
【0】Common questions about sodium cromoglicate eye drops \- Brand names: Allercrom, Catacrom, Murine Hayfever Relief, Opticrom, Optrex
==================================================================================================================================

【1】How do sodium cromoglicate eye drops work?

【2】Sodium cromoglicate eye drops work by stopping the release of the natural substances in your body that can cause an allergic reaction (including histamine). They also reduce how severe your symptoms are when you're exposed to substances which you're allergic to.

【3】How long does it take to work?

【4】Sodium cromoglicate eye drops usually take a few days to start working, and a few weeks to work fully. Tell your doctor if you do not feel any better after using the eye drops for 2 weeks.

【5】Can I use it for a long time?

【6】You can use sodium cromoglicate eye drops for as long as you are in contact with the substance that triggers your allergy (use them during the hay fever season). Talk to your doctor or pharmacist if you think you need to use them for longer than 2 weeks.

【7】But do not use your bottle of eye drops for longer than 4 weeks. If it is open longer than that, throw it away and start a new one.

【8】How effective is it for hay fever?

【9】Sodium cromoglicate eye drops are often used if you keep getting symptoms, or your symptoms last a long time. You need to use them regularly for several weeks for them to work best.

【10】If your symptoms do not get better, speak to your doctor or pharmacist.

【11】How do sodium cromoglicate eye drops compare to similar medicines?

【12】Lodoxamide eye drops work in a similar way to sodium cromoglicate eye drops. There is not enough information to say whether one works better than the other.

【13】Talk to your doctor if you think your medicine is not helping your symptoms.

【14】What will happen if I stop taking it?

【15】If you stop taking sodium cromoglicate eye drops, your symptoms may come back.

【16】Will it affect my contraception?

【17】Sodium cromoglicate eye drops do not affect any type of contraception, including the combined pill and emergency contraception.

【18】Can I drive or ride a bike?

【19】Sodium cromoglicate eye drops can cause blurry vision for a few minutes after using them. If this happens, do not drive, cycle or operate machinery straight away. Wait until your eyes feel OK again and your vision is back to normal.

【20】Can I drink alcohol while using sodium cromoglicate eye drops?

【21】Yes, it is OK to drink alcohol while using these eye drops.

【22】Is there any food or drink I need to avoid?

【23】You can eat and drink normally while using sodium cromoglicate eye drops.

【24】Can lifestyle changes help with hay fever?

【25】It will help if you do not spend too much time outside if the pollen count is high.

【26】### Tips for when you're outside

【27】*   Do not cut grass or walk on grass.
*   Wear wraparound sunglasses to stop pollen getting into your eyes.
*   Put Vaseline around your nostrils to help trap pollen.
*   Shower and change your clothes after you have been outside to wash off pollen.

【28】### Tips for when you're inside

【29】*   Keep windows and doors shut as much as possible.
*   Vacuum regularly and dust with a damp cloth.
*   Do not keep fresh flowers in the house.
*   Do not smoke or be around smoke as it makes hay fever symptoms worse.

title: Doing a pregnancy test
text:
【0】Doing a pregnancy test
======================

【1】If you have missed a period and recently had unprotected sex, you may be pregnant. Pregnancy tests are most reliable from the first day of your missed period.

【2】When you can do a pregnancy test
--------------------------------

【3】You can carry out most pregnancy tests from the first day of a missed period. If you don't know when your next period is due, do the test at least 21 days after you last had unprotected sex.

【4】Some very sensitive pregnancy tests can be used even before you miss a period.

【5】You can do a pregnancy test on a sample of urine collected at any time of the day. It doesn't have to be in the morning.

【6】Where you can get a pregnancy test
----------------------------------

【7】You can buy pregnancy testing kits from pharmacists and some supermarkets. They can give a quick result and you can do the test in private.

【8】The following places provide free pregnancy tests:

【9】*   sexual health services
*   some young people's services – call the national sexual health helpline on 0300 123 7123 for details
*   Brook centres for under-25s – find your nearest Brook centre

【10】You may also be able to get a pregnancy test free of charge from your GP.

【11】How does a pregnancy test work?
-------------------------------

【12】All pregnancy tests detect the hormone human chorionic gonadotrophin (hCG), which starts to be produced around 6 days after fertilisation.

【13】Most pregnancy tests come in a box that contains 1 or 2 long sticks. You pee on the stick and the result appears on the stick after a few minutes. All tests are slightly different, so always check the instructions.

【14】Will a pregnancy test work if I'm on the pill?
----------------------------------------------

【15】Yes.

【16】Some methods of contraception, such as the contraceptive pill, contain hormones, but these hormones will not stop a pregnancy test working.

【17】No method of contraception is completely effective, so it's important to take a pregnancy test if you think you might be pregnant.

【18】Pregnancy test results
----------------------

【19】Home pregnancy tests are accurate as long as you follow the instructions correctly.

【20】A positive test result is almost certainly correct. However, a negative test result is less reliable.

【21】The result may not be reliable if you:

【22】*   do not follow the instructions properly
*   take the test too early

【23】Some medicines can also affect the results.

【24】If you get a negative result and still think you're pregnant, wait a few days and try again. Speak to your GP if you get a negative result after a second test but your period has not arrived.

【25】Continuing with the pregnancy
-----------------------------

【26】If you're pregnant and want to continue with the pregnancy, contact your GP or a midwife to start your antenatal care. You can use the pregnancy due date calculator to work out when your baby is due.

【27】If you're not sure you want to be pregnant
------------------------------------------

【28】If you're not sure about continuing with the pregnancy, you can discuss this confidentially with a healthcare professional. Your options are:

【29】*   continuing with the pregnancy and keeping the baby
*   having an abortion
*   continuing with the pregnancy and having the baby adopted

【30】As well as a GP or a nurse at your GP surgery, you can also get accurate, confidential information – from the age of 13 – from the following:

【31】*   sexual health services
*   the MSI Reproductive Choices website
*   the British Pregnancy Advisory service website
*   the National Unplanned Pregnancy Advisory service website

【32】All these services – including community contraceptive clinics – are confidential. If you're 13 or older, the staff won't tell your parents. They'll encourage you to talk to your parents, but they won't force you. 

【33】If you're under 25 and would prefer advice specifically for young people, the sexual health charity Brook provides a range of services for young people. The Brook website contains information on pregnancy choices. You can also use the Ask Brook 24/7 service.

--------------------------------------

title: MCADD
text:
【0】MCADD
=====

【1】**MCADD is a rare genetic condition where a person has problems breaking down fat to use as an energy source.**

【2】This means that someone with MCADD can become very ill if their body's energy demands exceed their energy intake, such as during infections or vomiting illnesses when they're unable to eat.

【3】Problems occur because fat is only partially broken down, which leads to a lack of energy and a build-up of harmful substances in the body.

【4】MCADD is a lifelong condition that's present from birth. It is usually picked up using the newborn blood spot test.

【5】MCADD stands for medium-chain acyl-CoA dehydrogenase deficiency.

【6】Is MCADD serious?
-----------------

【7】MCADD is a potentially serious condition that can be life-threatening if not recognised quickly and treated appropriately.

【8】However, most cases are picked up soon after birth and can be managed quite easily.

【9】With proper care, there's no reason why someone with MCADD cannot live a normal, healthy and active life.

【10】Symptoms of MCADD
-----------------

【11】Babies with MCADD are at risk of developing the following symptoms:

【12】*   irritability
*   poor feeding
*   sleepiness
*   floppiness
*   breathing difficulties
*   vomiting
*   seizures (fits)
*   coma

【13】If your baby is ill or is not feeding well, they should be given a special high-sugar drink, known as glucose polymer. This is called the emergency regimen.

【14】Families with a child with MCADD are taught how to prepare and give the emergency regimen.

【15】If you see no improvement after giving the emergency regimen, you should take your child to your nearest A&E department immediately.

【16】Take any relevant paperwork about your child's MCADD with you and tell hospital staff your child has MCADD.

【17】It's also helpful to contact your specialist care team to say you are on your way but do not delay going to hospital.

【18】What causes MCADD?
------------------

【19】MCADD is caused by a fault in the gene that provides the instructions to make an enzyme called medium-chain acyl-CoA dehydrogenase (MCAD).

【20】This genetic fault causes the enzyme to either not work properly or be missing entirely, which means the body cannot fully break down fat to release energy.

【21】If the body needs to break down fat quickly (for example, if you're unwell and have not eaten for a while), energy cannot be produced quickly enough to meet the body's needs and substances created when fat is partially broken down can build up to harmful levels in the body.

【22】This can lead to serious problems if not treated quickly.

【23】How MCADD is inherited
----------------------

【24】A child will only be born with MCADD if they inherit a copy of the faulty gene that causes it from both of their parents.

【25】The parents will not normally have the condition themselves because they usually only have one copy of the faulty gene each. This is known as being a "carrier".

【26】If both parents are carriers of the faulty gene, there's a:

【27】*   1 in 4 chance each child they have will not inherit any faulty genes and will not have MCADD or be able to pass it on
*   1 in 2 chance each child they have will just inherit a copy of the faulty gene from one parent and be a carrier
*   1 in 4 chance each child they have will inherit copies of the faulty gene from both parents and will have MCADD

【28】Read more about genetic and genomic testing

【29】Screening and testing for MCADD
-------------------------------

【30】A newborn blood spot test is now offered to all babies in England to earlier help detect problems including MCADD. 

【31】When your baby is 5 to 8 days old, a health professional will prick their heel and collect drops of blood on a special card. The blood is then sent to be checked for abnormalities that could indicate MCADD.

【32】You should receive the results by the time your baby is 6 to 8 weeks old. You'll be contacted sooner if a problem is found so you can attend a hospital appointment to discuss this further.

【33】If your baby has a screen positive result, further urine and blood tests will be carried out to confirm the diagnosis. You, your partner and any other children you have may also be tested to see if you carry the faulty gene that causes MCADD.

【34】If you've previously had a child with MCADD, the newborn blood spot test should be carried out within 24 to 48 hours of birth.

【35】How MCADD is treated
--------------------

【36】There's no specific treatment for MCADD. A specialist care team will give you advice about how to look after your child and support them as they get older.

【37】They will also:

【38】*   arrange regular follow-up appointments
*   provide you with contact details for your specialist care team and written information

【39】Children and adults with MCADD can eat a normal diet, as long as they:

【40】*   **frequently take special high-sugar drinks when they're ill** – this includes common illnesses such as a high temperature, diarrhoea, or vomiting
*   **avoid long periods without eating during the newborn period and infancy even when well** – the length of time your child can go without eating is known as the maximum "safe fasting time" and it varies depending on age; you'll be given advice about this

【41】The high-sugar drinks used for treating MCADD are available on prescription from a GP. You'll be advised by a specialist dietitian about when to use them and how much to use. If the drinks do not help or your child refuses them, they may need to be treated in hospital.

【42】You can find more detailed information about MCADD treatment in the British Inherited Metabolic Diseases Group (BIMDG) MCADD information sheet for parents and carers (PDF, 116kb).

【43】Information about you
---------------------

【44】If you or your child has MCADD, your clinical team will pass information about you or them to the National Congenital Anomaly and Rare Disease Registration Service (NCARDRS).

【45】This helps scientists look for better ways to prevent and treat this condition. You can opt out of the register at any time.

【46】Find out more about the register on GOV.UK

【47】Support groups
--------------

【48】In addition to the support of your care team, you may find it useful to contact a national or local support group for people with MCADD and their families.

【49】One of the main groups in the UK is Metabolic Support UK. You can find information about MCADD on its website and you can speak to their Family Advisers for free on 0845 241 2173.
