title: Henoch-Schönlein purpura (HSP)
text:
【0】Henoch-Schönlein purpura (HSP)
==============================

【1】**Henoch-Schönlein purpura (HSP) affects the blood vessels and causes a spotty rash. It's not usually serious, but can sometimes lead to kidney problems. It's more common in children, but adults can get it too.**

【2】Check if it's Henoch-Schönlein purpura (HSP)
--------------------------------------------

【3】The main symptom of Henoch-Schönlein purpura (HSP) is a rash with raised red or purple spots. The spots look like small bruises or blood spots.

【4】The rash usually appears on the legs, bottom, tummy, chest or back.

【5】Credit:

【6】John Watney/SCIENCE PHOTO LIBRARY https://www.sciencephoto.com/media/618969/view

【7】There may be lots of spots or just a few.

【8】Credit:

【9】DR P. MARAZZI/SCIENCE PHOTO LIBRARY https://www.sciencephoto.com/media/260662/view

【10】You may also have pain or swelling in your joints, such as your knees and ankles. You may also have tummy pain.

【11】Credit:

【12】Don't Forget the Bubbles - Skin Deep: https://dftbskindeep.com/all-diagnoses/henoch-schonlein-purpura/#!jig\[1\]/ML/872

【13】Urgent advice: Ask for an urgent GP appointment or get help from NHS 111 if:
----------------------------------------------------------------------------

【14】*   you or your child have a rash that does not fade when a glass is pressed against it but you do not feel unwell

【15】This could be Henoch-Schönlein purpura (HSP).

【16】You can call 111 or get help from 111 online.

【17】Immediate action required: Call 999 or go to A&E if:
----------------------------------------------------

【18】*   a rash does not fade when a glass is pressed against it and you feel very unwell – for example, it's painful to look at bright lights or you have a stiff neck

【19】This could be something serious like meningitis.

【20】Important: How to do the glass test
-----------------------------------

【21】1.  Press the side of a clear glass firmly against the skin.
2.  Check a few times to see if you can still see the spots through the glass.

【22】If you have brown or black skin, check paler areas like the palms of the hands and the soles of the feet.

【23】See what a rash that does not fade looks like

【24】Credit:

【25】Alamy Stock Photo https://www.alamy.com/testing-of-meningococcal-rash-image589611.html?pv=1&stamp=2&imageid=6C8D2A33-C874-43AF-A58B-398C0D9552AF&p=17774&n=0&orientation=0&pn=1&searchtype=0&IsFromSearch=1&srch=foo%3dbar%26st%3d0%26pn%3d1%26ps%3d100%26sortby%3d2%26resultview%3dsortbyPopular%26npgs%3d0%26qt%3dA8FF2B%26qt\_raw%3dA8FF2B%26lic%3d3%26mr%3d0%26pr%3d0%26ot%3d0%26creative%3d%26ag%3d0%26hc%3d0%26pc%3d%26blackwhite%3d%26cutout%3d%26tbar%3d1%26et%3d0x000000000000000000000%26vp%3d0%26loc%3d0%26imgt%3d0%26dtfr%3d%26dtto%3d%26size%3d0xFF%26archive%3d1%26groupid%3d%26pseudoid%3d195878%26a%3d%26cdid%3d%26cdsrt%3d%26name%3d%26qn%3d%26apalib%3d%26apalic%3d%26lightbox%3d%26gname%3d%26gtype%3d%26xstx%3d0%26simid%3d%26saveQry%3d%26editorial%3d1%26nu%3d%26t%3d%26edoptin%3d%26customgeoip%3d%26cap%3d1%26cbstore%3d1%26vd%3d0%26lb%3d%26fi%3d2%26edrf%3d0%26ispremium%3d1%26flip%3d0%26pl%3d

【26】Treatments for Henoch-Schönlein purpura (HSP)
---------------------------------------------

【27】There's no treatment for Henoch-Schönlein purpura (HSP). It usually gets better in a few weeks and you can usually just rest at home until you feel better.

【28】HSP cannot spread to others, so:

【29】*   your child can return to school or nursery when they feel well enough
*   you can go back to work as soon as you feel up to it

【30】### Treatment to relieve your symptoms

【31】Paracetamol can help ease any pain.

【32】Do not take ibuprofen without speaking to your doctor because it could harm your kidneys.

【33】### Regular check-ups for kidney problems

【34】You'll have regular check-ups for 6 to 12 months to check how well your kidneys are working.

【35】You'll usually be asked to provide a sample of pee and have your blood pressure checked at each appointment. This may be done at home, at your GP surgery, or in hospital.

【36】### Treatment in hospital

【37】You may need to go into hospital if HSP affects your kidneys.

【38】In hospital, you may be given strong medicines like steroids to help ease your symptoms.

【39】Risks of Henoch-Schönlein purpura (HSP)
---------------------------------------

【40】Most people with Henoch-Schönlein purpura (HSP) make a full recovery. Any kidney problems usually get better without treatment.

【41】But sometimes HSP can be severe and last several months.

【42】There's also a small chance the kidneys could be permanently damaged (chronic kidney disease). This is why it's important to have regular check-ups.

【43】### Important: Getting HSP again

【44】You can get HSP more than once. Get medical advice quickly if the symptoms come back.

title: Dosulepin
text:
【0】Side effects of dosulepin
=========================

【1】Like all medicines, dosulepin can cause side effects, but many people have no side effects or only minor ones.

【2】Common side effects
-------------------

【3】These common side effects of dosulepin happen in more than 1 in 100 people. There are things you can do to help cope with them:

【4】Constipation

【5】Eat more high-fibre foods, such as fresh fruit and vegetables and cereals. Try to have several glasses of water, or other non-alcoholic drinks, every day. If you can, it may also help to do some exercise.

【6】Feeling dizzy

【7】This is probably because of low blood pressure (hypotension). Drink plenty of water or non-alcoholic drinks. Do not stand up too quickly after sitting or lying down.

【8】Dry mouth

【9】Chew sugar-free gum or suck sugar-free sweets.

【10】Feeling sleepy or tired

【11】Take dosulepin in the evening and try to cut down the amount of alcohol you drink. Do not drive or use tools or machinery if you're feeling sleepy. If this does not help, talk to your doctor.

【12】Difficulty peeing

【13】Relax when you try to pee. Do not try to force the flow of urine. If you cannot go, try again later. Talk to your doctor, urgently, if you cannot pee at all.

【14】Headaches

【15】Make sure you rest and drink plenty of fluids. Try not to drink too much alcohol. Talk to your doctor if the headaches last longer than a week or are severe.

【16】Blurred vision

【17】Do not drive, cycle or operate machinery if this happens to you. This may improve as your body gets used to the medicine, but if it does not get better after 1 week, talk to your doctor as they may need to prescribe a different medicine.

【18】If this advice does not help and any of these side effects continue, tell your doctor or pharmacist.

【19】Serious side effects
--------------------

【20】Serious side effects after taking dosulepin are rare but there are some risks. There is an increased risk of heart problems.

【21】Call your doctor call 111 now if:

【22】*   your heart is beating faster or in an irregular way
*   the whites of your eyes turn yellow, or your skin turns yellow although this may be less obvious on brown or black skin – this can be a sign of liver problems
*   you have constant headaches, long-lasting confusion or weakness, or frequent muscle cramps – these can all be signs of low sodium levels in your blood
*   you get eye pain, a change in your eyesight, or swelling or redness in or around the eye
*   you have severe constipation or you're unable to pee

【23】### Immediate action required: Call 999 or go to A&E if:

【24】*   you have thoughts about harming yourself or ending your life

【25】### Immediate action required: Call 999 now if you get:

【26】*   weakness on one side of your body
*   trouble speaking or thinking
*   loss of balance, or blurred eyesight

【27】These can be signs of a stroke.

【28】### Serious allergic reaction

【29】In rare cases, it's possible to have a serious allergic reaction (anaphylaxis) to dosulepin.

【30】#### Immediate action required: Call 999 now if:

【31】*   your lips, mouth, throat or tongue suddenly become swollen
*   you're breathing very fast or struggling to breathe (you may become very wheezy or feel like you're choking or gasping for air)
*   your throat feels tight or you're struggling to swallow
*   your skin, tongue or lips turn blue, grey or pale (if you have black or brown skin, this may be easier to see on the palms of your hands or soles of your feet)
*   you suddenly become very confused, drowsy or dizzy
*   someone faints and cannot be woken up
*   a child is limp, floppy or not responding like they normally do (their head may fall to the side, backwards or forwards, or they may find it difficult to lift their head or focus on your face)

【32】You or the person who's unwell may also have a rash that's swollen, raised, itchy, blistered or peeling.

【33】These can be signs of a serious allergic reaction and may need immediate treatment in hospital.

【34】Other side effects
------------------

【35】These are not all the side effects of dosulepin. For a full list, see the leaflet inside your medicine packet.

【36】Information:

【37】You can report any suspected side effect using the Yellow Card safety scheme.

【38】Visit Yellow Card for further information.

【39】More in Dosulepin
-----------------

【40】*   About dosulepin

*   How and when to take it
*   Side effects
*   Pregnancy, breastfeeding and fertility

title: You and your baby at 32 weeks pregnant
text:
【0】You and your baby at 32 weeks pregnant
======================================

【1】Your baby at 32 weeks
---------------------

【2】By about 32 weeks, the baby is usually lying with their head pointing downwards, ready for birth. This is known as cephalic presentation.

【3】If your baby is not lying head down at this stage, it's not a cause for concern – there's still time for them to turn.

【4】The amount of amniotic fluid in your uterus is increasing, and your baby is still swallowing fluid and passing it out as urine.

【5】You at 32 weeks
---------------

【6】Being active and fit during pregnancy will help you adapt to your changing shape and weight gain. It can also help you cope with labour and get back into shape after the birth.

【7】Find out about exercise in pregnancy.

【8】You may develop pelvic pain in pregnancy. This is not harmful to your baby, but it can cause severe pain and make it difficult for you to get around.

【9】Find out about ways to tackle pelvic pain in pregnancy.

【10】Read about the benefits of breastfeeding for you and your baby. It's never too early to start thinking about how you're going to feed your baby, and you do not have to make up your mind until your baby is born.

【11】Things to think about
---------------------

【12】*   how you might feel after the birth

【13】Start4Life has more about you and your baby at 32 weeks pregnant.

title: Radiotherapy
text:
【0】Side effects \- Radiotherapy
============================

【1】Contents
--------

【2】1.  Overview
2.  What happens
3.  Side effects

【3】**Radiotherapy can cause side effects, although many of these can be treated or prevented and most will go away after the treatment stops.**

【4】It's difficult to predict what side effects you'll get and in some cases you may only develop side effects months, or even years, after you start treatment.

【5】Side effects vary from person to person and depend on things such as the part of your body being treated and the type of radiotherapy you have. Ask your care team about the side effects you might get.

【6】Sore skin
---------

【7】In some people, radiotherapy can make your skin sore, change colour (it might become red, lighter or darker than your normal skin tone), or dry and itchy. Sometimes it can blister and peel.

【8】This tends to start 1 to 2 weeks after treatment begins.

【9】Tell your care team if you notice any soreness or changes to your skin.

【10】To care for your skin during radiotherapy you should:

【11】*   wash your skin every day with your usual soap
*   pat your skin dry instead of rubbing it
*   apply your usual moisturiser every day, or start using a moisturiser
*   use your usual deodorant, unless it irritates your skin
*   avoid shaving the area if possible and do not use laser, wax, or hair-removal creams
*   avoid using heat or cold packs on the area
*   try wearing loose-fitting clothes made from natural fibres such as cotton or silk, and avoid tight bands, ties or straps on the sore area
*   use a high-factor sunscreen (SPF 50 or above) to protect your skin from the sun and continue to use it for at least a year after treatment ends
*   check with your care team if you should stop swimming – chlorine in the water can sometimes make your skin worse when you're having radiotherapy
*   stop using any products on your skin if your skin breaks

【12】Skin problems usually settle within 2 to 4 weeks of treatment finishing, but sometimes your skin might stay slightly darker or lighter than it was before.

【13】Tiredness
---------

【14】Many people having radiotherapy feel tired (fatigued) a lot of the time or become tired very easily from doing everyday activities.

【15】This usually starts during treatment and can continue for several weeks or months after treatment finishes.

【16】It can help to:

【17】*   get plenty of rest
*   avoid doing tasks or activities that you do not feel up to
*   do light exercise, such as going for short walks, if you're able to – this can boost your energy level, but be careful not to push yourself too hard
*   ask your friends and family for help with everyday tasks

【18】If you're working, you may want to ask your employer for time off or to let you work part-time until your treatment has finished.

【19】Read more tips to help fight tiredness.

【20】Contact your care team if you suddenly feel very tired and out of breath. This can be a sign of a lack of red blood cells (anaemia), which may need to be treated.

【21】Hair loss
---------

【22】Hair loss is a common side effect of radiotherapy. But unlike hair loss during chemotherapy, it only causes hair loss in the area being treated.

【23】Ask your care team to show you exactly where your hair is likely to fall out.

【24】Your hair will usually start to fall out 2 to 3 weeks after treatment starts.

【25】It should start to grow back a few weeks after treatment finishes, although sometimes it may be a slightly different texture or colour than it was before.

【26】Occasionally, hair loss can be permanent if you have a high dose of radiotherapy. Ask your doctor if this is a risk before starting treatment.

【27】### Coping with hair loss

【28】Hair loss can be upsetting. Talk to your care team if you find losing your hair difficult to cope with.

【29】They understand how distressing it can be and can support you and discuss your options with you.

【30】You may decide you want to wear a wig if you lose the hair on your head. Synthetic wigs are available free of charge on the NHS for some people, but you'll usually have to pay for a wig made from real hair.

【31】Other options include headwear such as headscarves.

【32】Read advice about cancer and hair loss.

【33】Feeling sick
------------

【34】Some people feel sick during, or for a short time after, radiotherapy treatment sessions.

【35】This is more likely to happen if the treatment area is near your stomach, or if your brain is being treated.

【36】Tell your care team if you feel sick during or after treatment. They can prescribe anti-sickness medicine to help.

【37】You should stop feeling sick soon after your treatment finishes.

【38】Macmillan has more information about managing sickness and vomiting.

【39】Problems eating and drinking
----------------------------

【40】Radiotherapy can sometimes cause:

【41】*   a sore mouth
*   loss of appetite and weight loss
*   discomfort when swallowing

【42】### Sore mouth

【43】Radiotherapy to your head or neck can make the lining of your mouth sore and irritated. This is known as mucositis.

【44】Symptoms tend to happen within a couple of weeks of treatment starting and can include:

【45】*   the inside of your mouth feeling sore – as if you have burned it by eating very hot food or drink
*   mouth ulcers, which can become infected
*   discomfort when eating, drinking and/or talking
*   a dry mouth
*   reduced sense of taste
*   bad breath

【46】Tell your care team if you have any of these problems. They may recommend painkillers or a special mouthwash that can help. Avoiding spicy, salty or sharp foods can also help.

【47】Mucositis usually gets better a few weeks after treatment finishes, although sometimes a dry mouth can be a long-term problem.

【48】### Loss of appetite

【49】Feeling sick and tired during radiotherapy can make you lose your appetite, which could lead to weight loss. You may also find that your sense of taste changes, which can also affect appetite.

【50】But it's important to try to eat healthily and maintain your weight during treatment. Tell your care team if you do not feel you're eating enough.

【51】They may give you tips, such as eating frequent small meals instead of 3 large meals, or refer you to a dietitian.

【52】### Discomfort when swallowing

【53】Radiotherapy to your chest, head, neck or oesophagus (gullet or food pipe) can make swallowing uncomfortable.

【54】Tell your care team if this affects you, as you may need to make some changes to your diet, such as eating soft or liquid foods.

【55】You may also be prescribed medicine to reduce the discomfort and in a few cases you may need a temporary feeding tube.

【56】Read more about treatments for swallowing problems.

【57】Swallowing problems usually improve after treatment stops.

【58】Diarrhoea
---------

【59】Diarrhoea is a common side effect of radiotherapy to the tummy or pelvic area.

【60】It usually starts a few days after treatment begins and may get a bit worse as treatment continues.

【61】Tell your care team if you get diarrhoea. Medicine is available to help relieve it.

【62】Diarrhoea should disappear within a few weeks of treatment finishing. Tell your doctor if your symptoms have not improved after a few weeks, or if you notice blood in your poo.

【63】Stiff joints and muscles
------------------------

【64】Radiotherapy can sometimes make your joints and muscles in the area being treated feel stiff, swollen and uncomfortable.

【65】Exercising and stretching regularly can help to prevent stiffness.

【66】Tell your care team if joint or muscle stiffness a problem. They may refer you to a physiotherapist, who can recommend exercises for you to try.

【67】Sex and fertility issues
------------------------

【68】Radiotherapy can have an effect on your sex life and fertility, especially if your lower tummy, pelvic area or groin is treated.

【69】Ask your care team if there's a chance it could affect you.

【70】### Sex and fertility issues for women

【71】In women, there's a risk that radiotherapy could cause:

【72】*   loss of interest in sex (loss of libido) – this tends to gradually improve after treatment stops
*   stiffening and narrowing of the vagina – your care team may suggest using vaginal dilators (devices you insert into your vagina) to prevent this; having sex regularly may also help
*   vaginal dryness – lubricants, vaginal moisturisers and medicated creams can help with this
*   the menopause – this can cause symptoms such as hot flushes and night sweats, but treatment with hormone replacement therapy (HRT) can help
*   infertility – if there's a risk this could happen, it may be possible to store some of your eggs before treatment

【73】Cancer Research UK has more information about women's sex life and fertility after radiotherapy.

【74】### Sex and fertility issues for men

【75】In men, there's a risk that radiotherapy could cause:

【76】*   loss of interest in sex (loss of libido) – this tends to gradually improve after treatment stops
*   difficulty getting an erection (erectile dysfunction) – this tends to improve with time and there are several erectile dysfunction treatments available
*   pain when ejaculating – this should pass a few weeks after the treatment ends
*   infertility – if there's a risk this could happen, it may be possible to store a sample of your sperm before treatment

【77】Cancer Research UK has more information about men's sex life and fertility after radiotherapy.

【78】Emotional issues
----------------

【79】Having radiotherapy can be a frustrating, stressful and traumatic experience. It's natural to feel anxious and to wonder if your treatment will be successful.

【80】Stress and anxiety can also increase your risk of depression.

【81】Speak to your care team if you're struggling to cope emotionally. They can offer support and discuss possible treatment strategies.

【82】Joining a cancer support group may also help. Talking to other people in a similar situation can often reduce feelings of isolation and stress.

【83】The cancer support charity Macmillan Cancer Support has a directory of support groups. You can also call the free Macmillan support line: 0808 808 00 00 (every day, 8am to 8pm).

【84】Lymphoedema
-----------

【85】Radiotherapy can damage your body's lymphatic system, which is a network of channels and glands that form part of your immune system (the body's defence against illness).

【86】One of the jobs of the lymphatic system is to stop fluid building up in your body. If it becomes damaged, you may experience pain and swelling. This is known as lymphoedema.

【87】It's most common in the arms or legs, but it can affect other areas, depending on the part of your body that was treated.

【88】It may be possible to reduce your risk of lymphoedema by looking after your skin and doing regular exercises. Ask your care team if you're at risk and what you can do to help avoid it.

【89】If you do get it, treatment for lymphoedema can often help keep the symptoms under control.

【90】Getting another type of cancer
------------------------------

【91】Radiotherapy can slightly increase your risk of developing another type of cancer in the years after treatment.

【92】But the chance of this happening is small, and the benefits of treatment generally outweigh the risk.

title: Epilepsy
text:
【0】Overview \- Epilepsy
====================

【1】Contents
--------

【2】1.  Overview
2.  Symptoms
3.  Diagnosis
4.  Treatment
5.  Living with

【3】**Epilepsy is a common condition that affects the brain and causes frequent seizures.**

【4】Seizures are bursts of electrical activity in the brain that temporarily affect how it works. They can cause a wide range of symptoms.

【5】Epilepsy can start at any age, but usually starts either in childhood or in people over 60.

【6】It's often lifelong, but can sometimes get slowly better over time.

【7】Symptoms of epilepsy
--------------------

【8】Seizures can affect people in different ways, depending on which part of the brain is involved.

【9】Possible symptoms include:

【10】*   uncontrollable jerking and shaking, called a "fit"
*   losing awareness and staring blankly into space
*   becoming stiff
*   strange sensations, such as a "rising" feeling in the tummy, unusual smells or tastes, and a tingling feeling in your arms or legs
*   collapsing

【11】Sometimes you might pass out and not remember what happened.

【12】When to get medical help
------------------------

【13】See a GP if you think you might have had a seizure for the first time.

【14】This does not mean you have epilepsy, as a seizure can have several causes and sometimes they're just a one-off, but you should see a doctor to find out why it happened.

【15】Find out more about the tests for epilepsy you might have 

【16】Call 999 for an ambulance if someone:

【17】*   is having a seizure for the first time
*   has a seizure that lasts more than 5 minutes
*   has lots of seizures in a row
*   has breathing problems or has seriously injured themselves

【18】Find out what to do if someone has a seizure

【19】Treatments for epilepsy
-----------------------

【20】Treatment can help most people with epilepsy have fewer seizures or stop having seizures completely.

【21】Treatments include:

【22】*   medicines called anti-epileptic drugs – these are the main treatment
*   surgery to remove a small part of the brain that's causing the seizures
*   a procedure to put a small electrical device inside the body that can help control seizures
*   a special diet (ketogenic diet) that can help control seizures

【23】Some people need treatment for life. But you might be able to stop treatment if your seizures disappear over time.

【24】Living with epilepsy
--------------------

【25】Epilepsy is usually a lifelong condition, but most people with it are able to have normal lives if their seizures are well controlled.

【26】Most children with epilepsy are able to go to a mainstream school, take part in most activities and sports, and get a job when they're older.

【27】But you may have to think about your epilepsy before you do things such as driving, certain jobs, swimming, using contraception and planning a pregnancy.

【28】Advice is available from a GP or support groups to help you adjust to life with epilepsy.

【29】Find out more about living with epilepsy

【30】Causes of epilepsy
------------------

【31】In epilepsy, the electrical signals in the brain become scrambled and there are sometimes sudden bursts of electrical activity. This is what causes seizures.

【32】In most cases, it's not clear why this happens. It's possible it could be partly caused by your genes affecting how your brain works, as around 1 in 3 people with epilepsy have a family member with it.

【33】Occasionally, epilepsy can be caused by damage to the brain, such as damage from:

【34】*   a stroke
*   a brain tumour
*   a severe head injury
*   drug abuse or alcohol misuse
*   a brain infection
*   a lack of oxygen during birth

title: Compartment syndrome
text:
【0】Compartment syndrome
====================

【1】**Compartment syndrome is an increase in pressure inside a muscle, which restricts blood flow and causes pain. If it happens suddenly, it can be serious and need treatment as soon as possible.**

【2】Check if you have compartment syndrome
--------------------------------------

【3】You can get compartment syndrome in any muscle, but it most often affects the muscles in the lower legs and forearms.

【4】Symptoms include:

【5】*   pain in a muscle – this may feel like a burning pain or a deep ache (moving the body part can make the pain even worse)
*   swelling or bulging of the muscle
*   numbness, weakness or pins and needles
*   tightness or difficulty moving the affected body part

【6】The symptoms can start suddenly, such as after an injury or if a bandage or plaster cast is too tight. This is called acute compartment syndrome.

【7】Symptoms can also come on gradually after exercising and go away when you rest. This is called chronic compartment syndrome.

【8】Immediate action required: Call 999 or go to A&E if:
----------------------------------------------------

【9】*   you have sudden, severe pain in any part of your body

【10】If compartment syndrome is causing the pain, you’ll need surgery to treat it as soon as possible.

【11】Find your nearest A&E

【12】What we mean by severe pain

【13】Severe pain:

【14】*   always there and so bad it's hard to think or talk
*   you cannot sleep
*   it's very hard to move, get out of bed, go to the bathroom, wash or dress

【15】Moderate pain:

【16】*   always there
*   makes it hard to concentrate or sleep
*   you can manage to get up, wash or dress

【17】Mild pain:

【18】*   comes and goes
*   is annoying but does not stop you doing daily activities

【19】Non-urgent advice: See a GP if:
-------------------------------

【20】*   you keep getting pain, numbness, swelling, or have difficulty moving a part of your body when you exercise

【21】A GP can help find out if the pain is caused by compartment syndrome or another condition.

【22】Tests for compartment syndrome
------------------------------

【23】If the GP thinks you may have compartment syndrome, you may be referred to a specialist for tests.

【24】Tests you may have include:

【25】*   an X-ray to check if you’ve broken a bone
*   MRI scans while you’re resting and while you’re exercising
*   compartment pressure measurement – a needle connected to a pressure monitoring device is inserted into your muscle before and after exercise to measure the pressure inside it

【26】Measuring the pressure inside a muscle is usually only recommended if your symptoms and other test results suggest compartment syndrome.

【27】Treatments for compartment syndrome
-----------------------------------

【28】Treatment for compartment syndrome depends on whether it happens suddenly or comes on gradually.

【29】### Sudden (acute) compartment syndrome

【30】If compartment syndrome happens suddenly, you’ll need surgery as soon as possible to relieve the pressure in the muscle.

【31】This type of surgery is called a fasciotomy. During a fasciotomy, the surgeon makes cuts around the muscle to relieve the pressure.

【32】Sometimes, skin may need to be removed from another part of the body and used to cover the wound. This is known as a skin graft.

【33】After the operation, you’ll have medicine to help ease any pain. You may also need physiotherapy to help regain full movement in the affected part of your body.

【34】### Gradual (chronic) compartment syndrome

【35】Treatment is often not needed for compartment syndrome that develops gradually.

【36】To help relieve your symptoms you can:

【37】*   avoid the activity that caused them – if you run, switching to a low-impact exercise, such as cycling, may help
*   use anti-inflammatory painkillers to reduce the pain and discomfort
*   have physiotherapy
*   use inserts (orthotics) in your shoes if you start running again

【38】If your symptoms do not improve after trying these things, surgery may be an option. The operation is similar to the one used to treat acute compartment syndrome.

title: Ulcerative colitis
text:
【0】Treatment \- Ulcerative colitis
===============================

【1】Contents
--------

【2】1.  Overview
2.  Causes
3.  Diagnosis
4.  Treatment
5.  Living with
6.  Complications

【3】**Treatment for ulcerative colitis depends on how severe the condition is and how often your symptoms flare-up.**

【4】The main aims of treatment are to:

【5】*   reduce symptoms, known as inducing remission (a period without symptoms)
*   maintain remission

【6】This usually involves taking various types of medicine, although surgery may sometimes be an option.

【7】Your treatment will normally be provided by a range of healthcare professionals, including:

【8】*   specialist doctors, such as gastroenterologists or surgeons
*   GPs
*   specialist nurses

【9】Your care will often be co-ordinated by your specialist nurse and your care team, and they'll usually be your main point of contact if you need help and advice.

【10】Aminosalicylates
----------------

【11】Aminosalicylates, also known as 5-ASAs, are medicines that help to reduce inflammation. This in turn allows damaged tissue to heal.

【12】They're usually the first treatment option for mild or moderate ulcerative colitis.

【13】5-ASAs can be used as a short-term treatment for flare-ups. They can also be taken long term, usually for the rest of your life, to maintain remission.

【14】5-ASAs can be taken:

【15】*   orally – by swallowing a tablet or capsule
*   as a suppository – a capsule that you insert into your bottom (rectum), where it dissolves
*   through an enema – where fluid is pumped into your large intestine

【16】How you take 5-ASAs depends on the severity and extent of your condition.

【17】If you have mild-to-moderate ulcerative colitis, you'll usually be offered a 5-ASA to take in suppository or enema form.

【18】If your symptoms do not improve after 4 weeks, you may be advised to take 5-ASA in tablet or capsule form as well.

【19】These medicines rarely have side effects, but some people may experience:

【20】*   headaches
*   feeling sick
*   tummy pain
*   a rash
*   diarrhoea

【21】Corticosteroids
---------------

【22】Corticosteroids, such as prednisolone, are an alternative type of medicine used to reduce inflammation.

【23】They can be used with or instead of 5-ASAs to treat a flare-up if 5-ASAs alone are not effective.

【24】Like 5-ASAs, steroids can be administered orally, or through a suppository or enema.

【25】But unlike 5-ASAs, corticosteroids are not used as a long-term treatment to maintain remission because they can cause potentially serious side effects, such as weakening of the bones (osteoporosis) and cloudy patches in the lens of the eye (cataracts), when used for a long time.

【26】Side effects of short-term steroid use can include:

【27】*   acne
*   weight gain
*   increased appetite
*   mood changes, such as becoming more irritable
*   difficulty sleeping (insomnia)

【28】Find out more about the side effects of corticosteroids

【29】Immunosuppressants
------------------

【30】Immunosuppressants, such as tacrolimus and azathioprine, are medicines that reduce the activity of the immune system.

【31】They're usually given as tablets to treat mild or moderate flare-ups, or maintain remission if your symptoms have not responded to other medicines.

【32】Immunosuppressants can be very effective in treating ulcerative colitis, but they may take a while to start working.

【33】The medicines can make you more vulnerable to infection, so it's important to report any signs of infection, such as a high temperature or sickness, promptly to a GP.

【34】They can also lower the production of red blood cells, making you prone to anaemia.

【35】You'll need regular blood tests to monitor your blood cell levels and check for any other problems.

【36】Treating severe flare-ups
-------------------------

【37】While mild or moderate flare-ups can usually be treated at home, more severe flare-ups should be managed in hospital to minimise the risk of dehydration and potentially fatal complications, such as your colon rupturing.

【38】In hospital, you'll be given medicine and sometimes fluids directly into a vein (intravenously).

【39】The medicines you have may be a type of corticosteroid or an immunosuppressant medicine called infliximab or ciclosporin.

【40】### Ciclosporin

【41】Ciclosporin is given slowly through a drip in your arm (an infusion) and treatment will usually be continuous, for around 7 days.

【42】Side effects of intravenous ciclosporin can include:

【43】*   an uncontrollable shaking or trembling of part of the body (a tremor)
*   excessive hair growth
*   extreme tiredness (fatigue)
*   swollen gums
*   feeling and being sick
*   diarrhoea

【44】Ciclosporin can also cause high blood pressure and reduced kidney and liver function, but you'll be monitored regularly during treatment to check for signs of these.

【45】### Biologic medicines

【46】Biologic medicines are medicines that reduce inflammation of the intestine by targeting proteins the immune system uses to stimulate inflammation.

【47】These medicines block these receptors and reduce inflammation.

【48】They may be used to treat moderate to severe ulcerative colitis if other options are not suitable or not working.

【49】Biologic medicines are given in hospital as an infusion through a drip in your arm every 4 to 12 weeks, or as an injection every 1 to 4 weeks.

【50】Your treatment team will then see how you respond to treatment. If your symptoms are under control (remission) for a year or more, they may recommend treatment is stopped.

【51】Biologic medicines affect your immune system and can increase your risk of getting infections. Talk to a GP if you have any symptoms of a possible infection, such as coughs, a high temperature or a sore throat.

【52】Find out more about biologic medicines from Crohn's & Colitis UK

【53】### JAK inhibitors

【54】There are now new types of medicines called JAK inhibitors, such as tofacitinib and filgotinib, that can be used to treat ulcerative colitis.

【55】These work by blocking enzymes (proteins) that the immune system uses to trigger inflammation.

【56】JAK inhibitors can be taken as tablets.

【57】JAK inhibitors may be recommended for people with moderate to severe ulcerative colitis if standard treatments or biologics have not worked, or are not suitable.

【58】JAK inhibitors are not recommended for use in pregnancy. Women should use reliable contraception when taking them, for at least 4 weeks after finishing the course.

【59】### Ozanimod

【60】A medicine called ozanimod may be recommended for people with moderate to severe ulcerative colitis if standard treatments or biologic medicines have not worked or are not suitable.

【61】It comes as tablets that you take once a day. You'll usually take it long term. You'll have regular checks with your treatment team to see if it's working well for you.

【62】Ozanimod affects your immune system and can increase your risk of getting infections. Talk to a GP if you have any symptoms of a possible infection, such as coughs, a high temperature or a sore throat.

【63】Find out more about ozanimod from Crohn's & Colitis UK

【64】Surgery
-------

【65】If you have frequent flare-ups that have a significant effect on your quality of life, or you have a particularly severe flare-up that's not responding to medicines, surgery may be an option.

【66】Surgery for ulcerative colitis involves permanently removing the colon (a colectomy).

【67】Once your colon is removed, your small intestine will be used to pass waste products out of your body instead of your colon.

【68】This can be achieved by creating:

【69】*   an ileostomy – where the small intestine is diverted out of a hole made in your tummy; special bags are placed over this opening to collect waste materials after the operation
*   an ileoanal pouch (also known as a J-pouch) – where part of the small intestine is used to create an internal pouch that's then connected to your anus, allowing you to poo normally

【70】As the colon is removed, ulcerative colitis cannot come back again after surgery.

【71】But it's important to consider the risks of surgery and the impact of having a permanent ileostomy or ileoanal pouch.

【72】Your healthcare team will discuss the best option with you.

【73】Find out more about ileostomies

【74】Help and support
----------------

【75】Living with a condition like ulcerative colitis, especially if your symptoms are severe, can be a frustrating and isolating experience.

【76】Talking to others with the condition can provide support and comfort.

【77】Crohn's & Colitis UK provides information on where you can find help and support

Next review due: 01 November 2025

title: Patau's syndrome
text:
【0】Patau's syndrome
================

【1】**Patau's syndrome is a serious, rare genetic disorder caused by having an additional copy of chromosome 13 in some or all of the body's cells. It's also called trisomy 13.**

【2】Each cell normally contains 23 pairs of chromosomes, which carry the genes you inherit from your parents. 

【3】But a baby with Patau's syndrome has 3 copies of chromosome 13, instead of 2.

【4】This severely disrupts normal development and, in many cases, results in miscarriage, stillbirth or the baby dying shortly after birth.

【5】Babies with Patau's syndrome grow slowly in the womb and have a low birth weight, along with a number of other serious medical problems.

【6】Patau's syndrome affects about 1 in every 4,000 births. The risk of having a baby with the syndrome increases with the mother's age.

【7】More than 9 out of 10 children born with Patau's syndrome die during the first year.

【8】Symptoms and features
---------------------

【9】Babies with Patau's syndrome can have a wide range of health problems.

【10】Their growth in the womb is often restricted, resulting in a low birth weight, and 8 out of 10 will be born with severe heart defects.

【11】The brain often does not divide into 2 halves. This is known as holoprosencephaly.

【12】When this happens, it can affect facial features and cause defects such as:

【13】*   cleft lip and palate
*   an abnormally small eye or eyes (microphthalmia)
*   absence of 1 or both eyes (anophthalmia)

【14】Other abnormalities of the face and head include:

【15】*   smaller than normal head size (microcephaly)
*   ear malformations and deafness

【16】Patau's syndrome can also cause other problems, such as:

【17】*   an abdominal wall defect where the abdomen does not develop fully in the womb, resulting in the intestines being outside the body, covered only by a membrane – this is known as an exomphalos or omphalocoele
*   abnormal cysts in the kidneys

【18】There may also be abnormalities of the hands and feet, such as extra fingers or toes (polydactyly) and a rounded bottom to the feet, known as rocker-bottom feet.

【19】Causes of Patau's syndrome
--------------------------

【20】Patau's syndrome happens by chance and is not caused by anything the parents have done.

【21】Most cases do not run in families (they're not inherited). They happen randomly during conception, when the sperm and egg combine and the foetus starts to develop.

【22】There's an error when the cells divide, resulting in an additional copy, or part of a copy, of chromosome 13, which severely affects the baby's development in the womb.

【23】In many cases, the baby dies before reaching full term (miscarriage) or is dead at birth (stillbirth).

【24】In most cases of Patau's syndrome, a baby has a whole extra copy of chromosome number 13 in their body's cells. This is sometimes known as trisomy 13 or simple trisomy 13.

【25】In some cases of Patau's syndrome, genetic material is rearranged between chromosome 13 and another chromosome. This is called a chromosomal translocation. Patau's syndrome that arises because of this can be inherited.

【26】Sometimes only some cells have the extra copy of chromosome 13. This is known as trisomy 13 mosaicism. Occasionally, only part of 1 chromosome 13 is extra (partial trisomy 13).

【27】The symptoms and features of both mosaicism and partial trisomy tend to be less severe than in simple trisomy 13, resulting in more babies living longer.

【28】Genetic Alliance UK has more information about chromosome disorders

【29】Screening for Patau's syndrome
------------------------------

【30】You'll be offered a screening test for Patau's syndrome, as well as Down's syndrome (trisomy 21) and Edwards' syndrome (trisomy 18), from 10 to 14 weeks of pregnancy.

【31】The test assesses your chances of having a baby with these syndromes.

【32】The screening test offered at 10 to 14 weeks of pregnancy is called the combined test because it involves a blood test and an ultrasound scan.

【33】If the screening tests show you have a higher chance of having a baby with Patau's syndrome, you'll be offered a second screening test called non-invasive prenatal testing (NIPT).

【34】This is a blood test that can give you a more accurate screening result and help you to decide whether to have a diagnostic test or not. It's available free on the NHS.

【35】A diagnostic test will check the chromosomes in a sample of cells taken from your baby and helps to find out for certain if they have Patau's syndrome.

【36】Two techniques can be used to obtain the cell sample: amniocentesis or chorionic villus sampling (CVS). 

【37】These are invasive tests to remove a sample of tissue or fluid so it can be tested for the presence of the extra copy of chromosome 13.

【38】If you're not able to have the combined screening test, you'll be offered a scan that looks for physical abnormalities, including those found in Patau's syndrome.

【39】This is sometimes called the mid-pregnancy scan and is carried out when you're between 18 and 21 weeks pregnant.

【40】Find out more about screening tests for Down's syndrome, Edwards' syndrome and Patau's syndrome

【41】Treating and managing Patau's syndrome
--------------------------------------

【42】There's no specific treatment for Patau's syndrome. As a result of the severe health problems a newborn baby with the syndrome will have, doctors usually focus on minimising discomfort and ensuring the baby is able to feed.

【43】For the small number of babies with Patau's syndrome who survive beyond the first few days of life, their care will depend on their specific symptoms and needs.

【44】If your baby is diagnosed with Patau's syndrome, either before birth or shortly afterwards, you'll be offered counselling and support.

【45】Genetic testing for parents
---------------------------

【46】Both parents will need to have their chromosomes analysed if their baby is affected by Patau's syndrome caused by a chromosomal translocation.

【47】Genetic testing is carried out to help parents plan for future pregnancies, rather than as part of the decision-making process for the current pregnancy.

【48】The test results will allow a more accurate assessment to be made of the likelihood of the syndrome affecting future pregnancies.

【49】Other family members may also be affected and should be tested.

【50】Find out more about genetic and genomic testing

【51】### Information about your child

【52】If your child has Patau's syndrome, your clinical team will pass information about him or her on to the National Congenital Anomaly and Rare Disease Registration Service (NCARDRS).

【53】This helps scientists look for better ways to prevent and treat this condition. You can opt out of the register at any time.

【54】Find out more about the National Congenital Anomaly and Rare Disease Registration Service on GOV.UK

【55】Further information and support
-------------------------------

【56】These organisations are useful further sources of information about Patau's syndrome.

【57】They can also provide advice and support:

【58】*   Contact
*   Genetic Alliance UK
*   Support Organisation for Trisomy 13/18 (SOFT UK)

Next review due: 18 July 2026

title: Paxlovid
text:
【0】Taking Paxlovid with other medicines and herbal supplements
===========================================================

【1】If you are taking ritonavir as part of your treatment for HIV or hepatitis C infection, you can continue taking your treatment as usual.

【2】Cautions with other medicines
-----------------------------

【3】Some medicines do not mix well with Paxlovid. Tell your doctor if you're taking:

【4】*   medicines such as methylphenidate or dexamfetamine for attention deficit hyperactivity disorders (ADHD)
*   painkillers such as morphine, fentanyl, methadone, pethidine, buprenorphine or other medicines similar to morphine
*   medicines for heart conditions and irregular heartbeats such as digoxin, amiodarone, flecainide or ranolazine
*   cancer treatments such as afatinib, abemaciclib, apalutamide, ceritinib, dasatinib, nilotinib, vincristine, vinblastine, encorafenib, fostamatinib, ibrutinib or venetoclax
*   medicines used to prevent blood clots (anticoagulants) such as warfarin, apixaban, dabigatran or rivaroxaban
*   carbamazepine, lamotrigine or phenytoin, used for epilepsy
*   medicines for depression or anxiety such as amitriptyline, fluoxetine, imipramine, nortriptyline, paroxetine or sertraline
*   allergy medicines, such as fexofenadine or loratadine
*   antibiotics (antibacterials) such as rifabutin, rifampicin, erythromycin, fusidic acid, atovaquone, bedaquiline, delamanid, clarithromycin or sulfamethoxazole/trimethoprim
*   antifungals such as ketoconazole, voriconazole or itraconazole
*   medicines for HIV or AIDS such as amprenavir, atazanavir, darunavir, fosamprenavir, efavirenz, maraviroc, raltegravir or zidovudine
*   medicines for mental health or mood disorders, such as clozapine, pimozide, haloperidol, risperidone, quetiapine or lurasidone
*   medicines for asthma and other lung-related problems such as chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), such as salmeterol or theophylline
*   medicines for high blood pressure (hypertension) such as amlodipine, diltiazem or nifedipine
*   medicines for high blood pressure in the blood vessels that supply the lungs, such as bosentan or riociguat
*   medicines for hepatitis C virus infection such as glecaprevir/pibrentasvir
*   medicines used to lower cholesterol such as atorvastatin, simvastatin, fluvastatin, pravastatin, rosuvastatin or lomitapide
*   medicines used to suppress your immune system such as ciclosporin, tacrolimus or everolimus
*   medicines for erectile dysfunction (also known as impotence) such as sildenafil, tadalafil, avanafil or vardenafil
*   medicines used as sedatives or to help sleep such as alprazolam, buspirone, clonazepam, flurazepam, midazolam or zolpidem
*   steroids used to treat inflammation, such as budesonide, dexamethasone, fluticasone propionate, prednisolone or triamcinolone
*   bupropion for smoking cessation
*   oral or patch contraceptives containing ethinylestradiol
*   levothyroxine for underactive thyroid gland (hypothyroidism)
*   colchicine for gout
*   alfuzosin for prostate problems
*   cisapride for stomach problems

【5】Paxlovid and COVID-19 vaccines
------------------------------

【6】There is no evidence that Paxlovid affects the COVID-19 vaccine.

【7】COVID-19 treatments do not replace vaccinations. Vaccines are given to help your immune system fight a future COVID-19 infection.

【8】The COVID-19 vaccine is not recommended within 4 weeks of having COVID-19.

【9】**Mixing Paxlovid with herbal remedies and supplements**
--------------------------------------------------------

【10】Do not take St John's wort, the herbal remedy for depression, while you are being treated with Paxlovid. This is because it may make your course of treatment less effective.

【11】There is not enough information to say that other herbal remedies or supplements are safe to take with Paxlovid. They are not tested in the same way as pharmacy and prescription medicines. They're generally not tested for the effect they have on other medicines.

【12】Important: Medicine safety
--------------------------

【13】Tell your doctor or pharmacist if you're taking any other medicines, including herbal remedies, vitamins or supplements.

7.  Complications
8.  Prevention

【3】**If a heart attack is suspected, you should be admitted to hospital immediately. You will usually be admitted to an acute cardiac care unit (ACCU), or directly to the cardiac catheterisation unit, to confirm the diagnosis and begin treatment.**

【4】Electrocardiogram
-----------------

【5】An electrocardiogram (ECG) is an important test in suspected heart attacks. It should be done within 10 minutes of being admitted to hospital.

【6】An ECG measures the electrical activity of your heart. Every time your heart beats, it produces tiny electrical impulses. An ECG machine records these signals onto paper, allowing your doctor to see how well your heart is functioning.

【7】An ECG is painless and takes about 5 minutes to do. During the test, flat metal discs (electrodes) are attached to your arms, legs and chest. Wires from the electrodes are connected to the ECG machine, which records the electrical impulses.

【8】An ECG is important because:

【9】*   it helps confirm the diagnosis of a heart attack
*   it helps determine what type of heart attack you have had, which will help determine the most effective treatment

【10】**Blood tests**
---------------

【11】Damage to your heart from a heart attack causes certain proteins to slowly leak into your blood.

【12】If doctors suspect you have had a heart attack, a sample of your blood will be taken so it can be tested for these heart proteins (known as cardiac markers).

【13】The most common protein measurement is called cardiac troponin. Your troponin level can help in diagnosing the type of heart attack you've had.

【14】Types of heart attack
---------------------

【15】Heart attacks can be classified by a measurement from an ECG known as the ST segment, and the level of heart protein (troponin) in the blood.

【16】### Acute coronary syndrome

【17】A heart attack is a form of acute coronary syndrome (ACS), where there is a significant blockage in the coronary arteries.

【18】The 3 main types of ACS include:

【19】*   ST segment elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI)
*   non-ST segment elevation myocardial infarction (NSTEMI)
*   unstable angina

【20】### ST segment elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI)

【21】A STEMI is a type of heart attack where there is a long interruption to the blood supply. This can cause extensive damage to the heart. It's diagnosed when specific changes show on an ECG.

【22】It needs urgent treatment to unblock the artery.

【23】### Non-ST segment elevation myocardial infarction (NSTEMI)

【24】An NSTEMI is another type of heart attack where there is some loss of blood supply, causing damage.

【25】It's diagnosed when an ECG does not show the type of changes seen in a STEMI, but blood tests show that the heart is damaged.

【26】An NSTEMI is a medical emergency. Without treatment, it can progress to a STEMI.

【27】### Unstable angina

【28】In unstable angina, you have symptoms of a heart attack but tests do not show damage to the heart.

【29】The blood supply to the heart is still seriously restricted, and you are at high risk of a heart attack.

【30】Other tests
-----------

【31】Other tests can be used to assess the state of your heart and check for related complications. However, because heart attacks are medical emergencies, some of these tests are usually done after your initial treatment has begun and your condition has been stabilised.

【32】### Chest X-ray

【33】A chest X-ray can be useful if diagnosis of a heart attack is uncertain and there are other possible causes of your symptoms, such as a pocket of air trapped between the layers of your lungs (pneumothorax).

【34】A chest X-ray can also be used to check whether complications have happened because of the heart attack, such as a build-up of fluid inside your lungs (pulmonary oedema).

【35】### Echocardiogram

【36】An echocardiogram is a type of scan that uses sound waves to build a picture of the inside of your heart.

【37】This can be useful to identify exactly which areas of the heart have been damaged and how this damage has affected your heart's function.

【38】### Coronary angiography

【39】Coronary angiography can help determine whether there is a blockage or narrowing in the coronary arteries and, if so, to locate the exact place of the blockage or narrowing.

【40】The test involves inserting a thin tube (catheter), into one of the blood vessels in your groin or arm. The catheter is guided into your coronary arteries using X-rays.

【41】A special fluid, called a contrast agent, is pumped through the catheter. This fluid can be seen on X-rays and studying how it flows around and through your heart can help locate the site of any blockage or narrowing. This helps a doctor who specialises in heart conditions (cardiologist) decide the best treatment for you.

【42】Find out more about treating a heart attack.

text:
【0】Incontinence (urinary), see Urinary incontinence
Incontinence products \- Urinary incontinence
=============================================

【1】Contents
--------

【2】1.  Overview
2.  Symptoms
3.  Causes
4.  Diagnosis
5.  Non-surgical treatment
6.  Surgery and procedures
7.  Incontinence products
8.  10 ways to stop leaks

【3】**Incontinence pads and other products and devices can make life easier for you if you're waiting for a diagnosis or for a treatment to work.**

【4】A wide range of products and devices are available for urinary incontinence.

【5】They include:

【6】*   pads and pants
*   bed and chair protection
*   catheters and penile sheaths
*   skincare and hygiene products
*   specially adapted clothing and swimwear

【7】Pads and pull-up pants
----------------------

【8】The most popular incontinence products are absorbent pads that are worn inside underwear to soak up urine.

【9】Pads and pull-up pants use the same technology as babies' nappies and have a "hydrophobic" layer which draws urine away from the surface of the product, so your skin stays dry.

【10】If you have mild to moderate incontinence you can buy thin, discreet pads or pull-up pants for men and women from many supermarkets and pharmacies.

【11】For people with severe leaks, continence clinics and district nurses can supply incontinence pads on the NHS, but these tend to be big and bulky.

【12】Using tampons for stress incontinence
-------------------------------------

【13】Placing a tampon in your vagina puts pressure on the neck of your bladder to stop leaks on exertion. However, do not regularly use super-size tampons to prevent sudden leaks if you have stress incontinence.

【14】The National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) does not recommend using tampons for the routine management of urinary incontinence in women.

【15】However, tampons can be used occasionally, when necessary, to prevent leaks. For example, during exercise.

【16】Appliances and bedding
----------------------

【17】Other useful incontinence products for more severe leaks include urinals (devices that collect urine), or sheaths and drainage systems (if you have a penis).

【18】A variety of incontinence bedding is also available, such as washable bed pads that sit on top of the mattress and soak up any overnight leaks. The pads stay dry to the touch and they can be useful for trips away from home.

【19】Can I get incontinence products on the NHS?
-------------------------------------------

【20】You may be able to get incontinence products on the NHS depending on your local integrated care board (ICB). Ask your GP for details of your local continence service. To qualify for NHS products you may need to be assessed by a healthcare professional.

【21】Where to buy incontinence products
----------------------------------

【22】The charity Bladder & Bowel UK gives independent advice on products that can help manage bladder and bowel problems.

【23】For more information on products and how to order them, call its helpline on 0161 214 4591 or visit the Bladder & Bowel UK website.

【24】The Continence Product Advisor gives independent and evidence-based advice on how to choose and use suitable incontinence products.

title: Pain relief in labour
text:
【0】Pain relief in labour
=====================

【1】Your pain relief options
------------------------

【2】Labour can be painful – it can help to learn about all the ways you can relieve the pain.

【3】It's also helpful for whoever is going to be with you during your labour to know about the different options, as well as how they can support you. 

【4】Ask your midwife or doctor to explain what's available so you can decide what's best for you.

【5】Write down your wishes in your birth plan, but remember you need to keep an open mind. You may find you want more pain relief than you'd planned, or your doctor or midwife may suggest more effective pain relief to help the delivery.

【6】Self-help in labour
-------------------

【7】You're likely to feel more relaxed in labour and better placed to cope with the pain if you: 

【8】*   learn about labour – this can make you feel more in control and less frightened about what's going to happen; talk to your midwife or doctor, ask them questions, and go to antenatal classes
*   learn how to relax, stay calm and breathe deeply
*   keep moving – your position can make a difference, so try kneeling, walking around, or rocking backwards and forwards
*   bring a partner, friend or relative to support you during labour, but do not worry if you do not have a partner – your midwife will give you all the support you need
*   ask your partner to massage you – although you may find you do not want to be touched
*   have a bath
*   take paracetamol, which can help relieve some of the pain in the early stages of labour

【9】Gas and air (Entonox) for labour
--------------------------------

【10】This is a mixture of oxygen and nitrous oxide gas. Gas and air will not remove all the pain, but it can help reduce it and make it more bearable. It's easy to use and you control it yourself.

【11】You breathe in the gas and air through a mask or mouthpiece, which you hold yourself. The gas takes about 15 to 20 seconds to work, so you breathe it in just as a contraction begins. It works best if you take slow, deep breaths.

【12】### Side effects

【13】*   there are no harmful side effects for you or the baby
*   it can make you feel lightheaded, sick, sleepy or unable to concentrate, but if this happens you can stop using it

【14】If gas and air does not give you enough pain relief, you can ask for a painkilling injection as well.

【15】Pethidine injections in labour
------------------------------

【16】This is an injection of a medicine called pethidine into your thigh or buttock to relieve pain. It can also help you to relax. Sometimes, less commonly, a medicine called diamorphine is used.

【17】It takes about 20 minutes to work after the injection. The effects last between 2 and 4 hours, so would not be recommended if you're getting close to the pushing (second) stage of labour.

【18】### Side effects

【19】There are some side effects of pethidine and diamorphine to be aware of:

【20】*   it can make you feel woozy, sick and forgetful
*   if pethidine or diamorphine are given too close to the time of delivery, they may affect the baby's breathing – if this happens, another medicine to reverse the effect will be given
*   these medicines can interfere with the baby's first feed

【21】Epidural
--------

【22】An epidural is a type of local anaesthetic. It numbs the nerves that carry the pain impulses from the birth canal to the brain. It should not make you sick or drowsy.

【23】In most cases, an epidural gives complete pain relief. It can be helpful if you are having a long or particularly painful labour.

【24】An anaesthetist is the only person who can give an epidural, so it will not be available at home. If you think you might want one, check whether anaesthetists are always available at your hospital.

【25】How much you can move your legs after an epidural depends on the local anaesthetic used. Some hospitals offer "mobile" epidurals, which means you can walk around.

【26】However, this also requires the baby's heart rate to be monitored remotely (by telemetry) and many hospitals do not have the equipment to do this. Ask your midwife if mobile epidural is available in your local hospital.

【27】An epidural can provide very good pain relief, but it's not always completely effective in labour.

【28】### How does an epidural work?

【29】To have an epidural:

【30】*   a drip will run fluid through a needle into a vein in your arm
*   while you lie on your side or sit up in a curled position, an anaesthetist will clean your back with antiseptic, numb a small area with some local anaesthetic, and then introduce a needle into your back
*   a very thin tube will be passed through the needle into your back near the nerves that carry pain impulses from the womb (uterus). Medicines (usually a mixture of local anaesthetic and opioid) are administered through this tube. It takes about 10 minutes to set up the epidural, and another 10 to15 minutes for it to work. It does not always work perfectly at first and may need adjusting
*   the epidural can be topped up by your midwife, or you may be able to top it up yourself through a machine
*   your contractions and the baby's heart rate will need to be continuously monitored. This means having a belt around your abdomen and possibly a clip attached to the baby's head

【31】### Side effects of epidurals in labour

【32】There are some side effects of epidurals to be aware of.

【33】An epidural may make your legs feel heavy, depending on the local anaesthetic used.

【34】Your blood pressure can drop (hypotension), but this is rare because the fluid given through the drip in your arm helps to maintain good blood pressure.

【35】Epidurals can prolong the second stage of labour. If you can no longer feel your contractions, the midwife will have to tell you when to push. This means that forceps or a ventouse may be needed to help deliver the baby (instrumental delivery).

【36】When you have an epidural, your midwife or doctor will wait longer for the baby's head to come down (before you start pushing), as long as the baby is showing no signs of distress. This reduces the chance you'll need an instrumental delivery. Sometimes less anaesthetic is given towards the end, so the effect wears off and you can feel to push the baby out naturally.

【37】You may find it difficult to pee as a result of the epidural. If so, a small tube called a catheter may be put into your bladder to help you.

【38】You may get a headache after an epidural. This happens in about 1 in 100 cases and can be treated.

【39】Your back might be a bit sore for a day or two, but epidurals do not cause long-term backache.

【40】You may feel tingles or pins and needles down one leg after having a baby. This happens in about 1 in 2,000 cases. This is more likely to be the result of childbirth itself rather than the epidural. You'll be advised by the doctor or midwife when you can get out of bed.

【41】Remifentanil
------------

【42】Remifentanil goes into a vein in your arm. You control it yourself by pushing a button.

【43】It works quickly and wears off after a few minutes. You can use it up until your baby is born.

【44】You’ll need a small clip on your finger to measure your oxygen levels, as remifentanil can make you feel breathless or need oxygen.

【45】### Side effects

【46】Remifentanil can make you feel sleepy, sick, dizzy or itchy. These stop once you stop taking the medicine.

【47】Like pethidine, remifentanil can affect the baby’s breathing but this usually wears off quickly.

【48】Using water in labour (water birth)
-----------------------------------

【49】Being in water can help you relax and make the contractions seem less painful. Ask if you can have a bath or use a birth pool. The water will be kept at a comfortable temperature, but not above 37.5C, and your temperature will be monitored.

【50】Find out more about using water during labour and birth on the National Childbirth Trust website

【51】TENS machines
-------------

【52】TENS stands for transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation. Some hospitals have TENS machines. If not, you can hire your own machine.

【53】TENS has not been shown to be effective during the active phase of labour, when contractions get longer, stronger and more frequent. It's probably most effective during the early stages, when you may have lower back pain.

【54】TENS may also be useful while you're at home in the early stages of labour or if you plan to give birth at home. If you're interested in TENS, learn how to use it in the later months of your pregnancy. Ask your midwife to show you how it works.

【55】### How TENS machines work

【56】Electrodes are taped on to your back and connected by wires to a small battery-powered stimulator. Holding this, you give yourself small, safe amounts of current through the electrodes. You can move around while you use TENS.  

【57】TENS is believed to work by stimulating the body to produce more of its own natural painkillers, called endorphins. It also reduces the number of pain signals sent to the brain by the spinal cord.

【58】### Side effects of TENS machines

【59】There are no known side effects of TENS for either you or the baby.

【60】Read more about TENS

【61】Alternative methods of labour pain relief
-----------------------------------------

【62】You may choose alternative treatments such as acupuncture, aromatherapy, homeopathy, hypnosis, massage and reflexology. Most of these techniques are not proven to provide effective pain relief.

【63】If you'd like to use any of these methods, it's important to discuss them with your midwife or doctor and let the hospital know beforehand. Most hospitals do not offer them for pain relief during labour.

【64】If you want to try any of these techniques, make sure the practitioner is properly trained and experienced. 

【65】Learn more about complementary and alternative medicines and how they're regulated

【66】Find maternity services near you

title: Sitagliptin
text:
【0】Side effects of sitagliptin
===========================

【1】Like all medicines, sitagliptin can cause side effects in some people. But many people have no side effects, or only minor ones.

【2】Common side effects
-------------------

【3】The most common side effect of sitagliptin, which happens in more than 1 in 100 people, is headaches.

【4】Talk to your doctor if headaches last longer than a week or are severe.

【5】If taking sitagliptin gives you a headache, make sure you rest and drink plenty of fluids. Do not drink too much alcohol.

【6】Ask your pharmacist to recommend a painkiller.

【7】Low blood sugar
---------------

【8】Sitagliptin does not usually cause low blood sugar (known as hypoglycaemia, or "hypos") when taken on its own.

【9】But hypos can happen when you take sitagliptin with other diabetes medicines, such as insulin or gliclazide.

【10】Early warning signs of low blood sugar include:

【11】*   feeling hungry
*   trembling or shaking
*   sweating
*   confusion
*   difficulty concentrating

【12】It's also possible for your blood sugar to go too low while you're asleep. If this happens, it can make you feel sweaty, tired and confused when you wake up.

【13】Low blood sugar may happen if you:

【14】*   take too much of some types of diabetes medicines
*   eat meals irregularly or skip meals
*   are fasting
*   do not eat a healthy diet and are not getting enough nutrients
*   change what you eat
*   increase your physical activity without eating more to compensate
*   drink alcohol, especially after skipping a meal
*   take some other medicines or herbal remedies at the same time
*   have a hormone disorder, such as an underactive thyroid (hypothyroidism)
*   have kidney or liver problems

【15】It's important to have regular meals, including breakfast, to prevent hypoglycaemia. Never miss or delay a meal.

【16】If you're planning to exercise more than usual, make sure you eat carbohydrates like bread, pasta or cereals before, during or after exercise.

【17】Always carry a fast-acting carbohydrate with you, like sugar cubes, fruit juice or some sweets, in case your blood sugar level gets low. Artificial sweeteners will not help.

【18】You may also need to eat a starchy carbohydrate, like a sandwich or a biscuit, to maintain your blood sugar for longer.

【19】If taking in sugar does not help or the hypo symptoms come back, contact your doctor or the nearest hospital.

【20】Make sure your friends and family know about your diabetes and the symptoms of low blood sugar levels so they can recognise a hypo if it happens.

【21】Serious side effects
--------------------

【22】It happens rarely, but some people may have serious side effects after taking sitagliptin.

【23】Call your doctor or call 111 straight away if:

【24】*   you get severe stomach pains – this may be a sign of pancreatitis
*   the whites of your eyes turn yellow, or your skin turns yellow although this may be less obvious on brown or black skin – this can be a sign of liver problems

【25】### Serious allergic reaction

【26】It's possible to have a serious allergic reaction (anaphylaxis) to sitagliptin.

【27】#### Immediate action required: Call 999 now if:

【28】*   your lips, mouth, throat or tongue suddenly become swollen
*   you're breathing very fast or struggling to breathe (you may become very wheezy or feel like you're choking or gasping for air)
*   your throat feels tight or you're struggling to swallow
*   your skin, tongue or lips turn blue, grey or pale (if you have black or brown skin, this may be easier to see on the palms of your hands or soles of your feet)
*   you suddenly become very confused, drowsy or dizzy
*   someone faints and cannot be woken up
*   a child is limp, floppy or not responding like they normally do (their head may fall to the side, backwards or forwards, or they may find it difficult to lift their head or focus on your face)

【29】You or the person who's unwell may also have a rash that's swollen, raised, itchy, blistered or peeling.

【30】These can be signs of a serious allergic reaction and may need immediate treatment in hospital.

【31】**Other side effects**
----------------------

【32】These are not all the side effects of sitagliptin. For a full list, see the leaflet inside your medicines packet.

【33】Information:

【34】You can report any suspected side effect using the Yellow Card safety scheme.

【35】Visit Yellow Card for further information.

title: Mebeverine
text:
【0】About mebeverine \- Brand names: Colofac, Colofac IBS, Aurobeverine
===================================================================

【1】Mebeverine (sometimes called mebeverine hydrochloride) is a type of medicine known as an antispasmodic. It helps with muscle spasms.

【2】It can be used to ease painful stomach cramps if you have irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) or other conditions. It works by relaxing certain muscles in your gut.

【3】Mebeverine comes as tablets or slow-release capsules (also called modified release).

【4】It's available on prescription. You can also buy mebeverine tablets for IBS symptoms at a pharmacy.

【5】Mebeverine is also available mixed with a laxative called ispaghula husk (brand name Fybogel Mebeverine). If you have IBS you can take this to treat constipation.

【6】Key facts
---------

【7】*   Take mebeverine 20 minutes before you have a meal.
*   Mebeverine starts to work after 1 hour.
*   Mebeverine is generally safe and you're unlikely to have side effects. Some people may get a mild itchy rash (hives).
*   It's important to only take mebeverine that you buy from a pharmacy without a prescription if you've been diagnosed with IBS.

title: Sequential combined hormone replacement therapy (HRT) tablets and patches
text:
【0】About sequential combined hormone replacement therapy (HRT) \- Brand names: Evorel Sequi, Elleste Duet, Femoston, Novofem
=========================================================================================================================

【1】Sequential combined hormone replacement therapy (HRT) is a medicine that contains the hormones oestrogen and progestogen. It's used to treat menopause symptoms.

【2】Menopause is when your periods stop due to lower hormone levels. It usually affects women between the ages of 45 and 55, but it can happen earlier. It affects anyone who has periods.

【3】As you reach the menopause your ovaries gradually begin to produce less oestrogen and progestogen. This can cause symptoms such as hot flushes, mood swings and vaginal dryness.

【4】Taking HRT can help these symptoms and help prevent other conditions such as weakening of the bones (osteoporosis), which is common after the menopause.

【5】A doctor will usually recommend sequential combined HRT if you have menopause symptoms but you're still having periods, or your last period was less than 12 months ago.

【6】Sequential combined HRT involves taking oestrogen every day and taking progestogen for 10 to 14 days of each 28-day cycle. You'll usually have withdrawal bleeding at the end of each course of progestogen.

【7】This is different to continuous combined HRT, where you take both oestrogen and progestogen every day with no monthly bleeding. Continuous combined HRT is usually prescribed after you have not had a period for 1 year or more.

【8】You'll need to take combined HRT if you still have a womb. This is because taking oestrogen on its own can thicken the womb lining, which slightly increases the risk of womb cancer. Taking progestogen together with oestrogen reduces the risk.

【9】Sequential combined HRT is only available on prescription. It comes as tablets or skin patches.

【10】Brands include Elleste Duet, Clinorette, Femoston, Novofem, Tridesta and Trisequens tablets, and Evorel Sequi and FemSeven Sequi patches.

【11】### Important: HRT shortages

【12】Currently there are supply shortages of some types of HRT. If the medicine you've been prescribed is not available, a pharmacist or doctor will be able to advise you about using a different brand or type of HRT that is suitable for you.

【13】Key facts
---------

【14】*   Your medicine will contain 2 or 3 different types of tablet or patch. You'll take the oestrogen part of your medicine every day and take your progestogen for 10 to 14 days of each 28-day cycle.
*   HRT can take up to 3 months to work fully to improve your symptoms.
*   Common side effects include headaches, breast tenderness, feeling sick and irregular vaginal bleeding, but these usually improve in the first few months of starting treatment.
*   If you feel that the HRT you're taking is not helping your symptoms, talk to a doctor. It can take time to find the right type and dose to suit you.
*   It's common to take sequential combined HRT for 2 to 5 years, and then try stopping to see if your menopause symptoms have improved. Your doctor may suggest swapping to continuous combined HRT after 1 to 2 years when the risk of irregular bleeding will be reduced.
*   It's important to see your doctor at least once a year for a check-up and to review whether you need to keep taking HRT.

title: Nitrofurantoin
text:
【0】Taking nitrofurantoin with other medicines and herbal supplements
=================================================================

【1】Cautions with other medicines
-----------------------------

【2】There are some medicines that do not mix well with nitrofurantoin.

【3】Tell your doctor if you're taking any of these medicines before you start taking nitrofurantoin:

【4】*   indigestion remedies known as antacids, particularly those that contain magnesium
*   cystitis remedies you can buy from a pharmacy
*   antibiotics known as quinolones, including nalidixic acid, ciprofloxacin, levofloxacin, norfloxacin, ofloxacin and moxifloxacin

【5】Typhoid vaccines given by mouth may not work properly if you're taking nitrofurantoin. It does not affect typhoid vaccines given by injection.

【6】Mixing nitrofurantoin with herbal remedies and supplements
----------------------------------------------------------

【7】It's not possible to say that complementary medicines or herbal remedies are safe to take with nitrofurantoin. They're not tested in the same way as pharmacy and prescription medicines.

【8】Important: Medicine safety
--------------------------

【9】Tell your doctor or pharmacist if you're taking any other medicines, including herbal remedies, vitamins or supplements.

----------------------
