title: Spina bifida
text:
【0】Symptoms \- Spina bifida
========================

【1】Contents
--------

【2】1.  Overview
2.  Symptoms
3.  Causes
4.  Treatment

【3】**Spina bifida can cause a wide range of symptoms, including problems with movement, bladder and bowel problems, and problems associated with** **hydrocephalus** **(excess fluid on the brain).**

【4】The severity of the symptoms of spina bifida varies considerably, largely depending on the location of the gap in the spine.

【5】A gap higher up the spine is more likely to cause paralysis of the legs and mobility difficulties compared with gaps in the middle or at the base of the spine, which may only cause continence issues.

【6】A baby is more likely to have learning difficulties if they develop hydrocephalus.

【7】Movement problems
-----------------

【8】The brain controls all the muscles in the body with the nerves that run through the spinal cord. Any damage to the nerves can cause problems controlling the muscles.

【9】Most children with spina bifida have some degree of weakness or paralysis in their lower limbs. They may need to use ankle supports or crutches to help them move around. If they have severe paralysis, they'll need a wheelchair.

【10】Paralysis can also cause other, associated problems. For example, as the muscles in the legs are not being used regularly, they can become very weak.

【11】The muscles support the bones so muscle weakness can affect bone development. This can cause dislocated or deformed joints, bone fractures, misshapen bones and an abnormal curvature of the spine (scoliosis).

【12】Bladder problems
----------------

【13】Many people with spina bifida have problems storing and passing pee. This is caused by the nerves that control the bladder not forming properly. It can lead to problems such as:

【14】*   urinary incontinence
*   urinary tract infections (UTIs)
*   hydronephrosis – where one or both kidneys become stretched and swollen due to a build-up of pee inside them
*   kidney scarring
*   kidney stones

【15】The bladder and kidneys will need to be regularly monitored because of the risk of infection. Ultrasound scans may be needed, as well as tests to measure the bladder's volume and the pressure inside it.

【16】Bowel problems
--------------

【17】The nerves that run through the spinal cord also control the bowel and the sphincter muscles that keep poo in the bowel.

【18】Many people with spina bifida have limited or no control over their sphincter muscles and have bowel incontinence.

【19】Bowel incontinence often leads to periods of constipation followed by episodes of diarrhoea or soiling.

【20】Hydrocephalus
-------------

【21】Some babies with spina bifida have hydrocephalus (excess fluid on the brain), which can damage the brain and cause further problems.

【22】Many people with spina bifida and hydrocephalus will have normal intelligence, although some will have learning difficulties, such as:

【23】*   a short attention span
*   difficulty solving problems
*   difficulty reading
*   difficulty understanding some spoken language – particularly fast conversations between a group of people
*   difficulty organising activities or making detailed plans

【24】They may also have problems with visual and physical co-ordination – for example, tasks such as tying shoelaces or fastening buttons.

【25】In some babies the lower parts of the brain are pushed downwards towards the spinal cord. This is known as type 2 Arnold-Chiari malformation and is linked to hydrocephalus.

【26】Hydrocephalus can cause additional symptoms soon after birth, such as irritability, seizures, drowsiness, being sick and poor feeding.

【27】Read more about the symptoms of hydrocephalus.

【28】Other problems
--------------

【29】Other problems associated with spina bifida include: 

【30】*   skin problems – reduced sensation can make it difficult to tell when the skin on the legs has been damaged – for example, if the skin gets burnt on a radiator; if a person with spina bifida injures their legs without realising, the skin could become infected or an ulcer could develop; it's important to check the skin regularly for signs of injury
*   latex allergy – people with spina bifida can develop an allergy to latex; symptoms can range from a mild allergic reaction – watery eyes and skin rashes – to a severe allergic reaction, known as anaphylactic shock, which requires an immediate injection of adrenalin; tell medical staff if you or your child is allergic to latex

title: Buprenorphine for pain
text:
【0】Common questions about buprenorphine \- Brand names: Butec, Buvidal, Espranor, Suboxone, Subutex
================================================================================================

【1】How does buprenorphine work?

【2】Buprenorphine is from a group of medicines called opioids or narcotics.

【3】It works in the central nervous system and the brain to block pain signals to the rest of the body. It also reduces the anxiety and stress caused by pain.

【4】When will I feel better?

【5】This depends on the type of buprenorphine you take.

【6】A buprenorphine injection into a vein gives the quickest pain relief. It works almost straight away and is usually only given in hospital.

【7】Buprenorphine tablets take about 1 to 2 hours to work.

【8】Buprenorphine patches can take up to a day or 2 to start working but they'll last longer. Patches are usually given after buprenorphine tablets or another opioid such as morphine liquid. This is to make sure that you have pain relief until the patches start to work.

【9】Are there any long-term side effects?

【10】Some people with conditions that need long-term pain relief may need to take buprenorphine for a long time.

【11】If you need to take it for a long time your body can become used to it (known as tolerance). That means you need higher doses to control your pain over time.

【12】Some people can become more sensitive to pain (hyperalgesia). If this happens, your doctor will reduce your dose gradually to help these symptoms.

【13】It's possible to become addicted to buprenorphine. For this reason, your dose will be reviewed to make sure you're only having the amount you need to control your pain.

【14】Your treatment plan may include details of how and when you'll stop buprenorphine.

【15】If you're having treatment for cancer pain or other severe pain, your pain control will be carefully monitored. Speak to your doctor if you're worried about tolerance, hyperalgesia or becoming addicted.

【16】How will I know if I'm addicted?

【17】If you're addicted to buprenorphine you may find it difficult to stop using it, or feel you want to use it more often than you need to.

【18】If you stop taking buprenorphine suddenly you may get withdrawal symptoms.

【19】These can include:

【20】*   feeling agitated or anxious
*   panic attacks
*   feeling your heart beat (palpitations)
*   difficulty sleeping
*   shaking
*   sweating
*   body aches
*   feeling restless

【21】Talk to your doctor if you:

【22】*   are worried about addiction
*   need help with addiction
*   want to stop taking buprenorphine

【23】What will happen if I stop taking it?

【24】If you need to take or use buprenorphine for a long time, your body can become used to it.

【25】This is not usually a problem. However, you could get withdrawal symptoms if you stop taking it suddenly.

【26】If you want to stop taking or using buprenorphine, talk to your doctor first. Your dose can be reduced gradually so you do not get withdrawal symptoms.

【27】If you stop having buprenorphine suddenly it can make you:

【28】*   feel agitated
*   feel anxious
*   shaky
*   sweat a lot

【29】### Important

【30】If you've been taking or using buprenorphine for more than a few weeks, do not stop taking it without speaking to your doctor first.

【31】How does buprenorphine compare with other opioids?

【32】Buprenorphine acts on different pain signals in the brain to some other opioids, such as codeine, morphine and tramadol.

【33】The pain relief and side effects from buprenorphine will be different for everyone. Your doctor may prescribe buprenorphine if you've had side effects from other opioids.

【34】The way you take buprenorphine is different to some other painkillers. Buprenorphine is not absorbed very well by swallowing tablets. Instead, your body absorbs it through your skin or mouth.

【35】Some people find skin patches more convenient than taking tablets or capsules regularly.

【36】What do I do with used buprenorphine patches?

【37】Fold the buprenorphine patch in half so that the sticky sides stick to each other. Then either put the patch back in the packet it came in or, if you're replacing it with a new patch, you could put your used patch in the empty packet from the new patch.

【38】Return any used or unused patches to your pharmacist who will destroy them safely.

【39】Patches can accidentally stick to another person.

【40】### Urgent advice: Call your doctor or call 111 now if:

【41】*   a buprenorphine patch sticks to someone it has not been prescribed for

【42】If this happens, remove the patch straight away.

【43】Will it affect my contraception?

【44】Buprenorphine does not affect any type of contraception including the combined pill or emergency contraception.

【45】However, if buprenorphine makes you vomit, your contraceptive pills may not protect you from pregnancy. Look on the pill packet to find out what to do.

【46】Read more about what to do if you're on the pill and you're being sick.

【47】Can I drive or ride a bike?

【48】Do not drive a car or ride a bike if buprenorphine makes you sleepy, gives you blurred vision or makes you feel dizzy, clumsy or unable to concentrate or make decisions.

【49】This may be more likely when you first start using buprenorphine but could happen at any time, for example when starting another medicine.

【50】It's an offence to drive a car if your ability to drive safely is affected. It's your responsibility to decide if it's safe to drive. If you're in any doubt, do not drive.

【51】Even if your ability to drive is not affected, the police have the right to request a saliva sample to check how much buprenorphine is in your body.

【52】Talk to your doctor or pharmacist if you're unsure whether it's safe for you to drive while using buprenorphine. GOV.UK has more information on the law on drugs and driving.

【53】Can I drink alcohol while using or taking buprenorphine?

【54】It's best not to drink alcohol when you first start taking or using buprenorphine until you see how it affects you.

【55】Drinking alcohol while using buprenorphine can make you more sleepy and increases the risk of side effects.

【56】Is there any food or drink I need to avoid?

【57】Buprenorphine is not generally affected by food or drink so you can eat normally. It's best not to drink alcohol when you first start taking or using buprenorphine until you see how it affects you.

【58】Check the information leaflet that came with your tablets to see whether you need to avoid food at the same time as taking your tablets.

【59】Will recreational drugs affect it?

【60】If you take recreational drugs, such as cannabis, cocaine or heroin, while you're taking buprenorphine, you're more likely to get serious side effects. These include breathing difficulties, heart problems such as high blood pressure, seizures or fits and even going into a coma.

【61】Some recreational drugs, such as cannabis, will also increase the risk of side effects from buprenorphine – it may make you feel very sleepy or dizzy.

【62】Taking heroin while you're on buprenorphine is especially dangerous. You're more likely to get all the side effects of buprenorphine.

【63】Tell your doctor if you think you may take recreational drugs while you're on buprenorphine.

【64】You can find out about the side effects of recreational drugs on the Frank website.

title: Varicose veins
text:
【0】Diagnosis \- Varicose veins
===========================

【1】Contents
--------

【2】1.  Overview
2.  Causes
3.  Diagnosis
4.  Treatment
5.  Complications

【3】**If you have varicose veins and they do not cause you any discomfort, you may not need to visit a GP.**

【4】Varicose veins are rarely a serious condition and they do not usually require treatment.

【5】But speak to a GP if:

【6】*   your varicose veins are causing you pain or discomfort
*   the skin over your veins is sore and irritated
*   the aching in your legs is causing irritation at night and disturbing your sleep

【7】Speak immediately to a GP or call 111 if your varicose veins start bleeding. You may need urgent treatment.

【8】Seeing a GP
-----------

【9】Varicose veins are diagnosed by their appearance. The GP will examine your legs while you're standing to check for signs of swelling.

【10】You may also be asked to describe any pain you have and whether there are situations that make your varicose veins worse.

【11】For example, some women find their menstrual cycle (period) affects their varicose veins.

【12】The GP will also want to know if you're at an increased risk of developing varicose veins, such as:

【13】*   having a family history of varicose veins
*   being pregnant
*   whether you have a healthy body mass index (BMI)
*   having deep vein thrombosis (a blood clot in one of the deep veins of the body)
*   a history of leg injury (for example, having previously broken a bone in your leg)

【14】Further investigation
---------------------

【15】The GP may refer you to a vascular specialist (a doctor who specialises in veins) if you have any of the following:

【16】*   varicose veins that are causing pain, aching, discomfort, swelling, heaviness or itching
*   changes in the colour of the skin on your leg that may be caused by problems with the blood flow in the leg
*   skin conditions affecting your leg, such as eczema, that may be caused by problems with the blood flow in the leg
*   hard and painful varicose veins that may be caused by problems with the blood flow in the leg
*   a healed or unhealed leg ulcer (a break in the skin that has not healed within 2 weeks) below the knee

【17】In most cases, a test called a duplex ultrasound scan will be carried out. This is a type of scan that uses high-frequency sound waves to produce a picture of the veins in your legs.

【18】The picture shows the blood flow and helps the vascular specialist locate any damaged valves that might be causing your varicose veins.

title: Olmesartan
text:
【0】How and when to take olmesartan
===============================

【1】Always take olmesartan as instructed by your doctor.

【2】Dosage and strength
-------------------

【3】Olmesartan comes as 10mg, 20mg and 40mg tablets.

【4】For adults and children aged 6 years and over, the usual starting dose is 10mg taken once a day.

【5】Your dose may go up to 20mg or 40mg, taken once a day.

【6】Children weighing less than 35kg (about 5.5 stone) should not take more than 20mg daily.

【7】### Changes to your dose

【8】After a few weeks your doctor will check your blood pressure and ask you if you're getting any side effects.

【9】You may also have blood tests to check how well your kidneys are working and the amount of potassium in your blood.

【10】Your doctor will then decide whether to change your dose of olmesartan.

【11】If olmesartan does not bring your blood pressure down, your doctor may want to increase the dose.

【12】If your blood pressure gets too low or you get side effects, your doctor may want to lower your dose.

【13】How to take it
--------------

【14】Take olmesartan tablets once a day. Swallow the tablets whole with a drink of water. Do not crush or chew them.

【15】You can take olmesartan with or without food.

【16】Your doctor may suggest that you take your first dose before bedtime, as it can make you feel dizzy. After the first dose, you can then take olmesartan at any time of day.

【17】Usually people take olmesartan in the morning, but it does not really matter. Just try to take it at the same time every day.

【18】Speak to a pharmacist if you or your child have difficulty swallowing tablets.

【19】How long to take it for
-----------------------

【20】Usually treatment with olmesartan is long term, even for the rest of your life.

【21】If you get ill while taking it
------------------------------

【22】If you get severe diarrhoea or vomiting for any reason, contact your doctor or a pharmacist. They'll be able to advise you about what to do.

【23】They may lower your dose or recommend that you stop taking olmesartan until you're better and able to eat and drink normally again.

【24】If you take contraceptive pills and you're being sick (vomiting) or have severe diarrhoea for more than 24 hours, your contraception may not protect you from pregnancy. Check the pill packet to find out what to do.

【25】If you forget to take it
------------------------

【26】If you miss a dose of olmesartan, take it as soon as you remember if it's the same day. If you do not remember until the next day, skip the forgotten dose and take your next dose at the usual time.

【27】Do not take a double dose to make up for a forgotten one.

【28】If you forget doses often, it may help to set an alarm to remind you. You could also ask your pharmacist for advice on other ways to help you remember to take your medicine.

【29】Stopping olmesartan
-------------------

【30】Talk to your doctor if you want to stop taking olmesartan.

【31】Stopping olmesartan may cause your blood pressure to rise. This may increase your chances of having a heart attack or stroke.

【32】If you're bothered by side effects, your doctor may be able to prescribe a different blood pressure-lowering medicine.

【33】### Important

【34】Take olmesartan even if you feel well, as you'll still be getting the benefits of the medicine.

【35】If you take too much
--------------------

【36】Taking too much olmesartan can make you feel dizzy (due to low blood pressure).

【37】The amount of olmesartan that can lead to an overdose varies from person to person.

【38】### Urgent advice: Contact 111 for advice now if:

【39】*   you take more than your prescribed dose of olmesartan

【40】Go to 111.nhs.uk or call 111.

【41】If you need to go to A&E, do not drive yourself. Get someone else to drive you or call for an ambulance.

【42】Take the olmesartan packet or the leaflet inside it, plus any remaining medicine, with you.

title: Carbamazepine
text:
【0】About carbamazepine
===================

【1】Carbamazepine is a medicine used to treat epilepsy.

【2】It can also be taken for nerve pain caused by diabetes (peripheral neuropathy) or if you have a painful condition of the face called trigeminal neuralgia.

【3】Carbamazepine is occasionally used to treat bipolar disorder when other medicines have not worked.

【4】This medicine is only available on prescription. It comes as standard and slow-release tablets, a liquid that you drink and suppositories (medicine that you push gently into your anus).

【5】### Important

【6】The brand Carbagen has been discontinued. If you are currently taking Carbagen, contact your doctor for a different brand to be prescribed.

【7】Updated: 28 September 2020

【8】Key facts
---------

【9】*   It usually takes a couple of weeks for carbamazepine to work.
*   Common side effects of carbamazepine include feeling sleepy, feeling dizzy, headaches and feeling or being sick. These are usually mild and go away by themselves.
*   When taking carbamazepine for epilepsy, it's best to stick to the same brand. If your usual brand is not available, talk to your doctor.
*   Drinking alcohol while taking carbamazepine may make you feel sleepy or tired. It's best to stop drinking alcohol for the first few days, until you see how the medicine affects you.
*   Do not drink grapefruit juice if you're taking carbamazepine. It increases the amount of carbamazepine in your body and increases the risk of side effects.

title: Colic
text:
【0】Colic
=====

【1】**Colic is when a baby cries a lot but there's no obvious cause. It's a common problem that should get better by around 3 or 4 months of age. But call NHS 111 or see a GP if you're worried.**

【2】Check if your baby has colic
----------------------------

【3】All babies cry, but your baby may have colic if they cry more than 3 hours a day, 3 days a week for at least 1 week but are otherwise healthy.

【4】They may cry more often in the afternoon and evening.

【5】It may also be colic if, while they are crying:

【6】*   it's hard to soothe or settle your baby
*   they clench their fists
*   they go red in the face
*   they bring their knees up to their tummy or arch their back
*   their tummy rumbles or they're very windy

【7】It can start when a baby is a few weeks old. It usually stops by the time they're 3 to 4 months old.

【8】If you're not sure it's colic

【9】There are other reasons why your baby may be crying.

【10】It could be they:

【11】*   are hungry
*   have a dirty nappy
*   have wind
*   have reflux
*   have constipation

【12】If you're not sure what's wrong, it's best to speak to your health visitor, call NHS 111 or see a GP to be sure.

【13】Things you can try to soothe your baby
--------------------------------------

【14】Your baby does not usually need to see a doctor if they have colic. Speak to your health visitor for advice and support.

【15】Health visitors and doctors will usually advise you to:

【16】*   hold or cuddle your baby when they're crying a lot
*   sit or hold your baby upright during feeding to stop them swallowing air
*   wind your baby after feeds
*   gently rock your baby over your shoulder
*   gently rock your baby in their Moses basket or crib, or push them in their pram
*   bath your baby in a warm bath
*   have some gentle white noise like the radio or TV in the background to distract them
*   keep feeding your baby as usual

【17】Other things you may hear about include:

【18】*   anti-colic drops and herbal and probiotic supplements
*   changes to your diet if you're breastfeeding
*   applying gentle pressure to your baby's spine (spinal manipulation) or skull (cranial osteopathy)

【19】But there's very little evidence these things work. Speak to your health visitor for further advice.

【20】Non-urgent advice: Call NHS 111 or see a GP if:
-----------------------------------------------

【21】*   you're worried about your baby's crying
*   your baby has colic and nothing seems to be working
*   you're finding it hard to cope
*   your baby is not growing or putting on weight as expected
*   your baby still has symptoms of colic after 4 months of age

【22】A GP will check for possible causes of your baby's crying.

【23】Immediate action required: Go to A&E or call 999 if:
----------------------------------------------------

【24】*   your baby has a weak or high-pitched cry
*   your baby's cry does not sound like their normal cry

【25】You know better than anyone else what your child is usually like. Trust your instincts if you think something is seriously wrong, particularly if they have other worrying symptoms.

【26】Find your nearest A&E

【27】How to cope if you have a colicky baby
--------------------------------------

【28】Looking after a colicky baby can be upsetting, but it's usually nothing to worry about and will pass with time.

【29】Ask for support:

【30】*   from other parents, family or friends
*   by calling the Cry-sis helpline free on 0800 448 0737 (9am to 10pm, 7 days a week)
*   from your health visitor, by calling NHS 111 or seeing a GP

【31】Causes of colic
---------------

【32】It's not known exactly what causes some babies to get colic. But it may be because babies find it harder to digest food when they're young.

【33】Or they may be crying because they have problems with food allergies, such as a cows' milk allergy.

title: Losartan
text:
【0】About losartan
==============

【1】Losartan is a medicine called angiotensin receptor blocker (ARB). It's widely used to treat high blood pressure (hypertension) and heart failure. It's also used to protect your kidneys if you have both kidney disease and diabetes (diabetic kidney disease).

【2】Losartan can also help to prevent strokes and heart attacks, and is used to improve your survival if you're taking it for heart failure or after a heart attack.

【3】Like other ARBs, losartan relaxes and widens your blood vessels. This lowers your blood pressure and makes it easier for your heart to pump blood around your body.

【4】Losartan can also be combined with hydrochlorothizide and is called by the brand name Cozaar-Comp.

【5】This medicine is only available on prescription. It comes as tablets.

【6】Key facts
---------

【7】*   Losartan is often used as a second-choice treatment. Your doctor might prescribe it if you had to stop taking another medicine to lower your blood pressure because it gave you a dry, irritating cough.
*   If you have diarrhoea and vomiting from a stomach bug or illness while taking losartan, tell your doctor. You may need to stop taking it until you feel better.
*   The main side effects of losartan are feeling dizzy and tired, but they're usually mild and do not last long.
*   Losartan can make you feel dizzy, especially when you first start taking it or after taking a bigger dose. If this happens, do not drive a car, ride a bike, or use tools or machinery until you feel better.
*   Losartan is not normally recommended in pregnancy or while breastfeeding. Talk to your doctor if you're trying to get pregnant, are already pregnant or you're breastfeeding.
*   Do not use salt substitutes such as Lo-Salt. This is because they are high in potassium and when mixed with losartan, they may cause potassium levels in your blood to be too high.

【8】More in Losartan

title: Finasteride
text:
【0】Common questions about finasteride \- Brand names: Proscar, Propecia
====================================================================

【1】How does finasteride work?

【2】Finasteride is a type of medicine called a 5-alpha reductase inhibitor.

【3】It works by stopping testosterone (a sex hormone) turning into another hormone called dihydrotestosterone (DHT). DHT can cause your prostate to grow bigger (benign prostate enlargement). It can also stop your hair growing.

【4】Finasteride stops DHT being produced and this helps shrink your prostate and reduce hair loss.

【5】How long does it take to work?

【6】You may notice an improvement a little while after you start taking finasteride.

【7】However, for an enlarged prostate it can take up to 6 months for this medicine to work fully.

【8】For hair loss, you can expect to see some improvement after 3 to 6 months.

【9】Are there any long-term side effects?

【10】Finasteride is generally safe to take for a long time. Many people take it for many months or even years without any problems.

【11】However, there have been reports of breast cancer in some men taking finasteride, but this is rare. Speak to your doctor if you get any changes in your chest area such as lumps, pain or swelling, or discharge from your nipples.

【12】Some men have reported that sexual side effects (such as not being able to get an erection) continued to bother them even after they stopped taking finasteride.

【13】Talk to your doctor if you're bothered by any of these side effects.

【14】Will it affect my contraception?

【15】Finasteride is not thought to stop any type of contraception working. However, this medicine is not usually taken by women.

【16】The manufacturers of finasteride recommend using a condom when having sex because very small amounts of finasteride get into semen, but the actual risk is unlikely to be significant. Most experts agree that this is not necessary.

【17】Can I drive or ride a bike?

【18】Finasteride will not affect your ability to drive, cycle or use machinery.

【19】Can I drink alcohol while taking finasteride?

【20】You can drink alcohol with finasteride.

【21】Is there any food or and drink I need to avoid?

【22】You can eat and drink normally when taking finasteride.

【23】Can lifestyle changes help symptoms of an enlarged prostate?

【24】Making some simple changes to your lifestyle can help with symptoms of an enlarged prostate.

【25】*   Drink fewer fizzy drinks and less alcohol, caffeine and artificial sweeteners – they can irritate the bladder and make urinary symptoms worse.
*   Quit smoking – nicotine can irritate the bladder and make urinary symptoms worse.
*   Drink less in the evening – try to reduce the amount you drink and avoid drinking anything for 2 hours before bedtime. This might help you avoid getting up in the night. Make sure you're still drinking enough fluids earlier in the day.
*   Empty your bladder – remember to go to the toilet before long journeys or other situations when you know you may not be able to reach a toilet easily.
*   Try double voiding – this is when you finish peeing, wait a few moments, then try to go again. This can help you empty your bladder properly (but take care not to strain or push).
*   Check your medicines – ask a doctor whether any medicines you take, such as antidepressants or decongestants, may be making your urinary symptoms worse.
*   Eat more fruit and fibre – this can help you avoid constipation. Being constipated can put pressure on the bladder and make your symptoms worse.

title: Coal tar
text:
【0】How and when to use coal tar \- Brand names: Alphosyl, Exorex, Neutrogena, Polytar, Psoriderm
=============================================================================================

【1】Dosage and strength
-------------------

【2】Coal tar comes in different strengths:

【3】*   shampoo and scalp lotions contain 1% to 5% coal tar
*   cream and ointments contain 1% to 12% coal tar
*   bath liquid (emulsion additive) contains up to 40% coal tar

【4】To find out how much coal tar to use and how often, follow the instructions from your pharmacist or doctor, or check the product label.

【5】How to use it
-------------

【6】Always use the recommended amount of coal tar. Do not use it for longer than recommended.

【7】Do not use coal tar together with other skin treatments unless your doctor tells you to.

【8】### Important

【9】If you get coal tar in your eyes or mouth, wash it out immediately with plenty of cold water. If your eyes become irritated, talk to your doctor or pharmacist.

【10】### How to use cream or ointment

【11】Coal tar is available as a cream and ointment.

【12】Cream is better for skin that is moist or weepy. Ointment is thicker and greasier, and is better for dry or flaky areas of skin.

【13】Sometimes, the amount of coal tar cream or ointment you need to use is given in fingertip units. This is the amount you can squeeze onto the end of your finger.

【14】A fingertip unit is generally enough to treat both sides of your hand.

【15】For children, the right amount of cream or ointment depends on their age. A doctor or pharmacist can advise you.

【16】Credit:

【17】Mark Thomas/Science Photo Library https://www.sciencephoto.com/media/463425/view

【18】1.  Wash your hands.
2.  Squeeze out a fingertip unit of cream or ointment.
3.  Carefully smooth the cream or ointment in a thin layer over the affected area.
4.  Be careful not to get the cream or ointment onto broken skin or cuts.
5.  Wash your hands afterwards.

【19】If you need to use a dressing, like a bandage or plaster, wait at least 10 minutes after putting on coal tar cream or ointment.

【20】Use once or twice a day or as recommended by a doctor.

【21】Some creams, like Psoriderm, should only be used on the particular type of skin condition that they're recommended for. Check the packet or ask your doctor or pharmacist.

【22】#### Important: Fire warning

【23】Skin creams and ointments can dry onto your clothes and bedding. This makes them more likely to catch fire. Avoid naked flames.

【24】### How to use shampoo

【25】1.  Wet your hair thoroughly.
2.  Use enough shampoo to lather your hair, scalp and immediately surrounding areas if they're also affected.
3.  Using your fingertips, massage your scalp and affected areas well.
4.  Rinse off the shampoo thoroughly with water.
5.  Repeat steps 2 to 4.
6.  Wash and rinse your hands.

【26】Coal tar shampoo should be in contact with your scalp for between 3 and 5 minutes.

【27】Use once or twice a week or as recommended by a doctor.

【28】### How to use scalp lotion

【29】1.  Shake the bottle thoroughly before each use.
2.  Wash your hands.
3.  Unscrew the bottle cap and place the nozzle directly on your scalp.
4.  Gently squeeze the bottle to cover the scalp area with a thin and even layer of liquid.
5.  Do not use more than the recommended amount and try not to get it into your eyes.
6.  Massage the area gently with your fingertips.
7.  Leave the treatment to dry for 1 hour. Your scalp will feel cool while the liquid is drying.
8.  Wash the scalp lotion out with warm water.
9.  Wash your hands straight after use.

【30】For children and older people, the liquid can be diluted. Boil and cool some water. Pour the recommended amount of scalp treatment into the palm of your hand and add a few drops of the cooled water. Apply the mixture to the scalp and massage. Continue with steps 7, 8 and 9.

【31】How often you use the scalp lotion depends on your symptoms. If they are mild, use it once a week. If your symptoms are more severe, use it daily for the first 3 to 7 days then reduce to once a week.

【32】### How to use bath liquid (emulsion additive)

【33】1.  Add 30ml of the liquid to a bath of warm water.
2.  Get into the bath and soak for 5 to 20 minutes. Check your medicine instructions for information on how long to soak for.
3.  The bathtub may be slippery, so take care when getting out.
4.  Pat your skin dry with a soft towel. Avoid rubbing with the towel as this can make your skin condition worse.

【34】Use this as your doctor tells you and always follow the instructions that come with your medicine. This will help to prevent your symptoms coming back.

【35】If you forget to use it
-----------------------

【36】If you forget to use coal tar, use it as soon as you remember, unless you do not remember until it's nearly time to use it again. In this case, just wait and use it at the usual time.

【37】Do not use double the amount to make up for a missed use.

【38】If you use too much
-------------------

【39】Using more than the recommended amount of coal tar is unlikely to harm you but it may increase the risk of skin irritation. Speak to your pharmacist if you're worried.

【40】If you put on too much cream or ointment, wipe off the extra with a tissue.

【41】If you use too much scalp lotion, rinse your hair with water.

title: Swollen ankles, feet and fingers in pregnancy
text:
【0】Swollen ankles, feet and fingers in pregnancy
=============================================

【1】It's normal to get some swelling in pregnancy, particularly in your legs, ankles, feet and fingers.

【2】It's often worse at the end of the day and further into your pregnancy.

【3】Swelling that comes on gradually is not usually harmful to you or your baby, but it can be uncomfortable.

【4】A sudden increase in swelling can be a sign of pre-eclampsia, a condition that needs to be monitored as soon as possible.

【5】Non-urgent advice: Call your midwife, GP or labour ward immediately if you have:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

【6】*   a sudden increase in swelling in your face, hands or feet
*   a very bad headache
*   problems with your vision, such as blurring or flashing lights in your eyes
*   severe pain just below your ribs
*   vomiting with any of these symptoms

【7】These could be symptoms of pre-eclampsia, which can lead to serious complications if it's not monitored and treated.

【8】Normal pregnancy swelling
-------------------------

【9】Swelling is caused by your body holding more water than usual when you're pregnant.

【10】Throughout the day the extra water tends to gather in the lowest parts of the body, especially if the weather is hot or you have been standing a lot.

【11】The pressure of your growing womb can also affect the blood flow in your legs. This can cause fluid to build up in your legs, ankles and feet.

【12】What can help to reduce swelling
--------------------------------

【13】Try to:

【14】*   avoid standing for long periods
*   wear comfortable shoes and socks – avoid tight straps or anything that might pinch if your feet swell
*   try to rest with your feet up as much as you can
*   drink plenty of water – this helps your body get rid of excess water
*   exercise – try to take regular walks during the day or doing foot exercises

【15】### Foot exercises

【16】You can do foot exercises sitting or standing. They improve blood circulation, reduce swelling in the ankles, and prevent cramp in the calf muscles:

【17】*   bend and stretch your foot up and down 30 times
*   rotate each foot in a circle 8 times one way and 8 times the other way

【18】Get more tips on exercising in pregnancy.

title: Amitriptyline for pain and migraine
text:
【0】Common questions about amitriptyline for pain and migraine
==========================================================

【1】How does amitriptyline work?

【2】Amitriptyline is from a group of medicines called tricyclic antidepressants.

【3】They're thought to work by increasing a chemical called serotonin in your brain. This can improve your mood.

【4】This can also change the way that your nerves receive pain signals so pain goes away. This helps your symptoms if you're taking amitriptyline for pain relief or migraine.

【5】When will I feel better?

【6】You may find you're sleeping better straight away. But it usually takes 1 or 2 weeks for pain to begin to wear off.

【7】It can take between 4 and 6 weeks before you feel the full benefits of amitriptyline as a painkiller.

【8】Do not stop taking amitriptyline after 1 to 2 weeks just because you feel it's not helping your symptoms. Allow at least 6 weeks to see if it works for you.

【9】Are there any long-term side effects?

【10】Although there is a lot of information on the short-term effects of taking amitriptyline, less is known about the long-term effects.

【11】There may be an increased risk of confusion and possibly dementia in people taking medicines like amitriptyline but more research needs to be done. If you're worried about this, talk to your doctor.

【12】Your doctor will check with you regularly to make sure your treatment is still working and that you're not having problems with side effects.

【13】What will happen when I stop taking amitriptyline?

【14】You may get extra side effects when you stop taking amitriptyline. This is more likely if you stop taking it suddenly.

【15】These side effects are a physical reaction as the medicine leaves your system. You may get flu-like symptoms like feeling sick, muscle pain and feeling tired or restless.

【16】To help prevent these side effects, your doctor will probably recommend reducing your dose gradually over several weeks, or longer if you've been taking amitriptyline for a long time.

【17】### Important

【18】Do not stop taking amitriptyline suddenly without talking to your doctor.

【19】Are there other treatments that will help?

【20】Antidepressants like amitriptyline are just one of several ways to treat nerve pain or pain that lasts for a long time, or to prevent migraines. Other treatments include:

【21】*   other antidepressants such as duloxetine
*   painkillers such as paracetamol
*   medicines that are usually used for epilepsy such as pregabalin
*   medicines that are usually used to treat high blood pressure such as propranolol
*   physiotherapy
*   talking therapies such as cognitive behavioural therapy (CBT)
*   exercise programmes and physical activity
*   acupuncture

【22】Choosing a treatment that's most suitable for you depends on:

【23】*   what is causing the pain
*   how long you've had the pain
*   your symptoms
*   what medicines have worked or not worked for you in the past

【24】How will amitriptyline make me feel?

【25】Many people sleep better while they're taking amitriptyline.

【26】Although amitriptyline is an antidepressant, the doses are lower when used to treat pain. Taking amitriptyline as a painkiller will not have the same effects as taking it for depression.

【27】Is amitriptyline addictive?

【28】Amitriptyline is not addictive but you can get extra side effects if you stop taking it suddenly. You may have flu-like symptoms like feeling sick, muscle pain and feeling tired or restless.

【29】To help prevent this happening, your doctor will probably recommend reducing your dose gradually over several weeks, or longer if you've been taking amitriptyline for a long time.

【30】Will I gain or lose weight?

【31】Amitriptyline can change how hungry you feel. Some people feel more hungry when they're taking it while others feel less hungry. So your weight may change when you first start taking it.

【32】If you start to have problems with your weight while taking amitriptyline, talk to your doctor or a pharmacist.

【33】Will it affect my sex life?

【34】Some people have sex-related problems while taking amitriptyline. These can include:

【35】*   men having problems with getting an erection and problems with ejaculating
*   women having some vaginal bleeding
*   both men and women having breast swelling

【36】Sexual side effects are not common and should go away after the first couple of weeks. If they do not, and this is a problem for you, go back to your doctor to see if there's another medicine you can try.

【37】If you're a woman and you get vaginal bleeding after the menopause, make an appointment to see your doctor as soon as possible.

【38】Will it affect my contraception?

【39】Amitriptyline does not stop any type of contraception from working, including the combined pill and emergency contraception.

【40】Can I drive or ride a bike?

【41】Some people feel sleepy and dizzy while they're taking amitriptyline. It's best to stop driving and cycling, and avoid using machinery or tools, for the first few days of treatment until you know how this medicine makes you feel.

【42】It's an offence to drive a car if your ability to drive safely is affected. It's your responsibility to decide if it's safe to drive. If you're in any doubt, do not drive.

【43】Talk to your doctor or pharmacist if you're unsure whether it's safe for you to drive while taking amitriptyline. GOV.UK has more information on the law on drugs and driving.

【44】Can I drink alcohol while taking amitriptyline?

【45】You can drink alcohol while taking amitriptyline but it may make you feel sleepy. It's usually best to stop drinking alcohol until you see how the medicine makes you feel.

【46】Is there any food or drink I need to avoid?

【47】Apart from avoiding drinking too much alcohol, you can eat and drink normally while taking amitriptyline.

【48】Will recreational drugs affect amitriptyline?

【49】Cannabis with amitriptyline can make you feel very sleepy, especially if you've just started taking the medicine. Using them together can also give you a fast heartbeat.

【50】It can be dangerous to take amitriptyline with:

【51】*   methadone
*   stimulants like MDMA (ecstasy) or cocaine
*   hallucinogens like LSD
*   novel psychoactive substances (which used to be known as legal highs) like mephedrone

【52】Amitriptyline has not been properly tested with recreational drugs. Talk to your doctor if you think you might use recreational drugs while taking amitriptyline.

【53】Find out more the side effects of some recreational drugs on the Frank website.

title: How to care for children with complex needs
text:
【0】How to care for children with complex needs
===========================================

【1】If your child has been diagnosed with an illness, disability or sensory impairment and needs a lot of additional support on a daily basis, they're described as having "complex needs". A child might have complex needs from birth, or after an illness or injury.

【2】Support after diagnosis
-----------------------

【3】Although everyone's experience will be different, it can be reassuring to speak to other parents who have children with the same disability or health condition as yours. They're likely to have been through the same emotions and processes.

【4】Many organisations offer advice as well as online forums or message boards for parents:

【5】*   the charity Bliss can provide advice and support to families with a baby in special care
*   your local council may be able to provide details of parent carers groups in your area – find your local council on GOV.UK
*   Carers Direct has advice for parent carers – call on 0300 123 1053 from 9am to 8pm Monday to Friday, and 11am to 4pm at weekends (closed bank holidays), or use the textphone/minicom service on 0300 123 1004
*   health charities such as the Down's Syndrome Association can give advice and guidance on your child's specific health condition
*   the charity Contact has advice and information for families with disabled children

【6】### GP carers register

【7】If your GP's surgery has a carers register, ask to be added. If your GP knows you're a carer, they can keep an eye on your health and you'll have someone to speak to in confidence about how you're feeling.

【8】They can also advise on local organisations and carers services that may benefit you and your child now and in the future.

【9】Your child's medical needs
--------------------------

【10】Your child's medical and healthcare needs are the responsibility of your local NHS health services.

【11】This includes any medical equipment, such as special beds, bed equipment, hoists, and aids to help with incontinence, mobility or hearing. It's usually provided free.

【12】If your child needs regular healthcare treatment at home, your family may be supported by community children's nurses. They can also help with any treatment you need to carry out for your child, such as giving oxygen or injections.

【13】Your child may receive a continuing care package if they have needs arising from disability, an accident or illness that can't be met by existing universal or specialist services alone.

【14】Children who have a continuing care package have the right to a personal health budget so that their families and carers can have more control over their care.

【15】Find out more about personal health budgets.

【16】Daily living with a disabled child
----------------------------------

【17】Your local authority is responsible for providing any non-medical care services your child is assessed as needing. This could include equipment for daily living, home care, access to play schemes, and respite care so that you can have a break.

【18】To access services from your local authority, you'll need to ask for your child to have a needs assessment. Your needs, and the rest of your family's, can be considered during your child's assessment.

【19】If the assessment doesn't address your needs as a carer, you can ask for your own carer's assessment.

【20】Get tips on caring for a disabled child.

【21】### Respite care

【22】Time away from your child can often be beneficial for you both. Being overwhelmed and exhausted by your caring responsibilities can affect your health.

【23】If family and friends can't always step in, respite care may be a possibility. Your GP or social worker will be able to discuss all the options and organise the care. Alternatively, you could pay for respite care privately.

【24】Find out more about carers' breaks and respite care.

【25】Single parent carers
--------------------

【26】There are lots of organisations specifically aimed at single parents, including those with disabled children, such as Gingerbread that can provide information and advice.

【27】Local support groups provide the opportunity to talk to other single parents. Some run drop-in centres or offer home visits. Your local group may also publish a newsletter covering activities in your area or providing help with organising respite care.

【28】For more support, call Gingerbread's single parent helpline on 0808 802 0925 or Contact on 0808 808 3555.

【29】Single parents of disabled children may be entitled to a range of benefits. Check using GOV.UK's online benefits calculators.

【30】### Employment and single parents

【31】If you've worked for your employer for at least 26 weeks, you have the right to ask your employer for a flexible working pattern.

【32】This includes changing the time, or number of hours or days you work, or applying for a job share.

【33】Grandparent carers
------------------

【34】Grandparents sometimes assume full-time care of their grandchildren. Looking after children can be a physical and financial strain at any age but particularly if you're older.

【35】Advice and support on being the sole carer of a grandchild is available from Kinship.

【36】Lifelong care for a disabled child
----------------------------------

【37】It's natural to be concerned about your child's future if they are born with an illness or disability, or diagnosed at an early age.

【38】It's worth asking your local authority for an assessment of your child's needs and for your needs as a carer.

【39】The local authority should consider the needs of your whole family, especially if you have other children who may be young carers themselves.

【40】To find out about assessments, call the Carers Direct helpline on 0300 123 1053.

【41】Find contact details for your local council on GOV.UK.

【42】### Independence in adulthood

【43】Many young people who have disabilities live independent lives, while others may always need significant care.

【44】Even if they have extensive care needs, your child may still be able to live independently with the right support.

【45】The video below shows how Victoria, who has profound intellectual and multiple disabilities, lives in her own home and employs her own personal assistants.

【46】Many organisations can offer advice about managing a young person's move from children's social care to adult social care.

【47】You can find contact details for these organisations in the directory of local carers' services.

【48】### What will happen to my child after I die?

【49】You may want to plan for your child's future and make sure things are in place in case they outlive you.

【50】If your child has a physical disability, they might need someone to help them with personal care or transportation.

【51】If your child has learning disabilities, they may require specialist provision such as sheltered housing, care homes or specialist nursing care.

【52】### Make a will

【53】Writing a will can help you address the fears you may have about what will happen to your children when you die. You can write a will through a solicitor, or using a will-writing pack or online will-writing services.

【54】You might have family or friends who could care for your child in an emergency, or who would be willing to look after your son or daughter if you die. If this is the case, you may want to make a will explaining your wishes for your child. It's also a good idea to let social services know in advance and to include them in an emergency care plan.

【55】If friends and family can't help, speak to social services about the best options for your child.

【56】### Written instructions

【57】It will help your child, and those who may need to care for them, if they know exactly what has to be done each day.

【58】Keep a log of the food and drinks your child likes and dislikes, what time they wake up and go to bed, what time they need their medication and so on. Doing this will make life easier for your child and their new carer.

【59】### Care plans

【60】A care plan is a good way to ensure that your child will be properly looked after if you fall ill and can't care for them, or if you die.

【61】Even if you have made arrangements for emergencies, it's essential to make an emergency care plan for your child, especially if they have complex needs. This should include your child's details and medical requirements, and the names and numbers of who to contact in case of an emergency.

【62】Your local authority will help you develop an emergency care plan when they carry out an assessment for your child under the Children Act.

title: MRI scan
text:
【0】Overview \- MRI scan
====================

【1】Contents
--------

【2】1.  Overview
2.  How it's performed
3.  Who can have one

【3】**Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) is a type of scan that uses strong magnetic fields and radio waves to produce detailed images of the inside of the body.**

【4】An MRI scanner is a large tube that contains powerful magnets. You lie inside the tube during the scan.

【5】An MRI scan can be used to examine almost any part of the body, including the:

【6】*   brain and spinal cord
*   bones and joints
*   breasts
*   heart and blood vessels
*   internal organs, such as the liver, womb or prostate gland

【7】The results of an MRI scan can be used to help diagnose conditions, plan treatments and assess how effective previous treatment has been.

【8】What happens during an MRI scan?
--------------------------------

【9】During an MRI scan, you lie on a flat bed that's moved into the scanner.

【10】Depending on the part of your body being scanned, you'll be moved into the scanner either head first or feet first.

【11】Credit:

【12】MEDICIMAGE / SCIENCE PHOTO LIBRARY

【13】https://www.sciencephoto.com/media/1200089/view

【14】The MRI scanner is operated by a radiographer, who is trained in carrying out imaging investigations.

【15】They control the scanner using a computer, which is in a different room, to keep it away from the magnetic field generated by the scanner.

【16】You'll be able to talk to the radiographer through an intercom and they'll be able to see you on a television monitor and through the viewing window throughout the scan.

【17】At certain times during the scan, the scanner will make loud tapping noises. This is the electric current in the scanner coils being turned on and off.

【18】You'll be given earplugs or headphones to wear.

【19】It's very important to keep as still as possible during your MRI scan.

【20】The radiographer may ask you to hold your breath for a few seconds or follow other instructions during the scan.

【21】The scan lasts 15 to 90 minutes, depending on the size of the area being scanned and how many images are taken.

【22】Read more about how an MRI scan is performed.

【23】How does an MRI scan work?
--------------------------

【24】Most of the human body is made up of water molecules, which consist of hydrogen and oxygen atoms.

【25】At the centre of each hydrogen atom is an even smaller particle called a proton. Protons are like tiny magnets and are very sensitive to magnetic fields.

【26】When you lie under the powerful scanner magnets, the protons in your body line up in the same direction, in the same way that a magnet can pull the needle of a compass. You will not be able to feel this.

【27】Short bursts of radio waves are then sent to certain areas of the body, knocking the protons out of alignment.

【28】When the radio waves are turned off, the protons realign. This sends out radio signals, which are picked up by receivers.

【29】These signals provide information about the exact location of the protons in the body.

【30】They also help to distinguish between the various types of tissue in the body, because the protons in different types of tissue realign at different speeds and produce distinct signals.

【31】In the same way that millions of pixels on a computer screen can create complex pictures, the signals from the millions of protons in the body are combined to create a detailed image of the inside of the body.

【32】Safety
------

【33】An MRI scan is a painless and safe procedure. You may find it uncomfortable if you have claustrophobia, but most people are able to manage it with support from the radiographer.

【34】Most modern MRI scanners have a wider tunnel, which can help reduce claustrophobia. Going into the scanner feet first may be easier, although this isn't always possible.

【35】Extensive research has been carried out into whether the magnetic fields and radio waves used during MRI scans could pose a risk to the human body.

【36】No evidence has been found to suggest there's a risk, which means MRI scans are one of the safest medical procedures available.

【37】But MRI scans may not be recommended in certain situations. For example, if you have a metal implant fitted, such as a pacemaker or artificial joint, you may not be able to have an MRI scan.

【38】If you're pregnant, a doctor will discuss with you whether an MRI scan is suitable for you.

【39】Read more about who can and can't have an MRI scan.

title: Domperidone
text:
【0】Pregnancy, breastfeeding and fertility while taking domperidone \- Brand name: Motilium
=======================================================================================

【1】Domperidone and pregnancy
-------------------------

【2】Domperidone can be taken in pregnancy if other anti-sickness medicines have not worked.

【3】Domperidone and breastfeeding
-----------------------------

【4】If your doctor or health visitor says your baby is healthy, you can take domperidone while breastfeeding but it's best to only take it for a short time.

【5】There is not much information about how much domperidone passes into breast milk, but it's only a tiny amount. It's been used during breastfeeding for many years without babies having side effects.

【6】Domperidone can also be used to help increase your breast milk supply. Although it's not made for this purpose, a specialist may offer this to you, if other things have not worked.

【7】If you notice your baby has diarrhoea, or you have any other concerns about your baby, talk to a midwife, health visitor, pharmacist or doctor as soon as possible.

【8】Domperidone and fertility
-------------------------

【9】There's no evidence to suggest that taking domperidone affects fertility in either men or women.

【10】Non-urgent advice: Tell your doctor if you're:
----------------------------------------------

【11】*   trying to get pregnant
*   pregnant
*   breastfeeding

【12】Find out how anti-sickness medicines such as domperidone can affect you and your baby on the Best Use of Medicines in Pregnancy (BUMPS) website.

title: Trazodone
text:
【0】Side effects of trazodone
=========================

【1】Like all medicines, trazodone can cause side effects in some people, but many people have no side effects or only minor ones.

【2】Common side effects
-------------------

【3】Some of the common side effects of trazodone will gradually get better as your body gets used to it. There are things you can do to help cope with them:

【4】Feeling sleepy or tired

【5】Take trazodone in the evening and try to cut down the amount of alcohol you drink. If you take trazodone twice a day, talk to your doctor. Feeling sleepy should become less of a problem after a few days as your body gets used to the medicine. Do not drive, ride a bike or use tools or machinery if you're feeling sleepy or tired.

【6】Headaches

【7】Make sure you rest and drink plenty of fluids. Try not to drink too much alcohol. Talk to your doctor if the headaches last longer than a week or are severe.

【8】Feeling sick (nausea)

【9】Try taking trazodone with or after food to see if that helps. It's best to avoid rich or spicy food while you're taking this medicine.

【10】Constipation

【11】Eat more high-fibre foods, such as fresh fruit and vegetables and cereals. Try to drink several glasses of water every day. If you can, it may also help to do some exercise.

【12】A dry mouth

【13】Try sugar-free gum or sugar-free sweets.

【14】Tell your doctor if this advice does not help or the side effects do not go away.

【15】Serious side effects
--------------------

【16】Serious side effects are rare and happen in less than 1 in 1,000 people.

【17】Call your doctor or call 111 now if:

【18】*   the whites of your eyes turn yellow, or your skin turns yellow although this may be less obvious on brown or black skin – this can be a sign of liver problems
*   you have difficulty pooing (constipation) or you're unable to pee
*   you are bruising more easily than usual or have unexplained bruising
*   you get more infections than usual, such as a sore throat or skin infections
*   you have a fast, slow or abnormal heartbeat

【19】### Immediate action required: Call 999 or go to A&E now if you have:

【20】*   a long-lasting and painful erection that lasts longer than 2 hours – this may happen even when you're not having sex
*   a seizure or fit
*   thoughts of self-harming or ending your life

【21】Find your nearest A&E

【22】Serious allergic reaction
-------------------------

【23】In rare cases, it's possible to have a serious allergic reaction (anaphylaxis) to trazodone.

【24】#### Immediate action required: Call 999 now if:

【25】*   your lips, mouth, throat or tongue suddenly become swollen
*   you're breathing very fast or struggling to breathe (you may become very wheezy or feel like you're choking or gasping for air)
*   your throat feels tight or you're struggling to swallow
*   your skin, tongue or lips turn blue, grey or pale (if you have black or brown skin, this may be easier to see on the palms of your hands or soles of your feet)
*   you suddenly become very confused, drowsy or dizzy
*   someone faints and cannot be woken up
*   a child is limp, floppy or not responding like they normally do (their head may fall to the side, backwards or forwards, or they may find it difficult to lift their head or focus on your face)

【26】You or the person who's unwell may also have a rash that's swollen, raised, itchy, blistered or peeling.

【27】These can be signs of a serious allergic reaction and may need immediate treatment in hospital.

【28】Sexual side effects
-------------------

【29】Trazodone can cause problems with ejaculation. Some people say it gives them a higher sex drive, others say it makes it lower.

【30】Other side effects
------------------

【31】These are not all the side effects of trazodone. For a full list, see the leaflet inside your medicines packet.

【32】Information:

【33】You can report any suspected side effect using the Yellow Card safety scheme.

【34】Visit Yellow Card for further information.

title: Dexamethasone eye drops
text:
【0】Common questions about dexamethasone eye drops \- Brand names: Dexafree, Dropodex, Eythalm, Maxidex
===================================================================================================

【1】How do dexamethasone eye drops work?

【2】Dexamethasone eye drops are a steroid (corticosteroid) medicine. Steroids closely copy the effects of natural hormones produced in your adrenal glands. These sit on top of your kidneys.

【3】Dexamethasone works on your immune system to reduce the symptoms of inflammatory conditions and allergic reactions such as swelling, redness and itching.

【4】When will I feel better?

【5】Your eye symptoms should start to improve quickly within a few days. Tell your doctor if you do not feel better after 7 days.

【6】Are there any long-term side effects?

【7】Once your condition has settled down, your doctor will generally recommend that you stop using this medicine.

【8】If you have been using dexamethasone eye drops for a long time, your doctor may advise you to gradually reduce the amount you use before stopping completely.

【9】Using dexamethasone continuously for a long time can increase the risk of side effects.

【10】What will happen if I stop using it?

【11】If you've been using the drops for more than a few weeks, your doctor may tell you to use them less often before you stop completely. This is to reduce the chances of your condition coming back.

【12】Talk to your doctor if your symptoms come back after you have stopped using dexamethasone eye drops.

【13】What are dexamethasone eye drops combined with an antibiotic used for?

【14】Dexamethasone can be combined with an antibiotic as eye drops, eye ointment, ear drops or ear spray.

【15】They're usually prescribed if you have eye inflammation and your eye could become infected.

【16】The eye drops and eye ointment are not usually used to treat an eye infection but the antibiotic is to prevent infection, for example while the eye heals after injury or surgery.

【17】Dexamethasone ear drops and ear spray are often used for inflammation in the ear canal (outer ear) which may be infected, for example eczema in the ear or “swimmer's ear.”

【18】Can dexamethasone eye drops be used in the ear?

【19】It is safe to use dexamethasone eye drops in the ear but only use them in the ear if advised by a doctor.

【20】Will it affect my contraception?

【21】Dexamethasone eye drops do not stop any type of contraception from working, including the combined pill or emergency contraception.

【22】Can I drive or ride a bike?

【23】For most people, using dexamethasone eye drops will not affect their ability to drive a car or cycle. However, it might help to wait 15 minutes after using the eye drops so that your vision returns to normal.

【24】The eye drops can sometimes make your eyesight blurred or cloudy. If this happens to you, do not drive a car, ride a bike, or use tools or machinery until you feel well and you can see clearly again.

【25】It's an offence to drive a car if your ability to drive safely is affected. It's your responsibility to decide if it's safe to drive. If you're in any doubt, do not drive.

【26】Talk to your doctor or pharmacist if you're unsure whether it's safe for you to drive while using dexamethasone eye drops. GOV.UK has more information on the law on drugs and driving.

【27】Can I drink alcohol while using dexamethasone eye drops?

【28】Yes, you can drink alcohol while using dexamethasone eye drops.

【29】Is there any food or drink I need to avoid?

【30】No, you can eat and drink normally while using dexamethasone eye drops.

title: Zika virus
text:
【0】Zika virus
==========

【1】**Zika virus is mainly spread by mosquitoes found in some parts of the world. For most people it's mild and not harmful, but can cause problems if you're pregnant.**

【2】Check if you're at risk of Zika virus
-------------------------------------

【3】Zika virus is usually caught by being bitten by an infected mosquito.

【4】Very rarely, you can get the virus by having sex with someone who has it.

【5】Zika virus is found in parts of:

【6】*   South and Central America
*   the Caribbean
*   the Pacific islands
*   Africa
*   Asia

【7】The type of mosquitoes that carry Zika virus are not found in the UK.

【8】Information:

【9】### Check before you travel

【10】It's important to check the risk for the country you're going to before you travel.

【11】Find out more about the Zika virus risk in specific countries on the Travel Health Pro website

【12】How to avoid Zika virus
-----------------------

【13】If you're travelling to an area where Zika virus is found, get advice from a GP, nurse, pharmacist or travel clinic before you go.

【14】It's best to do this at least 4 to 6 weeks before you travel, but you can still get advice at the last minute if you need to.

【15】There are things you can do to avoid getting Zika virus while you're travelling.

【16】### Do

【17】*   use insect repellent on your skin – make sure it's 50% DEET-based
    
*   sleep under mosquito nets treated with insecticide
    
*   wear loose clothing that covers your arms and legs – the mosquitoes that carry Zika virus are most active during the day
    

【18】Symptoms of Zika virus
----------------------

【19】Most people have few or no symptoms if they get Zika virus.

【20】If you do have symptoms, they're usually mild and last around 2 to 7 days.

【21】The most common symptoms include:

【22】*   a high temperature
*   a headache
*   sore, red eyes
*   swollen joints and joint and muscle pain
*   a rash and itching all over the body

【23】Urgent advice: Ask for an urgent GP appointment or get help from NHS 111 if:
----------------------------------------------------------------------------

【24】You've recently travelled to a country with a Zika virus risk and:

【25】*   you feel unwell
*   you or your partner are pregnant
*   you or your partner get pregnant within 3 months of coming back to the UK
*   have numbness, pins and needles, muscle weakness or pain in your feet and hands that spreads to your arms and legs

【26】You can call 111 or get help from 111 online.

【27】Get medical advice quickly if you have Zika virus symptoms while you're travelling.

【28】Treatments for Zika virus
-------------------------

【29】There are no specific treatments for Zika virus.

【30】If you have symptoms, you should:

【31】*   get plenty of rest
*   drink lots of fluids
*   take pain relief, such as paracetamol

【32】If you're pregnant and have Zika virus, your midwife or hospital doctor will talk about the risk with you and may arrange an ultrasound scan to check your baby's growth.

【33】You may also be referred to a specialist for more monitoring.

【34】Complications of Zika virus
---------------------------

【35】Zika virus can harm a developing baby if you get it when you're pregnant.

【36】It can cause problems with the baby's brain and the baby having an unusually small head (microcephaly).

【37】You can have Zika virus without having any symptoms. This is why it's important to avoid getting pregnant for up to 3 months after you've come back to the UK from a country where there's a Zika virus risk.

【38】Speak to your midwife or doctor for advice if you're worried your unborn baby may be affected by Zika virus.

【39】Rarely, Zika virus can also cause Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS), a serious condition that affects the nervous system.

【40】Information:

【41】### Find out more

【42】*   GOV.UK: how long to avoid getting pregnant after travelling to a Zika risk area
*   best use of medicines in pregnancy (bumps): Zika virus
*   Royal College of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists: Zika virus infection and pregnancy
